story:
LAWYER FIGHTS TO PROTECT ATTORNEY FREE SPEECH

Attorneys have free speech rights like every other citizen, including the right to criticize judges.  That is an important principle that I wish to have re-established by my planned appeal to the United States Supreme Court.   I am seeking donations for that appeal.  

This case that has already gotten substantial publicity.  (See links at the bottom of the page for stories on my case.)   In March of 2013, I was charged by the Indiana Supreme Court Disciplinary Commission with the violation of Rule 8.2 of the Rules of Professional Conduct.  That is the rule that purports to limit an attorney's criticism of judges and candidates for judges.

My offense?  I had written an email criticizing a judge for mishandling an estate case in which I represented one of three heirs who only received $8,000 in cash (and an interest in an LLC) out of over a million dollars in cash that passed through the estate in the six years it was open.  The email was in response to one that was sent to me and only went to the estate's attorney and others involved in the case.  The judge, who I had removed through the "lazy judge" procedure, was no longer on the case which was in its final stages of wrapping up.

The mother of the executor who I suspected of misappropriating money took the emails into the judge who demanded I apologize.   Even if I felt I owed him an apology for claiming he mishandled the estate, to do so could have been malpractice as it might have been used against my client should he take an appeal. When the apology didn't come, the judge sent the emails to the Disciplinary Commission which eventually filed charges.

Counsel for the Disciplinary Commission says it doesn't matter if a statement is public or private or even if a statement is simply an opinion.  The Commission takes the position that an attorney who criticizes a judge is subject to discipline under Rule 8.2 and that, if charged, the attorney bears the burden of proving the statement is true or the attorney is subject to sanctions.  If an attorney is out to lunch with a friend and says "I think Judge Smith is biased against my client," according to the Commission that attorney is subject to a Rule 8.2 charge and will be sanctioned unless he can prove the judge is actually biased. 

Rule 8.2 expressly adopts the New York Times v. Sullivan subjective standard for libelous free speech.  Yet that standard is routinely ignored by state supreme courts most of which employ an objective standard and switch the burden of proof to the attorney charged with misconduct.  (Indiana has never ruled definitively on the issue.)  While the United States Supreme Court has yet to decide a Rule 8.2 case, the Court has heard attorney free speech cases before and has consistently rebuffed attempts to limit attorney free speech. 

In its most recent attorney free speech case, Gentile v. Nevada, the Court said attorneys enjoy free speech like everyone else and that disciplinary rules cannot be used to limit attorney free speech execept under the narrow circumstance when an attorney is speaking out publcly about a pending case in a manner that could influence a finder-of-fact, such as a jury.   

Unfortunately Gentile and other U.S. Supreme Court precedent have increasingly been ignored as state disciplinary bodies seek to sanction attorneys for violating "civility codes."  Want to criticize a judge in an email, on Twitter, on Facebook, on an attorney bulletin board?  Think again.  You might be a target for discipline.

Gentile is now 22 years old.  The issue of attorney free speech,and especially one involving Rule 8.2, is ripe for another United States Supreme Court opinion reconfirming that attorneys have free speech rights that state bars must respect.   That protected speech must include the right of attorneys to criticize judges, especially elected judges, about their performance on the bench.

I have no doubt we will achieve success if we get the case to the United States Supreme Court and the Court agrees to hear the case.  The issue of attorney free speech uniites conservatives and liberals on the Court.  But an appeal to the Court is not cheap.  As a sole practictioner, I do not have the funds to finance this appeal by myself.  That's why I am asking for help from other attorneys and those interested in confirming the principle that attorneys do not give up their right to free speech when they are sworn into the bar.

Here are some articles discussing my case.

http://www.indystar.com/article/20130729/NEWS/307290064/Indianapolis-attorney-blogger-Paul-Ogden-faces-judicial-disciplinary-complaint

http://www.theindianalawyer.com/criticism-of-judge-results-in-discipline-case/PARAMS/article/31510

http://www.theindianalawyer.com/blogger-attorney-ogden-grilled-in-public-discipline-hearing/PARAMS/article/32049

http://www.legalethicsforum.com/blog/2013/07/hearing-today-about-indiana-lawyer-who-criticized-judge-in-private-email.html

http://lawforwriters.blogspot.com/2013/07/first-amendment-at-risk-blogger-lawyer.html

http://sheilakennedy.net/2013/07/trading-the-first-amendment-for-a-law-license/

http://ethicsalarms.com/2013/08/02/the-persecution-of-paul-ogden-the-justin-carter-of-legal-ethics/

http://www.ogdenonpolitics.com/2013/07/attorney-free-speech-and-my-hope-for.html

http://www.ogdenonpolitics.com/2013/03/indiana-attorneys-and-free-speech.html

In conclusion, I should acknowledge that many attorneys, especially those in Indiana, have expressed concern that public support of my cause might make themselves a target for discipline.  I am not aware of any law that requires that donors to this cause be disclosed and I will fight to protect the confidentiality of attorneys and others who contribute to this campaign.

Thank you for any contribution you can make to the cause of defending attorney free speech.

story:
Summary and Impact:

Hello! We are Quelab, Albuquerque’s nonprofit makerspace. Our mission is to foster and sustain an environment that promotes creativity, invention, and collaboration at the intersections of science, culture, art, and technology. Quelab is an all-volunteer member-run organization that operates a facility for anyone in the community to use.

We are well into our 3rd year of operations, and Quelab is really beginning to grow. In fact we’re bursting at the seams! Quelab version 1.0 can no longer support all the cool projects, educational workshops, and creative events that we have planned. We need to upgrade to a bigger space. Luckily, our New Location Task Force has found us an awesome building where we can relocate. Quelab version 2.0 will give our members, and the community, an enhanced creative outlet and an opportunity for continued growth. Please donate to this "Moving Expenses" fundraiser campaign and you too could take advantage of this amazing new location with all it has to offer.

What to Expect in Quelab v2.0:

With this new space we will finally have room for the professional grade tools that will set us apart from the average handy-man’s garage. We will be moving out of the "frat-house" and into a warehouse space that has room for long duration projects and more storage. We will even have room for the plethora of parts and supplies that currently cover every available surface. 

Additionally we will keep plenty of room for those with less messy projects. A space where they may hone their craft, without worrying about it getting covered in metal shavings, or drowned out by the drill press and band saw.

About this Campaign:

To fund our move, we need a deposit and some additional capital for moving expenses. The total comes to $4500. This covers the moving truck(s), construction supplies, and cleaning for the old space. In addition we need some extra funds to help defray the cost of renting both our current and new facility for the month of the move. The specific break down of how we will spend these funds is as follows:

• $1,500 for the deposit on the building
• $1,500 to pay the first month’s rent at the new space
• $500 for the physical moving expenses
• $400 to pay the first months utilities at the new space
• $400 for building supplies
• $200 to be used for incidentals

If the satisfaction of donating in support of the Albuquerque maker community wasn't enough, we've added perks at 10 different donation levels. Check them out on the right. Please give generously to our campaign today, and then share this link with your friends and family! 

Help Spread the Word!

If a monetary contribution is out of the question for you, then consider an alternative means of support. Spread the word about this project on your favorite social network and share our project with everyone you meet. If you know anyone looking to maximize their charitable deduction on their taxes this year, keep Quelab in mind.

We sincerely appreciate your generous support. Thank you!

story:
About Me & My Campaign

Hi all, thank you so much for visiting my campaign page! My name is Hannah Pedersen and I am currently a first-year student at Johnson & Wales University in Denver, Colorado, studying Sport/Event/Entertainment Management. My college experience has been amazing so far, and the opportunities I have been offered already are unimaginable. Johnson & Wales has opened up so many new doors and allowed me to see the potential I hold.  

I have been blessed with the opportunity to study abroad in Berlin, Germany during my spring term for about two and a half months, March through May 2014. This is a first-year student program, and we will be studying World History, Economics, and Business Ethics while abroad. Along with the classes, we are given the opportunity to go on weekend ventures to experience Germany firsthand. I am also trying to travel around Europe on my own to get the most out of my time there. However, I cannot afford this on my own. That’s why I need your help, to offset some of the costs such as airfare, housing, and other miscellaneous costs.

By making a contribution to my campaign, whether it is good vibes or any amount of money, you will help me attain my goal to study abroad every year that I am in school at Johnson & Wales University. This trip will be the first chapter of many in my travel diary, and anything you can do to help is greatly appreciated.

What I Need & What You Get

  • The total cost of the program is estimated to be around $9,000. All funds will go towards airfare and the program cost itself.
  • I am currently working and setting all of my earnings aside for this trip, as well as applying for scholarships. Sadly, I don’t have enough hours in my day to earn all $9,000, so ANYTHING you can contribute will help immensely.
  • All contributions amounting $15 or more will receive a neat perk, which are listed to the right. My favorite perk is the custom painting of your pet. I have been painting pop art portraits of dogs for around three years. Here is some of my work:

                           

  • Please look under the gallery tab at the top of the page to see more of my artwork!

The Impact

How your contribution will help:

  • A goal that I have set for my time in college is to study abroad as much as I possibly can. I have the chance to study abroad at least once per year while at Johnson & Wales. I am getting a head start by partaking in this program, as many students don’t get the chance to study abroad until their Junior or Senior year.
  • By studying abroad, I will become more knowledgeable about international business and cultures.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know that not everyone can contribute monetarily, but there are other ways to help:

  • Share my campaign with family, friends, co-workers, or anyone you think would have any interest in helping my cause.
  • Send all the hugs, kisses, prayers, positive thoughts, etc. my way. I need all that I can get!
  • Share your travel tips with me! I have never been overseas and would love some knowledge from seasoned travelers. Are there any places I must visit while in Germany or Europe in general? Send them my way!

If you’ve read this far, THANK YOU SO MUCH! Your time and thoughts are appreciated. Please share this page with anyone and everyone, it takes a village!

-Hannah Pedersen

story:
Who is Paul?

Paul is a young man of 25 who has recently been diagnosed, and is currently battling, Acute Myeloid Leaukemia. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acute_myeloid_leuk...
Paul is staying at the Cleveland Clinic.

What Paul Needs

Paul and his family need your help. Like so many Americans, Paul is without health insurance and his expenses will keep skyrocketing as he continues treatment for this terrible disease.
 
We are seeking donations to assist with medical expenses while he is in the hospital, as well as funding his ongoing treatment once he leaves.
 
Funds will also directly help Paul begin to live an ordinary life once he is done receiving treatments at the hospital it may be some time before he is able to work again. Donations will help with food, bills and other living expenses.

How will my donations help Paul?

Your donations will go directly to saving my dear friend's life.  They will help him get back to living life as a normal person once his treatment is complete.  You are helping a family keep a son, and helping an incredible man stay alive.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can promote this site on Facebook, Twitter, Google + and other social media sites.  You can donate food or items to several charity events that are being held in Paul's honor over the next coming months.  You can stop by and visit him. REACH OUT IN ANY WAY YOU CAN!!!

story:
Creativity happens at home, in our communities. Bill Gates once said that his biggest fear of competition is from “someone in a garage who is devising something completely new”.  In 1992 his fears came true when two Stanford graduates came up with Google in a garage. From this garage environment, Google became one of the largest competitors to Microsoft. Their innovations have expanded from their core search market to now becoming a market leader in everything from email to satellite mapping, news aggregation and mobile computing.

If garages were the entrepreneur domain of the 20thcentury and collaboration spaces are the social evolution of the do-it-yourself garage, they are naturally looking to be the innovation hotspots of the future. Having a space where people can work and share knowledge while making innovations and sharing opportunities with others is the key idea behind a collaboration space. The desire to be an entrepreneur, creator of something new and innovative or just create to create should not be ignored because you don’t have the space and resources to grow your idea. 

Whether it is growing vegetables in our community garden or welding a new sculpture in our shop. If this is not what you like, then come over and create the next big computer game or IPhone application.  You may even want to donate your time teaching a class on watercolors or how to frame a window in your house. The possibilities are endless; all it will take is you and your ideals. Ours is a diverse community and with our community learning and teaching each other there are no limits to what can be made and done.

For our collaboration/maker space to be successful C4 will need to move into a larger building with more equipment and infrastructure. With the completion of this project we will be able to expand and allow for larger projects, create an area for the arts (IE: Painting, music, sculpting), planning/building a community aquaponics greenhouse, 3D prototyping, computer design, and whatever else our members can dream up!

$20,000 is the minimum we need for renting a space, some upgrades and would be greatly appreciated.

$100,000 would give us the funding we'd need to buy a building, all upgrades and equipment, and allow for more members!

story:
Support this new media literacy and media-making program for Ottawa youth!

If our children don't grow up with realistic gender representations in the media, how can we expect them to reach for the stars?

We need your support to provide media literacy and media-making workshops to K-12 schools across Ottawa.

This program was started in response to numerous examples of online harassment, sexist and over-sexualized portrayals of women, and the lack of diversity in media representations.

Your donation will go towards materials, technical equipment, and media facilitators for a program that will train Ottawa students to critically analyze problematic mainstream media and to create fair and diverse media representations. This program will counteract bullying behaviours and educate Ottawa youth about problematic representations in the media they consume every day.

Media Action Média is a Canadian non-profit working to promote gender equity through media analysis and action.

Media Action's REPRESENT. project has been bringing Canadians and media-makers together to improve media representations of women for a year:

REPRESENT. has sparked a national conversation about media representations of women. Canadians are telling media-makers how they want representations of women and girls to change through our REPRESENT. Video Project. Community and campus groups are hosting critical conversations and workshops on media literacy with our REPRESENT. Action Kits. And REPRESENT. events are bringing media-makers and Canadians face-to-face to create better practices models for media representation of women.

On International Women's Day 2013, REPRESENT. events were held at Ryerson University in Toronto and Carleton University in Ottawa, featuring exciting workshops and presentations that sparked meaningful discussion on media representations of women. Both events were also attended by influential Canadian media-makers, such as Scott Russell, Olympic Commentator and Host of CBC Sports Weekend, and MTV Canada's Aliya Jasmine Sovani.

REPRESENT. also engaged a number of influential media panelists, including journalists and hosts from Canada's largest news organizations, some of its most respected newspapers, marketing companies and online publications, among other media industries. Our major media partners include Shameless magazine, Gender Focus and Canadian Kiosk.

Your donation will be used to bring the critical media literacy work REPRESENT. has already sparked into schools across the city and give local youth the opportunity to harness their potential as media-makers!

Special Offer for local businesses and organizations: For every donation over $50, we will enter your business or organization in a draw to win a year of advertising from Ottawa Kiosk, a $2,000 value! $100 donations will receive 3 entries in the draw. Once you have made your donation, email amanda@media-action-media.com to enter the draw.

Please share Media Action's campaign with your networks. Every bit of support helps and Indiegogo's share tools make passing the word on super easy! 

For more information on Media Action and REPRESENT., visit www.media-action-media.com  and www.representmedia.wordpress.com or contact amanda@media-action-media.com. 

If you would like a tax receipt, contact amanda@media-action-media.com
story_txt:
Support this new media literacy and media-making program for Ottawa youth!
If our children don't grow up with realistic gender representations in the media, how can we expect them to reach for the stars?
We need your support to provide media literacy and media-making workshops to K-12 schools across Ottawa.
This program was started in response to numerous examples of online harassment, sexist and over-sexualized portrayals of women, and the lack of diversity in media representations.
Your donation will go towards materials, technical equipment, and media facilitators for a program that will train Ottawa students to critically analyze problematic mainstream media and to create fair and diverse media representations. This program will counteract bullying behaviours and educate Ottawa youth about problematic representations in the media they consume every day.
Media Action Média is a Canadian non-profit working to promote gender equity through media analysis and action. 
Media Action's REPRESENT. project has been bringing Canadians and media-makers together to improve media representations of women for a year: 
REPRESENT. has sparked a national conversation about media representations of women. Canadians are telling media-makers how they want representations of women and girls to change through our REPRESENT. Video Project. Community and campus groups are hosting critical conversations and workshops on media literacy with our REPRESENT. Action Kits. And REPRESENT. events are bringing media-makers and Canadians face-to-face to create better practices models for media representation of women.
On International Women's Day 2013, REPRESENT. events were held at Ryerson University in Toronto and Carleton University in Ottawa, featuring exciting workshops and presentations that sparked meaningful discussion on media representations of women. Both events were also attended by influential Canadian media-makers, such as Scott Russell, Olympic Commentator and Host of CBC Sports Weekend, and MTV Canada's Aliya Jasmine Sovani.
REPRESENT. also engaged a number of influential media panelists, including journalists and hosts from Canada's largest news organizations, some of its most respected newspapers, marketing companies and online publications, among other media industries. Our major media partners include Shameless magazine, Gender Focus and Canadian Kiosk.
Your donation will be used to bring the critical media literacy work REPRESENT. has already sparked into schools across the city and give local youth the opportunity to harness their potential as media-makers!
Special Offer for local businesses and organizations: For every donation over $50, we will enter your business or organization in a draw to win a year of advertising from Ottawa Kiosk, a $2,000 value! $100 donations will receive 3 entries in the draw. Once you have made your donation, email amanda@media-action-media.com to enter the draw.
Please share Media Action's campaign with your networks. Every bit of support helps and Indiegogo's share tools make passing the word on super easy! 
For more information on Media Action and REPRESENT., visit www.media-action-media.com  and www.representmedia.wordpress.com or contact amanda@media-action-media.com. 
If you would like a tax receipt, contact amanda@media-action-media.com

story:
Dear Friends,

I'm getting close to realizing my dream: it's an amazing feeling to be almost there! Here's my story:

My name is Cade, I'm 26 years old, I live in Florida, and since as far back as I can recall I have wanted to work with exotic animals. Today, I'm a Zoology/Veterinary Science major focusing on exotic animal rehabilitation and am as excited as when I was a kid. Unfortunately, my journey was interrupted about 2 years ago.

In mid 2010, I developed a health problem. After several months and treatments/surgeries it was determined that the problem was actually an aggressive form of B Cell Lymphoma. It was a bigger problem than I was ready to tackle, but tackle it was the only choice. After a year of undergoing two different kinds of chemo, too many emergency hospital visits and set-backs, I am now on the road to recovery and back to pursuing my dream.

My campaign is simple: get me to Africa where I will have the opportunity to work with one of the world's formost experts on animal behavior. Kevin Richardson is respected around the world for his amazing work with the world's most exciting, dangerous, and misunderstood creatures. I have applied to work with him in South Africa in October of this year and have been accepted.

Having the opportunity to experience and learn in that environment will give me skills and knowledge unavailable in a classroom. Working with white lions, hyenas, and black leopards in their natural environment not only aids in their preservation but gives me the insight and skills to protect and rehabilitate some of the worlds most beautiful endangered species.

While at the preserve I will be building and maintaining habitats, preparing food, nurturing cubs, participating in perimeter checks for snares and poachers, site maintenance, and studying with Kevin Richardson to better understand his unique connection with these creatures.

I will include you in my adventure by blogging as frequently as possible and producing a beautiful 2013 calendar from the photos and journaling during my stay. I have arranged to blog/Skype with students and would be happy to add other schools and students to my list for those supporting my adventure.

I have raised a good bit of the necessary funding and have secured my place on the preserve, gotten my plane ticket, money for food and lodging, as well as necessary papers. I am in need of an additional $1500 to cover the costs of supplies and gear. It seems I need things that aren't amongst my belongings!!

If I am unable to raise all the needed funds, I will donate what has been raised to the preserve and Kevin Richardson's work. For more information about Kevin Richardson and his work, please visit http://www.lionwhisperer.co.za/

story:
Short Summary

Our Campaign:

"One World Welfare Org" seeks to fund to help those in Pakistan who need it most- the homeless, the laborers, and all those who otherwise do not have the support they need to seek an education and empower women to raise their living standards in Pakistan.Many children in Pakistan have not been nearly as fortunate. Many mothers will never know the empowerment that education brings. Since finishing my own education, I have discovered a love for sharing knowledge with others. First, being a volunteer in Don Bosco, Quetta - and then as an elementary school teacher in Punjab and as a lawyer.


Through my work with young children, I discovered that I felt called to use education to try to bring real, lasting change to the kinds of opportunities that are available for children in my own country. I want to make sure that every child in Pakistan has an opportunity to experience the kind of life-changing education.
Before I ask for you help, however, let me tell you a little more about my story and the current state of education in Pakistan so you can better understand where I am coming from and how deeply committed I am to seeing this through.

Our Background:

One World Welfare Organization (OWWO) was established in 2009 with the goal of improving the lives of women and children in Pakistan through education. OWWO seeks to help those in Pakistan who need it most- the homeless, the laborers, and all those who otherwise do not have the support they need to seek an education. We worked on the educational needs of poor children; and second, empowering women to find and express their much needed voices in the community. Our educational goals enveloped the needs of children who, through necessity, became beggars, shoe-polishers, and laborers. In turn, they were poor, orphaned and from broken families.  

"OWWO" is the Pakistani based volunteer charity Organization which alleviates the suffering of the poorest people of Pakistan. We supply the basic necessities of life together with education, medical and other assistance.Our main object is to uplift the demoralized and exploited community of the society and fight for their rights in Pakistan. In practice, it stretches its care to the poor and orphan children.We believe to "help those in real need regardless of age,past life,race,color,caste and creed or religion and especially to children."


The Challenge:

"OWWO" is based in Youhanabad, Ferozepur Road, Lahore, in the province of Punjab, Pakistan. We established out first school in Youhanabad, a suburb there. When we first started, we only had 30 to 35 students. Since then, that number has risen to over 150. At the moment, we are renting a space to house the school. The fees are currently being covered by the Chairman of OWWO, Mrs. N.K. Gill; as well as donations from many generous individuals and families that see the good that our efforts bring. However, these donations are only enough to cover the bare minimum costs of running our one school.
And so, this is where all of you come in. OWWO wishes to build a school- we need money to purchase land and pay for the construction of a facility that would have the space and resources to serve many more students than we do now.


Our Solution / Your Impact:

A new facility would allow us to support both children's education, as well as youth vocational training and adult education. We want to offer a wide variety of vocations, including computer courses, tailoring, cosmetology, and culinary skills. We want to offer cheap financing to our students for the purchase of equipment related to the skills they are seeking to develop. We want to enable these empowered women to pursue these careers by maintaining shops where they can exercise their new found skills and make money before they find work elsewhere.

By establishing "One World Welfare School" with afternoon session in addition to its morning session, the "One World Welfare Org" will be able to benefiting a grand total of 355 children in the 2015 school year.  

Every dollar you give will go towards funding our children,youth & women  education program. We believe in quality services to all children, regardless of income or race. The student-driven learning approach, can have a powerful effect in high-poverty, high need communities. We are confident that together we will transform the lives of children and help build a brighter future for our community.

Our Vision and Long Term Goals:

We are tenacious in maintaining the legacy of our founder, Mrs. N;k.Gill, to help our community reach its full potential and fulfill its promise. We want to cultivate the use of autonomy as a learning tool to empower children, women & youth of all backgrounds. We will do this by expanding our staff, offering enrichment programs & growing a community.

Moreover,We provide a comprehensive educational experience to all children regardless of their color, religion, caste or creed. We offer them an education with very low fees of about 100 PKR (that’s just over $1 US Dollar) per student; some are totally free. We also provide free books, bags, shoes and uniforms to the students who cannot afford them.In the interest of expanding to reach more children, we considered establishing our very own stand-alone building. For that, we moved forward and purchased some land. Now we need further financial support in the construction of a school.
A number of students will be eligible for scholarships to put toward their studies. For the ineligible, we will arrange a small loan guarantee for their study fees, which they pay us back in installments. The terms and conditions for the loans will be simple. 

As I mentioned above, the second part of the project is to empower the youth and provide them some trainings through which they earn a livelihood and help their families as well as themselves in their education. For that, we are going to open a training center for them in which we offer them an opportunity to train in areas such as: tailoring, beautician/make-up arts, and culinary skills.

In the beginning, we will open a tailoring center for them. They will have a choice of three different diploma courses: one for 6 months, a year and 2 years. After completing their courses, we will help them in every conceivable way we can. The capacity of one badge is round about 50 students in a badge.

In the future, we intend to open a training boutique for them. The students of our institution work through their studies by making dresses. We will sell the dresses; 50% will go to the student dress makers and the other 50% to our NGO (One World Welfare). Upon course completion, many of the women could be provided their very own sewing machines. This will provide them the opportunity to earn money and slowly pay back the nominal tuition fee of the program and the machine.
We will emphasize the successes as they happen, which will encourage more and more women and children to participate, as well.



Youth of "OWWO"


My Story

I was born in Sialkot, Pakistan - the place that is famous for sports good, and being the town near the border of Jammu and Kashmir. In 1996, my family moved to the Lahore. There, my father started his practice in Lahore High Court as a Lawyer. When we moved to Lahore, we had a financial crisis earlier.

From a young age, I learned from my parents the value and importance of equality for all people. As a successful Lawyer, my father and given my family a comfortable life. My Father  with his 2 Lawyer friends made a "Christian Lawyer Association" and he became the Chairman of Christian Lawyer Association. They fight for the rights of poor especially Christians in Pakistan.  Instead, my parents chose to stay and take a stand for our people. Through his selfless actions, and the lives he touched - I learned that what my nation needs most is people like him who will fight for what they believe in.

Moreover, the work my parents have done has shown me the power to influence society in a constructive way. The power of being the change you want to see in the world. I deeply desire to be part of this kind of social change in my nation.I believe that creative, informed approaches that parallel the kind of work my parents & uncle have done for the availability of resources in Pakistan can help make education available for the under-served children in my country. It is also my hope that through the availability of education. 


The severe lack of education in Pakistan is causing increases in ignorance, discrimination and religious extremism. Since 2006 Pakistan has had an average of 30 bombings per year. Terrorist attacks on school but not a single damage in Punjab.Pakistan spends only 2.1 % of its GDP on education, in this budget they thinks to increase it, let see.Poverty is a big hurdle in education. According to UNICEF, 17.6 % of Pakistani children are working and supporting their families. Children working as domestic help is a common phenomenon in Pakistan, and this sector employs more girls than boys.


I have many dreams and ideas for how I can bring change to Pakistan. Opening a welfare school based on educational best practices, teacher prep programs and eventually working alongside the government to influence decisions about education.By becoming a well-educated, empowered woman - I will be in a better position to help other women do the same as my mother did.By becoming a well-educated, empowered woman - I will be in a better position to help other women do the same.
In general, i believe:

By becoming a well-educated, empowered woman - I will be in a better position to help other women do the same.

A chance to learn from some of the world's most gifted and knowledgeable educators
A chance to learn how to navigate complex power structures and influence policy-level decision making
Opportunities and doors to opportunities that can help me transform education in Pakistan.
 A network of other highly motivated, gifted, well-connected education professionals whose experience, knowledge and talents I can call upon when needed.
I may not be able to achieve my goal of opening a model school and transforming education in Pakistan immediately after graduation.
Opportunities will present themselves in life that may offer a more realistic value proposition - for example working at an education NGO that is already deeply involved in a well-developed, hands-on educational reform program in another developing nation. This way, I can gain the practical experience needed to bring this kind of change to Pakistan.

Eventually, once I have the education, experience and knowledge I need to bring change to my country, it is my greatest hope that I can find a way to use social entrepreneurship and welfare schools to set an example for Pakistan, and be the change I wish to see there.
With time, understanding and a lot of hard work, I know I can achieve this goal - but I need your help.

**Because of Indiegogo's  crowd funding  structure - I'm starting with $60,000 but hoping we can exceed it!**

I'm asking you to make an investment in the future of education in Pakistan, through me. Since most of you don't know me, and may even be struggling with student debts of your own - I realize this is a lot to ask. I can only assure you that I wouldn't be asking for hard-earned money from strangers unless I was absolutely convinced of my goals and tenaciously resolute in my commitment to pursuing and meeting them.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Share Our Story!

Tell your networks and media contacts about the "One World Welfare Org", our small but mighty school in Youhanabad, Lahore. Share our post in Facebook, Tweet about us, Instagram us and make as much noise by harnessing the power of all your social networks, every day during our campaign. 

Increase the Impact of Your Giving!

Match contributions and sponsor a week in Indiegogo.  Let us know if you are part of a company that has payroll giving, gift match opportunities or has a Corporate Social Responsibility program that supports local communities and early childhood education initiatives. 

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Spread the word, each share gets us closer to our goal!!

What You Get in Return:
Every donor gets the knowledge they are investing in a long-term solution to Pakistan's education problem. A lasting solution, that makes a real difference. In addition to this, we are offering a few souvenirs to our donors to let them know how much we appreciate their help:

 Thanks note.

Acknowledgement with a shout-out on all our social media platforms!

A digital picture of a Pakistani school going children holding a "Thank You" sign- with your name.

Original Punjabi/Urdu music fully written and composed by budding Pakistani musicians (I know them personally!)

  An authentic traditional hand made Punjabi scarf. 



 A beautiful, hand-crafted, reversible bracelet with our Logo on it! 

 T-Shirt & mug of NGO.

Hand made traditional Punjabi Jewellery along with the painting made by children.

Traditional Punjabi Crockery.

Hand maid traditional Punjabi dress.

A tour package of 3 months volunteer work with us and have amazing experience,people and amazing food! See some pictures here:

We can't do these things without your support. By donating to our cause, you are helping future generations of Pakistani women and children to raise and keep themselves out of the poor standard of living they find themselves in now.

Thank you so much for taking the time to learn about my situation, my hopes and my goals.Whether or not you can afford to partner with me at this time - I hope that you will reach out to us on our Facebook page, on Twitter or by email and say hello!
We would also be very grateful if you could share this page or our website at http://www.oneworldwelfareorganization.weebly.com with your friends and family.

Acknowledgement with a shout-out on all our social media platforms!A digital picture of a Pakistani school going children holding a "Thank You" sign- with your name.Original Punjabi/Urdu music fully written and composed by budding Pakistani musicians (I know them personally!)  An authentic traditional hand made Punjabi scarf.  A beautiful, hand-crafted, reversible bracelet with our Logo on it!  T-Shirt & mug of NGO.Hand made traditional Punjabi Jewellery along with the painting made by children.Traditional Punjabi Crockery.Hand maid traditional Punjabi dress.A tour package of 3 months volunteer work with us and have amazing experience,people and amazing food! See some pictures here:We can't do these things without your support. By donating to our cause, you are helping future generations of Pakistani women and children to raise and keep themselves out of the poor standard of living they find themselves in now.Thank you so much for taking the time to learn about my situation, my hopes and my goals.Whether or not you can afford to partner with me at this time - I hope that you will reach out to us on our Facebook page, on Twitter or by email and say hello!We would also be very grateful if you could share this page or our website at http://www.oneworldwelfareorganization.weebly.com with your friends and family.

story:
It costs $35 a month to sponsor a child at the Baba Ndogo Elementary School in the Mathare Valley slums just outside Nairobi, Kenya. For the price of a cup of coffee per day, a child in desperate poverty will recieve a school uniform, shoes, school supplies, basic medical care, two nutritious meals a day and a quality education.

Tim Hooker, his wife Fiona and son Quinlan visited the school in 2011 while they were on holiday in Kenya when they spent a day with Missions of Hope International, the NGO that builds and runs a number of schools within the slums. They returned in 2012 when they delivered 800 pairs of crocs shoes to the kids that had kindly been donated by friends, family and crocs UAE themselves. These visits were the subject of Fiona's photography exhibition she staged in Dubai in January 2013 to raise awareness of the appauling living conditions yet amazing sense of community that exists in the Mathare Slums. They have stayed in contact ever since.

The Jebel Raiders would like to raise money by cycling through the Alps for this very worthy cause.

story:
Hello World!

I am Salima Taylor, a student residing in Durham, North Carolina. Currently, I am a senior Public Health Education major at North Carolina Central University (NCCU). GO EAGLES!
As a child my family lived in Senegal, West Africa for several years where I experienced the impact of extreme poverty on health outcomes. This experience afforded me the opportunity, at a young age, to witness the health concerns of under served populations. The villagers would appeal to me for medical care and I would return to my mother on their behalf.  In retrospect, I was acting as an advocate, ensuring that the villagers received the care they needed in hopes of preventing worsening of their illnesses.The great importance of health continued to stick with me when my family moved to the United States.
In my community, I have volunteered in community gardens, mentored elementary school students, and been a public health research fellow. This 2 year program has enabled me to work on cancer research at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. This is my second summer in this program. Please check out my LinkedIn account to learn more about my roles and responsibilities as well as deliverables I have completed during my time as an intern.

https://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=274000585&trk=nav_responsive_tab_profile

In addition to the work I do in the community, I am also actively involved in on campus activities. I have held executive board positions in various student led organizations, maintained a competitive grade point average, been instrumental in coordinating a forum on the Affordable Care Act and a Leadershape Institute participant.
The previously listed public health experiences have challenged me to have a healthy disregard for the impossible. I found myself submitting abstracts to academic conferences, most note worthy APHA’s Annual Meeting and Exposition, producing research posters, and applying to a global health course in South Africa. 

South Africa!

Global Health Issues in South Africa is a month long course that will expose students to the healthcare infrastructure in South Africa, public health policies, and disease endemic to the country. Students will engage with current professionals in the field, conduct their own research and attend lectures on the topics listed about.

This course is an opportunity for me to experience, in my adult life, the interconnectedness of the world. To understand and gain perspective on global issues in order to have a greater level of cultural competence enabling me to become more tolerable of all people. This attribute is vital to public health professionals because we must interact and serve many diverse populations. 

As I plan for graduate school and my professional career, it is imperative that I have some experience in the field that I plan to get a graduate degree in. Going on this journey to South Africa will give me insight into what it is like working in the global health field. It is experiences such as this one that will shape my career path and give me exposure to fellow students with similar interest. 

Traveling to South Africa also provides me with a platform to study health disparities. As I do cancer health disparities research in NC, I am acutely aware of the burden of chronic disease in minority populations. Diabetes has been especially devastating in populations that have taken on a western diet while decreasing physical activity levels. Public health professional must work to decrease the negative impact of westernization especially in regards to diabetes. The World Health Organization (WHO) states from 2000 to 2030 the number of people in the world with Diabetes will roughly double (171,000,000 to 366,000,000 respectively). That is only 30 years! It is because of these rates that I am taking part in this course in South Africa.

Funds!

  • Program tuition and fees: $6,516

This also includes room and board while in South Africa. I have received a $3,000 scholarship from the Organization for Tropical Studies which has greatly helped! This leaves a $3,516 balance on my account. This is what I need help paying off. I have listed below other expenses that I have already used personal funds for.

Other expenses include:

  • Plane ticket: $2,150
  • Miscellaneous: 1,000
Miscellaneous include: passport fee, Megabus ticket, supplies, travel vaccinations and spending money for myself while in South Africa


I have a couple perks for individuals able to donate below! I would love for you to be a part of my academic journey :)

If you are not able to donate, please circulate my campaign on your social media accounts and encourage others to donate!

story:
My Story

My name is Dominique Fishback, I am a 20 year old Acting Major and Spoken word poet at Pace University in the Honors College.  I have 3 semesters left to finish my Bachelor of a Theater Arts degree with a minor in Arts and Entertainment Management. I am launching this campaign to take my education into my own hands.  I am tired of hearing Financial Aid tell me “You are closed out this semester,” “there’s nothing else we can do for you” and “take out a loan,” – a loan the bank always denies. I think the saddest thing is when a person, especially from “the hood” (a low income area) cries so hard, not because of the living circumstances, or the police brutality, or violence they face daily but because they have been told they do not have enough money to get their college degree. I am that person because every semester, after loans, I still have an $8,000 balance to pay out of pocket; with three semesters to go, I need $24,000 to finish college.

To this point, I have made up the balance through performing original poems.   Last May, I rode the trains of NYC and did poetry to raise money. I have won several competitions, and have also received tuition support from Tami and Shaunie from the Basketball Wives (http://www.vh1.com/video/misc/668270/project-girls.jhtml#id=1666500.) Freshmen year, my uncle cosigned for a $30,000 loan and he cannot afford to do it again. I have utilized every option and have no others to cover the next three semesters; therefore, I am at risk of having to drop-out.  The success of this campaign would let me know that every fight I’ve made to stay in college thus far and all the accomplishments I’ve made through my academic career have not been done in vain. I went to college because I knew that it was the best way to get started at a career that would take me away from the everyday nonsense of my neighborhood.  I was valedictorian in my high school and got accepted into Pace as below average. However, I worked hard and received a 3.8 GPA at the university, and got accepted into their honors college.

So far, at Pace I have had the opportunity to meet and interact with people from different places in the world and of different ethnicities. Because I am able to be in a college outside of Brooklyn, I have a more open and diverse mentality. I now have a much greater appreciation of the world and its many perspectives that I would not otherwise have.

 

The Impact

By donating to my college education, this campaign will not only help me, but have a powerful impact on many other people. Through my words and experiences, and with the direction of a nonprofit theater organization called Project Girl Performance Collective, (www.projectgirlperformancecollective.com) which creates a safe space for young women to write and perform their own words, I have learned and spoken out for the needs of impoverished girls worldwide. Our performances and values are in such high demand that we have been commissioned by the United Nation to perform on many occasions (including for the Secretary General), tour nationally on their “Girl Up” Unite for Girls campaign, and met with President Obama’s advisor to discuss our mission. At the end of the day, I know that my voice and words no longer belongs to just me but to anyone who believes in my advocacy. I write, perform, and speak “for the ones who can’t, who won’t, the ones that don’t, the ‘doesn’t know how’s and the ‘too scared to’ and the ‘I don’t have the same platforms you do.’

If this campaign is not successful, it will be harder to not to be one of the many statistics in my neighborhood – stuck and lost. For 20 years, I have rejected the negative influences of my neighborhood and the negative stereotypes associated with being from my neighborhood; I want to help others do the same. There are many people who believe in me, and I really want to make them proud.  The first step is graduating from college.  I know I can make it, but I need to finish what I started at Pace to be a successful advocate for those without this opportunity.

 

What We Need & What You Get

I need to raise $ 24,000 in the next two months to ensure I can graduate from the Honors College at Pace University -- $8,000 by December 31, 2011 for next semester alone. . If I don’t receive the full amount of remaining tuition, I will create another campaign and try again.  But again, I must raise at least $8,000 by December 31, 2011 to stay in school next semester.

Please know any donation amount is greatly appreciated.  There will be perks at different levels of giving!

·         Shoutout on Facebook - $15-25

·         Book of original poems (PDF version) - $50

·         Performance at schools in any of the 5 boroughs - $250 (negotiable)

·         Performance at events  - $500 (colleges and universities); $1000 for corporations

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to donating whatever amount possible, please help this campaign by spreading the word. Send the link to everyone and anyone you know. Post it on Facebook, blog it, tweet it, e-mail it, talk about it, and share on any other social networks out there.  Encourage friends, family, and contacts to watch my YouTube videos and “like” my Facebook acting page to get to know me better. http://www.youtube.com/user/Divinelyfavored91?feature=mhee http://www.facebook.com/#!/Dyme.Actress)

http://twitter.com/#!/Dymeactress

Finally, feel free to have them reach out to me at Dactress@gmail.com to talk further about my plans: graduating from Pace and pursuing a career in Acting.

Thank you, in advance, for all of your support.

story:
Hello!

 

If you support a clean, sustainable future for you, your kids and all the cute animals on earth, then you are our kind of person. 

We are a team passionate people committed to creating this positive future via green innovation and sustainable developemnt. 

We have a really special enviornment of innovation here in the Bay Area and, with your support, we can plant these seeds of innovation in other global cities.

We will be appearing at all the major events at the Rio+20 Earth Summit, engaging and collaborating with people from all over the planet. We want to amplify the impact of all that we are doing here and spread it to the world. 

 

The clock is ticking... help us get working!

 

Thanks!!!

The Bay2Rio Team.





What is The Innovation Bus? 

The Innovation Bus is a highly visible, attention-getting and fun mobile showcase of socially responsible businesses who are using innovation to solve social and ecological problems while growing the economy.

The goal is to connect with others, sow the seeds of innovation in other cities and feature forward-looking organizations. The Innovation Bus will feature hands-on demonstrations (provided by partners) and the “Innovation Presentation”, which explains what the innovation is and how companies and cities in the Bay Area specifically are involved. 

 

Who will see it? What are the media outlets?

The bus will be seen physically by most of the 50,000 delegates and business in attendance at Rio+20, and we anticipate coverage of the Innovation Bus in the following outlets: 

The New York Times: Dot Earth blog, Jim Witkin 

GreenBiz: Chairman & Executive Editor, Joel Makower

Sustainable Brands/ Triple Pundit: Editor-In-Chief, Nick Aster 

Huffington Post, Reporter, Lucia Graves

San Jose Mercury News, Environmental Reporter, Paul Rogers 

Treehugger, Business and Energy Editor, Mat McDermott

The Bold Italic, Head of Business Development, Mat Rick

CSR Newswire

7x7


Who we are?

BAY2RIO+20 is a delegation of civic leaders, entrepreneurs, activists and innovators dedicated to building collaborative bridges between the innovation centers of Brazil and the United States.

Kicking off with events in Rio and San Francisco leading up to and during the Rio+20 United Nations Convention on Sustainable Development (Earth Summit), Bay2Rio+20 is committed to dramatically moving the needle on social and ecological issues by sewing and showcasing the seeds of innovation in cities across the world.

 

Bay2Rio+20 is bringing the bay area’s “ethos for the innovator” to Rio. We will be extenuating the bay area spirit of collaboration, radical self-expression, and belief that something better is possible. We will highlight how this ethos provides the seeds for innovation to grow in technology, sustainability, design and business and how these industries cross-pollinate ideas to develop services and products.

We will highlight various organizations and partnerships that live the bay area’s ethos for the innovator and demonstrate how an open mind and open heart can affect sustainable development for our cities.

What is the opportunity?

We are looking for private and corporate donations to fuel the bus. In return, you or your organization will get publicity on a global scale and contribute to goodwill of the world.

story:
In one sentence: 

Fund Patrick Gibbs (US$500-800) to get on the LibreBus Cono Sur for two weeks, helping spread libre culture with an ecological awareness, and connecting first-hand with communities in Argentina and other LibreBus crew members to learn from their experiences and situation.

 
    (If you already think this idea seems wonderful, you can donate now! and/or email me: patricklibre-at-riseup-dot-net.)
 

A little more detail:

LibreBus Cono Sur is travelling through Chile, Argentina, Uruguay, and Paraguay with 20-ish people on board (called librenauts) participating in events about freedom of expression, free/open-access educational materials, freedom to share, free/libre/open-source software, biodiverysity, and gender. I met the LibreBus organizers at Hacks/Hackers Buenos Aires, said I wanted to join, and they invited me to participate in the final two weeks of LibreBus's route, as we recognize that my skills, experience, and perspective could add to the LibreBus project. They'll cover my expenses to participate, and that leaves me paying some related expenses, such as changing the date of my flight to the US, totalling US$ 500. If I receive more than $500, I'll put that money into followup, such as doing more LibreBus-themed events in Buenos Aires and Houston.
 
You can access the presentation directly if you want to see it at your own pace, instead of as a video -- change slides by clicking or with the arrow keys. I also translated the presentation to Spanish.
 
    (If you like the sound of this, you can donate now, and/or contact me.)
 

Cost details, in US dollars:

  • $300 to United Airlines, change flight to the US from September 12 to October 30.
  • $200, food, phone, and local transport during October
  • beyond $500:
    • $50, miscellaneous expenses during LibreBus trip
    • $50, photocopy fliers and informational pamphlets
    • $50, Internet hosting with May First / People Link, domain name registrations, email and VPN services from Riseup.net
    • $150, long distance bus travel to do events in Santa Fe province
  • beyond $800:
    • share funding with LibreBus project
    • spend money organizing ecologically-integrative free/libre culture events in Texas, maybe even a LibreBus.
If I don't reach my goal of $500, I won't get any money -- so if you want your donation to matter, spread the word so that we reach the goal, I get the money, I go on the LibreBus, I give you gifts, and I carry on the LibreBus project wherever I go next (probably Houston).
 
    (If this makes sense to you, you can donate now, and/or contact me.)
 

What I would do with LibreBus:

  • __ A workshop about appropriate technology and the Global Village Construction Set (Open Source Ecology) with teenagers at a rural school in José de la Quintana, Córdoba, north central Argentina.
  • __ Explain how May First / People Link functions as a democractic membership-based Internet services cooperative, and invite reflections and participation, with the purpose of catalysing an Argentine node of May First / People Link.
  • __ Explain the connections between cutural healing (which includes techniques such as co-counseling, popular education, power analysis, nature awareness) and free/libre culture (which includes software, art, books, videos, and more, with licenses that encourage sharing).
  • __ Spread my invitation to the free/libre culture community, and all people, to include in our sense of community the people who manufacture the computers that we use and that run the Internet, and to include the rivers and watersheds where computer-related mining, manufacturing, and dumping happen. In other words, as we create and use libre software, let's pay attention to what makes this possible, and let's use our intelligence to foster awareness, freedom, and responsibility throughout the cycle of producing, using, and recycling/dumping computers. See drafts in Spanish: Expandir estro Concepto de la Comunidad de la Cultura Libre and Mi Compu No Es Virtual.
  • __ Help translate LibreBus materials to English.
  • __ Apply my community living facilitation skills to LibreBus events, and to life on the bus. 
    (If this seems useful as a step forward in libre culture, you can donate now, and/or contact me.)
 

Why me:

I graduatedn 2011 with a BSc in Integrative EcoSocial Design from Gaia University (my portfolio). I worked with the University managing the website and designing the community and academic processes, and in 2009 I participated in a cooperative that ran the Ecovillage Training Center. Currently I work from a bioregional perspective, supporting the development of mutual support and education networks, focusing on cultural healing, environmental justice, and appropriate technologies.
 
For more details, see: about me at my website and my LibreBus proposal in Spanish.
 

Perks/gifts for you, donors:

If you donate, you get your name on a donors' list on my website, and depending on how much you donate, I'll mention you in a picturesque video of homage to integrative/libre/free culture supporters; I'll write you a poem about the LibreBus and work your name into it somehow; I'll have a one hour conversation with you, perhaps a software tutorial or active listening about whatever you're working on or want to talk about; and/or a cat-sized sculpture expressing the LibreBus trip! How about that!

If you can't donate money:

If you decide not to donate money, you can still put your effort into fostering libre, resposible culture. Take up the banner of librenaut wherever you are, and stay in touch -- encouragement and stories from your neighborhood go a long way to inspire me and others.

If you want to donate directly instead of using this IndieGoGo page:

First, note that I only get the IndieGoGo money if total donations are $500 or more. Still, maybe you have a reason that you refuse to use IndieGoGo -- you can send money via PayPal, WePay, or Flattr, Bitcoin (1AF9UY7DGukLHgo2jC7KKEJi9bStgJsvEX), or you can email me at patricklibre-at-riseup-dot-net for further communication (GPG key ID E726C6BB). Remember, please use this IndieGoGo page unless you have a specific reason to use something else -- this way I'm more likely to cross the $500 threshold.
story_txt:
In one sentence: 
Fund Patrick Gibbs (US$500-800) to get on the LibreBus Cono Sur for two weeks, helping spread libre culture with an ecological awareness, and connecting first-hand with communities in Argentina and other LibreBus crew members to learn from their experiences and situation.
 
    (If you already think this idea seems wonderful, you can donate now! and/or email me: patricklibre-at-riseup-dot-net.)
 
A little more detail:
LibreBus Cono Sur is travelling through Chile, Argentina, Uruguay, and Paraguay with 20-ish people on board (called librenauts) participating in events about freedom of expression, free/open-access educational materials, freedom to share, free/libre/open-source software, biodiverysity, and gender. I met the LibreBus organizers at Hacks/Hackers Buenos Aires, said I wanted to join, and they invited me to participate in the final two weeks of LibreBus's route, as we recognize that my skills, experience, and perspective could add to the LibreBus project. They'll cover my expenses to participate, and that leaves me paying some related expenses, such as changing the date of my flight to the US, totalling US$ 500. If I receive more than $500, I'll put that money into followup, such as doing more LibreBus-themed events in Buenos Aires and Houston.
 
You can access the presentation directly if you want to see it at your own pace, instead of as a video -- change slides by clicking or with the arrow keys. I also translated the presentation to Spanish.
 

    (If you like the sound of this, you can donate now, and/or contact me.)

 
Cost details, in US dollars:

$300 to United Airlines, change flight to the US from September 12 to October 30.
$200, food, phone, and local transport during October

beyond $500:

$50, miscellaneous expenses during LibreBus trip
$50, photocopy fliers and informational pamphlets
$50, Internet hosting with May First / People Link, domain name registrations, email and VPN services from Riseup.net
$150, long distance bus travel to do events in Santa Fe province



beyond $800:

share funding with LibreBus project
spend money organizing ecologically-integrative free/libre culture events in Texas, maybe even a LibreBus.


If I don't reach my goal of $500, I won't get any money -- so if you want your donation to matter, spread the word so that we reach the goal, I get the money, I go on the LibreBus, I give you gifts, and I carry on the LibreBus project wherever I go next (probably Houston).
 
    (If this makes sense to you, you can donate now, and/or contact me.)
 
What I would do with LibreBus:

__ A workshop about appropriate technology and the Global Village Construction Set (Open Source Ecology) with teenagers at a rural school in José de la Quintana, Córdoba, north central Argentina.
__ Explain how May First / People Link functions as a democractic membership-based Internet services cooperative, and invite reflections and participation, with the purpose of catalysing an Argentine node of May First / People Link.
__ Explain the connections between cutural healing (which includes techniques such as co-counseling, popular education, power analysis, nature awareness) and free/libre culture (which includes software, art, books, videos, and more, with licenses that encourage sharing).
__ Spread my invitation to the free/libre culture community, and all people, to include in our sense of community the people who manufacture the computers that we use and that run the Internet, and to include the rivers and watersheds where computer-related mining, manufacturing, and dumping happen. __ Help translate LibreBus materials to English.

__ Apply my community living facilitation skills to LibreBus events, and to life on the bus.

story:
Hi! I'm Rana Tayara, a Lebanese Psychologist living in Australia. Since 2006 and through my work for my PhD in Trauma, I have seen the amount of childhood trauma due to sexual abuse that many children have suffered from in silence. Silence because of guilt, shame, fear and ignorance.

In October of this year I decided to dedicate my platform to raise awareness around child sexual abuse and how to educate ourselves and our children to help prevent this from happening. 

Knowledge around body safety is key! This is why I decided  to create this calendar for children aged 6+ to remind them of important body safety rules and concepts.

Goal

The goal of this campaign is not just to raise children and parents awareness around body safety, but to also raise fund to support 2 great initiatives that are aiming at helping Lebanon and the Lebanese: Impact Lebanon and Let's Play. 

Let's Play's mission is to transform the school playgrounds in the areas in Beirut affected by the Port Explosion and to provide those schools and the children with a place of adventure and play. Two schools will enter the pilot phase hoping to then help all 44 schools affected by the blast.

75% of the proceeds from the Impact Lebanon Perks (ILP) will go to Impact Lebanon Initiative.

75% of the proceed  from the Let's Play Perks (LPP) will go to Let's Play Initiative.

25% will go to cover printing, shipping and all other expenses.

You can participate in the fundraiser by purchasing any of the perks mentioned below.

 

The Calendars

You can order one or a selection

ILP Initiative
ILP Desk Calendars- Size: 8.39" x 3.86"- 213 x 98 mm

ILP Classic Wall Calendar- Size: 8.5"x11"

ILP XL Wall Calendar- Size: 11"x14"

ILP Digital Calendar +I Am The Boss of My Body eWorkbook

ILP Desk Calendar + I Am The Boss of My Body eWorkbook

ILP Classic Wall Calendar + I AM The Boss of My Body eWorkbook

ILP XL Wall Calendar + I AM The Boss of My Body eWorkbook

 

LPP Initiative

LPP Digital Calendar +I Am The Boss of My Body eWorkbook+ It's Ok Not To Be OK eWorkbook

LPP Desk Calendars + I Am The Boss of My Body eWorkbook + It's Ok Not To Be OK eWorkbook

LPP Classic Wall Calendar + I AM The Boss of My Body eWorkbook + It's Ok Not To Be OK eWorkbook

LPP XL Wall Calendar + I AM The Boss of My Body eWorkbook+ It's Ok Not To Be OK eWorkbook

story:
Inaugural 5K Run / 2K Walk on October 20th, 2012 

for the benefit of Emerging Strategies for Learning and Leadership Inc., a 501 (c) (3) not for profit organization. To learn more about ES, see below or visit our website.

__________________________________________________

REGISTER TO RUN OR WALK:
Have we inspired you to Run/Walk for the cause? 

Email ESRunWalk@gmail.com to join the group.

__________________________________________________

SPREAD THE WORD: Please share this campaign information with your friends, family and work colleagues.  

Emerging Strategies - Join us on Facebook 

Prepare Inc. - Join us on Facebook

___________________________________________________________________________

DONATE:  Please support the Runners and Walkers with your tax-deductible donation. You can help us reach our goal of raising $2500 by October 20th, 2012!

DONATE HERE!

___________________________________________________________________________

Can you donate $20 in honor of the 20th Anniversary of Prepare Inc.?  Or a multiple of $20?  Help us raise the bar and exceed our fundraising goals.

RSVP: Prepare Inc.’s 20th Anniversary Party on October 20, 2012. 

Click here for event details!

___________________________________________________________________________

Donations in larger multiples of $20 (you alone or as a group) earn bonuses as follows:

BONUS:

20x20 = $400 – Prepare Inc. will offer a two hour intro workshop to any one or any group that donates $400, at their Chelsea Training Center or anywhere in Manhattan. The same donation provides a scholarship position in our 20-hour Basics class, or you can designate a community-based organization to receive that program.
 
20x200 = $4000 – Prepare Inc. will sponsor a teen basics class of 12 hours or 2 kids classes of 6 hours each, to any one or any group that donates $4000, at their Chelsea Training Center or anywhere in Manhattan.  Alternatively, you can designate a school or community based organization to receive that program. 

__________________________________________________

MORE ABOUT EMERGING STRATEGIES

Emerging Strategies for Leadership & Learning Inc. is a 501(c) (3) not-for-profit organization dedicated to providing the most effective personal safety and communications training to girls, boys and adults and their service providers in at-risk and underserved communities.  Emerging Strategies’ training programs are based on the Prepare/IMPACT curriculum that teaches individuals to identify appropriate safety boundaries, effective verbal communications of such boundaries and the physical techniques for maximizing personal safety. This training is grounded in an acknowledgement of self-value that is reinforced for each and every participant.  

Since inception, Emerging Strategies has provided numerous Scholarships and collaborated with Community Partner Programs in the Greater New York/New Jersey area.

Individual Scholarships

Over 60 individual scholarships have been awarded since 2001.

Community Partners

Girls for Gender Equity in Sports, The River East School, The Urban Assembly School for the Urban Environment, Power Play NYC Summer Sports Leadership Academy, Legal Outreach, Sadie Nash Leadership Project, The Retreat Center, Harlem Day Charter School, Five Children's Foundation, Marble Collegiate Church, Morristown Neighborhood House, Girls Inc. and Columbia University Business School, American Family Therapy Academy, North Shore Family and Child Guidance Center, Andrus, and more. 

SUCCESS STORIES

Don't just take it from us - read inspiring stories from participants who have directly benefited from Prepare Inc. training here!  And read testimonials from Emerging Strategies program participants here and Prepare Inc. participants here!

story:
Short Summary

Since 1989, the International Youth Leadership Institute (IYLI), a New York City nonprofit organization, has sponsored overseas study programs for African American and Latino high school students. This summer, students will study environmental science in Brasil and renewable energy in Senegal.Our campaign provides scholarships for students who otherwise wouldn't have this opportunity.

IYLI's programs, in Africa and Latin America expose students to the world outside their community and empower them as global citizens, not only citizens of the Bronx, Harlem or other NYC neighborhoods. During a month overseas, they study language, science, government and community development, delve deeply into social and political issues, practice research skills, contribute as volunteers in their host community and explore international study and career options.

Unlike most international study programs for high school students, cost does not prohibit participation. Every student is funded based on need through organization, foundation and individual contributions. Since 1989, IYLI has extended the benefits of travel to hundreds of students who would not otherwise have had the opportunity. 

What We Need & What You Get

We have done an extensive review of international travel and study programs for high school students and they are expensive!  The average program cost is about $7,500, including airfare for 3-5 weeks.  Very limited scholarship help is available for students who want to participate.  The result:  international travel and study opportunities are largely available only to student from upper middle class or affluent families.  That leaves out most of the students we serve!

We have kept our costs at $4,500 for four weeks and an additional 5-day pre-departure orientation. We have accomplished this through strong partnerships in our host countries and by identifying the most efficient options for transportation and housing. We pay an average of 80% of the costs through fundraising.  Students and their families pay an average of 20% of costs. Who else does that?

Family income does not dictate who can participate.  Some of the most worthy students and students who would benefit most from the international experience come from families whose net income is less than $40,000. The goal of our fundraising is to ensure that all students have opportunities for challenging international study and to counter the disparaging and inequitable message: No money- you need not apply!

IYLI’s summer programs are unique.  Students study a theme-based curriculum focusing on history, culture, geography and environment.  Themes include: Renewable Energy, Cultural Syncretism, Preserving the Environment for Future Generations, and The Role of Government, the Right of Citizens. While the curriculum includes articles about the host country, it also includes a broad representation of cultures, countries and regions. The underlying theme is we are all connected and what happens in one region often affects other regions. 

The summer programs also foster leadership development. What we are looking for is a student who has demonstrated leadership through school or community activities, or a student who has not demonstrated leadership through specific activities but shows special attributes such as caring and empathy and an aversion to injustice. We learn about students through an application process. We also recruit from the cadres of New York City IYLI Fellows, who participate in our leadership and academic programs during the regular school year. 

Students give back when they return from their overseas experience. They make presentations of their experience to sponsoring organizations as well as schools, community groups and others.

The Impact

Our country (and the world) needs good leaders, individuals who are not afraid of or hostile toward people and cultures that are different. In addition, we need leaders who recognize the connection that binds all people together no matter where they live. We are also connected through the environment and conservation and preservation policies must be predicated on an understanding that the planet is integrated and factors that impact one region, have implications for others.

IYLI’s summer programs train leaders. Through their exposure students develop and weigh arguments and viewpoints on important issues in order to inform their own. They learn about their own attitudes and beliefs by being immersed in another country where their norms and values are constantly tested. Through research projects and pairing with others to facilitate seminars, they learn how to plan and work together. They improve their communication skills. As importantly, they learn though their efforts that they are capable of achieving success in many aspects of their life. Experience is one of their best teachers!

When students return from Africa or Latin America, they implement a follow up plan to share their experiences with other.  The plan may include presentations to donors or organizations where they volunteer, school presentations, photo-essay exhibits, newspaper articles, and radio or television appearances, to name several.

Despite beginning our program at various academic levels, 100% of students have graduated from high school and enrolled in college the following fall. Throughout the summer students are asked to examine their attitudes about success, their habits and the strategies that will help them in relationships, schools and careers.

Evaluations of the program, parent feedback and reflections by students themselves all tell us that their experience is life-affirming and life-changing. The majority of participants we have been able to track over time have entered careers in the helping professions, community development, health, youth development, and teaching, in addition to government, law and international business.

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to sponsoring a student, there are other ways you can help. If you have a passion for international issues and travel, you can help us to identify new organizations and NGOs that may offer students opportunities for expanding their knowledge of other counties and cultures, or explore possibilities to become a group leader in one of our overseas programs. 

You can use the Indiegogo share tools to help us get the word out and make connections with programs, schools, religious institutions, corporate sponsors and others to identify and recruit outstanding or emerging young leaders.

Thank you for ALL that you do!!!!!
