story:
Censorship Is Unacceptable

The UNC Student Congress slashed the College Republicans' budget to bring two talented speakers to Chapel Hill: Katie Pavlich and Ann McElhinney.

The Congress said the women were "non-intellectual" with "no value." According to one student representative, "We’re cutting what we believe to be the cost of a speaker that may not actually be beneficial to the university."

It's clear why the rep thinks the speakers won't be "beneficial": The speakers will bring a conservative point of view to the college. 

No matter how the Congress dresses it up, this is blatant censorship of differing opinions. It's undeniable intolerance.

Shouldn't students hear diverse opinions in college?
Is it right to censor speech because you disagree with it?
Is this what they're teaching in universities?

The actions of the UNC Student Congress are reprehensible. They should be ashamed.

Both Katie and Ann are accomplished professionals who want to speak at UNC Chapel Hill. And with your help they still can!

UNC Students Need Your Help

We're raising money to cover the costs so Katie and Ann can bring their voices to a campus desperately in need of opinions that challenge the educational establishment. Katie and Ann will be speak on the same day to celebrate free speech and diversity of opinion. 

Your donation will send a direct message to those who would censor conservative voices: We will not be silenced! 

Spread the Word

You know the mainstream media won't cover this story, so it's up to you to get the word out! Please share the Indiegogo campaign on Facebook and Twitter. And tell your friends and family. 

* * * * *

Katie Pavlich Bio

Katie Pavlich is the news editor for Townhall.com and a contributing editor to Townhall Magazine. She is the award winning author of the New York Times Best Seller Fast and Furious: Barack Obama’s Bloodiest Scandal and Its Shameless Cover-Up. As a reporter, she has covered topics ranging from White House scandals and the 2012 presidential election to the Second Amendment and border issues. As a Fox News contributor, Katie has filled in as a guest co-host on the widely popular show The Five. Katie is a graduate of the University of Arizona with a degree in Journalism and is a former National Review Washington Fellow. Katie has shared her perspective on multiple media venues including, Fox News, CNN, MSNBC, CNBC and Fox Business, in addition to a host of national and local radio shows. She is a regular speaker on college campuses across the country.

Ann McElhinney Bio

Ann McElhinney is a filmmaker and investigative journalist. She has produced documentaries for the BBC, CBC (Canada) and RTE (Ireland). She has written for a series of newspapers including the UK Sunday Times and the Irish Times. Ann has worked as a filmmaker and journalist in many countries including Indonesia, Romania, Vietnam, Cambodia, Uganda, Madagascar, and Uzbekistan. She infiltrated a baby buying ring in Indonesia. As a result, two people are serving lengthy prison sentences for their parts in an illegal adoption. Ann produced and directed three feature-length documentaries with her husband, Phelim McAleer: FrackNation (2012), Not Evil Just Wrong (2009), and Mine Your Own Business (2006). She has appeared on or is a regular contributor to an array of international media organizations including ABC, BBC, CBC (Canada), ABC (Australia), RTE (Ireland), and Fox News. Ann is an accomplished speaker who has given talks on college campuses all over the US.
story_txt:
Censorship Is Unacceptable
The UNC Student Congress slashed the College Republicans' budget to bring two talented speakers to Chapel Hill: Katie Pavlich and Ann McElhinney.
The Congress said the women were "non-intellectual" with "no value." According to one student representative, "We’re cutting what we believe to be the cost of a speaker that may not actually be beneficial to the university."
It's clear why the rep thinks the speakers won't be "beneficial": The speakers will bring a conservative point of view to the college. 
No matter how the Congress dresses it up, this is blatant censorship of differing opinions. It's undeniable intolerance.
Shouldn't students hear diverse opinions in college?Is it right to censor speech because you disagree with it?Is this what they're teaching in universities?
The actions of the UNC Student Congress are reprehensible. They should be ashamed.
Both Katie and Ann are accomplished professionals who want to speak at UNC Chapel Hill. And with your help they still can!


UNC Students Need Your Help
We're raising money to cover the costs so Katie and Ann can bring their voices to a campus desperately in need of opinions that challenge the educational establishment. Katie and Ann will be speak on the same day to celebrate free speech and diversity of opinion. 
Your donation will send a direct message to those who would censor conservative voices: We will not be silenced! 


Spread the Word
You know the mainstream media won't cover this story, so it's up to you to get the word out! Please share the Indiegogo campaign on Facebook and Twitter. And tell your friends and family. 
* * * * *

Katie has shared her perspective on multiple media venues including, Fox News, CNN, MSNBC, CNBC and Fox Business, in addition to a host of national and local radio shows. She is a regular speaker on college campuses across the country.

She infiltrated a baby buying ring in Indonesia. As a result, two people are serving lengthy prison sentences for their parts in an illegal adoption. Ann produced and directed three feature-length documentaries with her husband, Phelim McAleer: FrackNation (2012), Not Evil Just Wrong (2009), and Mine Your Own Business (2006). She has appeared on or is a regular contributor to an array of international media organizations including ABC, BBC, CBC (Canada), ABC (Australia), RTE (Ireland), and Fox News. Ann is an accomplished speaker who has given talks on college campuses all over the US.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Sarah. I'm a senior at a small private college in the Fingerlakes.  I've always had a passion for literature. After being really indecisive, I decided to become an English major (get all of your "you'll be working at Starbucks forever" jokes out). I'd really like to use my English degree to educate students, but not in a classroom setting. I really enjoy museums and how they curate art, literature, and history.

For my senior internship, I have decided to visit six literary museums across New England over a week. During this time, I will be seeing:

  • Two of Robert Frost's homes
  • Mark Twain's house
  • Harriet Beecher Stowe's home
  • Edith Wharton's house
  • Emily Dickinson's museum

This trip will take me to Vermont, New Hampshire, Connecticut, and Massachusetts. At each of these museums, I will be studying how museums curate literature and learn about the different narrative styles presented by each museum. At the end of the trip, I will have completed a blog about the entire experience.

By helping fund my trip, you are not only helping me complete one of my last graduation requirements, you are helping me see a part of the country I've never been to, learn about the lives of authors that I would not normally be able to, and give me the opportunity to further my passion for museum education.

Your generous donation will be used to pay for gasoline and museum ticket cost ONLY. It will not be used for meal cost, lodging, or other personal costs.

 

What I Need & What You Get

If I am able to raise $500, I will be able to pay for gasoline. Over 25 hours of driving go into this trip and gas isn't getting any less expensive unfortunately. In addition, your generous donation will pay for tickets so that I can fully experience each museum. Tickets cost up to $16 each. This is to see every part of the museum, which I would like to do rather than just being able to afford one part. 

Note: My internship advisor will make sure that I use your donations ethically-- don't worry :)

Unfortunately, I can't offer much incentive. However, you will be able to follow me on the blog I will be making about my trip, and I will be happy to thank each individual contributor on the page!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that many of you, like me, are poor college students. So it's okay if you can't contribute. I just appreciate you taking the time to read about my goals. If you know someone that can help though, feel free to spread the word!

story:
Introduction

Bringing man to space and then to the moon is probably one of the greatest accomplishments of humanity. Many years have passed since that time and our technology has advanced greatly, but space is still inaccessible for most people. Sending humans to space is very expensive and unmanned spacecraft, though cheaper, are still too costly for average citizens. The best way to learn about something is to go there, but if you can't go then the next best option is to send something there for you. We want to go to space, but without our own rocket and satellite our best option is to send a helium balloon with a camera and science instruments to the edge of space for us. We are hoping to record some amazing images and interesting scientific data from the upper layers of the atmosphere.

//        //         //

Mandare un essere umano nello spazio e poi sulla luna è uno dei più grandi traguardi mai raggiunti dall'umanità. Molti, anzi troppi anni sono passati da quell'evento grandioso e nonostante la tecnologia si sia evoluta notevolmente lo spazio continua a rimanere un posto inaccessibile per la maggior parte degli uomini. Infatti le spedizioni spaziali sono molto costose e anche le più economiche sonde e satelliti sono troppo costosi per un cittadino medio. Il miglior modo per imparare qualcosa è di combinare tra loro teoria e pratica e quando si parla dello spazio è molto difficile mettere in atto questa strategia ma è qui che inizia la nostra sfida.

Vogliamo andare nello spazio ma non possiamo farlo con un razzo con un satellite, quindi un pallone sonda con una telecamera e una buona strumentazione scientifica è la migliore opzione che abbiamo. Speriamo di registrare il prima possibile delle fantastiche immagini prese direttamente dallo spazio e dati scientifici dagli strati più alti dell'atmosfera.


How to Get to Space

  1. Put electronics and camera in an insulated box
  2. Attach to a large latex balloon filled with helium
  3. The balloon ascends and expands as air pressure decreases
  4. At around 30km the balloon is 6m in diameter and pops
  5. The box with electronics comes down on a parachute
  6. We use the GPS device to find and recover the payload
  7. Time to watch a movie of space!
      //         //        //

  1.  Mettere i componenti elettronici, i gps e la telecamera in una scatola termicamente isolata a prova di urti
  2. Attaccarla ad un pallone sonda riempito con l'elio
  3. Dal momento che l'elio e' piu leggero dell'aria decollerà e mano a meno che salirà la pressione atmosferica diminuirà. Questo farà in modo che il pallone si gonfi e scoppi ad una certa altezza
  4. A Quest' altezza [ stimata intorno ai 30 km il pallone avrà un diametro di 6 m e scoppierà
  5. La scatola contenente la telecamera e gli strumenti ritornerà in modo sicuro sulla terra grazie ad un paracadute a cui e attaccata 
  6. Tramite 3 dispositivi GPS saremo in grado di recuperare entro poche ore il pallone
  7. Godiamoci il nostro video spaziale!

Equipment for our Space Machine

With just €600 we can accomplish a single simple mission. With our €1500 goal we will be able to establish a small space balloon program with repeated launches. The difference is being able to buy more equipment and creating a more durable platform for future missions. The estimated costs for developing our space program:

  • Camera (€300)
  • Helium  (sponsored by SIAD in Muggia near Trieste)
  • Balloon (€100-250)
  • Parachute (€100)
  • Electronics and Radio (€300)
  • Construction Materials (€100)
  • GPS Tracker (€300)

//        //          //

Come potete facilmente intuire dal sito, questo progetto è troppo costoso per essere finanziato dalla scuola quindi abbiamo deciso di organizzare una campagna raccolta fondi. Con soli 600 $ saremmo gi' in grado di realizzare una missione come questa ma in scala ridotta mentre se raggiungessimo il nostro obiettivo *1500 $ saremmo in grado di ripetere il lancio piu volte con lo stesso pallone e di ordinare ovviamente componenti migliori

Ricapitolando ci servono:

300 $ per una telecamera in HD di buona qualità' che possa registrare per pi\ di 2 ore consecutive

Bombole di elio *già finanziati dalla SIAD con sede a Muggia in Trieste

100/250  $ per Il Pallone, piu soldi significa una migliore qualità' e stabilita della scatola e quindi niente tremolii nel video

100 $ per il paracadute, che e fondamentale per recuperare il tutto

300 $ per i componenti elettronici e la radio

100 $ per i materiali di costruzione *corde per tenere il tutto unito, protezioni contro gli urti ecc...

300 $ per i tracciatori GPS


About us

We are a group of students at the International School of Trieste (IST, and hence 'BalloonISTs') in Italy that have chosen to create a space balloon as part of our space architecture class, lead by our science teacher Mr. Bryan Costanza. He has a background in Aerospace Engineering and worked for a time at NASA so he knows quite a lot about spacecraft and weather balloons. 

//       //       //

Siamo un gruppo di studenti della scuola superiore internazionale di Trieste e da qui il nome BalloonISTs che abbiamo scelto di costruire un pallone sonda 

Purpose

The primary goals of this project are to get some cool videos from space and record basic scientific data from space, such as temperature and pressure, across various layers of the atmosphere. Along the way we also hope to be the first balloon launch from the grand Piazza Unità in Trieste.

Mission Objectives

To complete this project we will need to work on skills such as collaboration, manufacturing, and creating written documentation of the experiment so that we can contribute to the science of space balloons. Universities or other amateur groups of adults usually accomplish projects like this so this is quite an opportunity. With the work we have already accomplished and the great opportunity that this is we cannot let a lack of funding stop our project.

Contact Us

For further information please see our blog http://somuchscience.com/balloonists/ or contact Mr. Costanza directly at costanza.bryan@istrieste.org.

Mission Description

On May 4th we will launch a helium-filled balloon that will reach about 30km in altitude (100,000 feet, about three times that of a commercial airliner). A payload is attached to the balloon with a series of strings and inside this box we will put a camera, a temperature probe, a barometer and other equipment used to record scientific data. Three different locator methods will be used to ensure that we get good data and ensure that we find the payload once it has landed. When the balloon will pop at the altitude of 30km a parachute will automatically open. This will make the balloon recovery safe for those of us stuck on earth as well as for the contents of the balloon.

Why you should help us with this project?


This project will contribute to the scientific and engineering knowledge of a group of 13 students while also helping contribute to the science of exploring space with high altitude balloons. This is a very uncommon thing to do in a high school and it is a huge opportunity so we don't want to lose it because we don't have funds. We will donate the images, documentation, and any other useful information fro the project to the science community through our blog.

Technical Partnership

HackerSpace Gorizia (HaSGO) has been critical in enabling this project to go forward, especially to work on the electronics. HaSGO will create the scientific recording electronics and radio that will serve as the “brain” of the space balloon. In this pursuit the group has created a space balloon electronics wiki and all information gained from their efforts will be made available to the public.

story:
Our Campaign

Working with leaders in the reproductive rights movement, the California Center for Research on Women and Families (CCRWF) is producing a short video - less than 15 minutes - documenting the history of reproductive health services in California.  The first release of the film will be at the California Women’s Policy Summit, scheduled for January 16 at the Sacramento Convention Center (go to www.ccrwf.org for more information).

2014 is the 45th anniversary of legal abortion in California – the perfect time to evaluate how far the movement has come and what challenges remain in ensuring access to safe and effective contraception and abortion services. 

The purpose of the video is to showcase the success we've had here in California in securing rights and establishing programs, and to honor the leadership that has brought about our relatively positive situation in California (compared to many other states).

Given the many challenges to reproductive health services across the country, the video will also serve another purpose – showcasing the new and young leadership that will "carry the torch" forward, and highlighting some of the ongoing challenges and struggles to achieve reproductive freedom.

This short film will combine archival footage, first person narratives and candid discussions with some of the leaders in the field in California.  From a time when women undergoing abortions could face jail time to more recent attacks on access to contraception coverage and new evidence of forced sterilization of prisoners, activists from diverse communities in the movement will provide their insights into the powerful history of reproductive rights in California.

In addition to documenting this history for the first time, this film will be used to brief boards of directors and educate students and other stakeholders.

Joining this effort are Planned Parenthood Affiliates of California, NARAL Pro-Choice California, the California Coalition for Reproductive Freedom, California Latinas for Reproductive Justice, and Black Women for Wellness.

What we need

We need your help to make this film a reality!  Your tax-deductible donation will be used to produce and edit the video, allowing us to create a high quality film that will educate and inspire young leaders.

Please note: 

* CCRWF is a program of the Public Health Institute, a 501(c)3 nonprofit, so your donations are tax deductible.

* If you would prefer to donate anonymously, simply decline any relevant “perks” on the donate page.  Thank you for your support!

story:
CAMPAIGN UPDATE

I've been in Ghana for more than 3 weeks now and I have not been idle. Here's what I've accomplished so far:

  • I've met with someone from the Osu Children's Library Fund, and discovered a series of beginner picture books written for and/or by Ghanaians. I have also visited one of their libraries in Accra and witnessed their adult literacy program, and I have a standing invitation to return for more advice and inspiration.
  • I attended a workshop sponsored by the Ghana Book Trust, where I met many Ghanaian writers and publishers. I also learned of the Burt Award and how it has helped to create a collection of young adult novels written by and for Ghanaians.
  • I met the head of the Ghana Book Trust, who may be able to donate some books and who will certainly be able to sell me the above-mentioned young adult books at a very reasonable cost.

So, African content is not going to be a problem at all!

I have also been encouraged by the reactions of the Ghanaian writers, teachers, librarians and social workers to this project. Many of them agree that my idea to foster a culture of reading and writing outside of academia is a good one, and that it addresses some of the key barriers to literacy in this country.

I will soon be working with children from a local drama club, and we have a space to meet in a youth center, while we wait for the Education Center construction to finish. The Education Center's books are now on Ghanaian soil, but tied up in Customs for an indeterminate period. Those books will be available eventually, but now that I know how much Ghanaian material is available, I'd like to proceed without waiting for the shipment to arrive.

What happens next?

  • I need to jump-start the fundraising. Without funds I can't get books and design the program. Even creative writing depends on the kids having books that model effective writing. Instead of merely telling them how to write, I want to show them.
  • Pleas share this link again, and also pass along any ideas you may have about how I can raise more funds. I'm currently considering a read-athon using African literature, and "donation instead of Christmas gift" campaign.

Thanks, everyone!


THE YOUNG WRITERS’ BOOK CLUB

In Canada, people learn to read both at school and informally outside of the education system. Many of us read to our children almost as soon as they're born. But in countries with low literacy rates like Ghana, you rarely see people reading for fun.The Young Writers' Book Club is a plan to support a uniquely African culture of reading and writing in Ghana. These activities are worthwhile for their own sake, but improved English literacy will also help children be more successful in school and in life.

The Plan:

Coaches will guide small groups of children (10 to 15 per group) during twice-weekly sessions including independent work and group activity.

  • They will choose stories from a reading list, containing books at various levels of difficulty. The coach will steer them towards easier or more difficult material as needed. Reading aloud and discussion will form part of the group activity.
  • Kids will write their own compositions, with the coach providing ideas and prompts.
  • The coach will edit these compositions for grammar and spelling, and give the kids as many chances as they want to rewrite.
  • Kids will get a chance to read their work aloud, act out plays they've written, and publish their stories in a group magazine at regular intervals.

Why is this needed?

Here are some of the obstacles to reading and writing that I saw firsthand when I was teaching English composition at a Ghanaian high school:

  • Schooling is mostly in English, which is not their first language
  • Class sizes are much too big for students to get enough individual help
  • School libraries are inadequate, often consisting of a single bookcase full of the kind of books you couldn't even give away at your last garage sale.
  • African content is hard to find.
  • Most people don't read for fun, and they don't read stories to small children.

In spite of all this bad news, many Ghanaians have done extremely well. Ghana has produced plenty of successful newspapers, notable authors, and a vibrant home-grown TV and film industry. But many people are still excluded from the world of writing.

The Good News

We are very fortunate to be partnering with Light For Children Ghana, an NGO that helps children in need in Kumasi, Ghana. With Light For Children, Rebecca Kuntz is building an Education Center for the kids of Atonsu (Kumasi), that will include a library and computer lab. This center is nearing completion and is scheduled to open early in 2014 -- the books have already been shipped for the library.

So we will have:

  • access to books
  • a place to meet with children
  • a computer lab
  • children who are eager to participate

Once the program is established, it can be run by international volunteers provided by Light For Children, so the ongoing costs will be minimal.

What We Still Need

Our goal is to raise $15,000 to cover these expenses:

  • Travel to Ghana
  • My living expenses for a one-year pilot period
  • Paper, writing supplies, printing costs, dictionaries
  • Fees for Ghanaian writers and educators who help me create the reading list and advise on African content

Check out some of the great incentives we're offering in return for donations. In the coming weeks we'll be featuring some of the artisans and co-ops who are providing these perks. By donating, you'll be helping them too!

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone has money to spare, but anyone can contribute. Here's how:

  • Spread the word. Use the tools on this site to share on Facebook, Twitter, etc.
  • If you have any questions about this campaign, please ask. Answering your questions will help us clarify our message for everyone.
  • If you have any personal stories about becoming a writer, especially in a time or place where literacy was not taken for granted, please share.

Thank you! And watch this site for updates in the coming weeks.
story_txt:
CAMPAIGN UPDATE
I've been in Ghana for more than 3 weeks now and I have not been idle. Here's what I've accomplished so far:
I've met with someone from the Osu Children's Library Fund, and discovered a series of beginner picture books written for and/or by Ghanaians. I have also visited one of their libraries in Accra and witnessed their adult literacy program, and I have a standing invitation to return for more advice and inspiration.
I attended a workshop sponsored by the Ghana Book Trust, where I met many Ghanaian writers and publishers. I also learned of the Burt Award and how it has helped to create a collection of young adult novels written by and for Ghanaians.
I met the head of the Ghana Book Trust, who may be able to donate some books and who will certainly be able to sell me the above-mentioned young adult books at a very reasonable cost.
So, African content is not going to be a problem at all!I have also been encouraged by the reactions of the Ghanaian writers, teachers, librarians and social workers to this project. Many of them agree that my idea to foster a culture of reading and writing outside of academia is a good one, and that it addresses some of the key barriers to literacy in this country. I will soon be working with children from a local drama club, and we have a space to meet in a youth center, while we wait for the Education Center construction to finish. The Education Center's books are now on Ghanaian soil, but tied up in Customs for an indeterminate period. Those books will be available eventually, but now that I know how much Ghanaian material is available, I'd like to proceed without waiting for the shipment to arrive.What happens next?
I need to jump-start the fundraising. Without funds I can't get books and design the program. Even creative writing depends on the kids having books that model effective writing. Instead of merely telling them how to write, I want to show them.
Pleas share this link again, and also pass along any ideas you may have about how I can raise more funds. I'm currently considering a read-athon using African literature, and "donation instead of Christmas gift" campaign.
Thanks, everyone!

access to books

a computer lab
children who are eager to participate

Travel to Ghana
My living expenses for a one-year pilot period
Paper, writing supplies, printing costs, dictionaries
Fees for Ghanaian writers and educators who help me create the reading list and advise on African content

Check out some of the great incentives we're offering in return for donations. In the coming weeks we'll be featuring some of the artisans and co-ops who are providing these perks. By donating, you'll be helping them too!
Other Ways You Can Help
Not everyone has money to spare, but anyone can contribute. Here's how:

Spread the word. Use the tools on this site to share on Facebook, Twitter, etc.

story:
Short Summary

Hello friends,

My name is Cathrine Yuill.  I live in Maitland, Nova Scotia: a small historical village known best historically for ship building and now as a spectacular location for viewing the world's highest tides and the tidal bore. 

For the last three years I have been working with a committee of friends, neighbors and colleagues to save our village school.  The demise of the small rural school is not a new issue.  Small schools are being closed all across North America and children as young as 5 are growing up on busses, being shipped great distances to consolidated schools far from their communities.

In facing our School Board's vote for closure of our school, we proposed an alternative: using the surplus space of our school for the creation of a Community Hub.  This Community Hub will aim to bring together small business and community services and supports to create both resource and opportunity.  The aim is to generate revenue to off set the amount of money the School Board would have saved by closing our school:  $130,000 per year.  This number may sound daunting but our committee has some excellent ideas which we think will go beyond saving our school and will even stimulate new economic activity in our community. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for your financial support to help us make this innovative solution a reality and possibly even an demonstration project for small rural communities all across North America. If we can do it, anyone can.  Contributions will fund our start up costs which include:
  • a feasibility study $3000
  • business plan development $4000
  • advertising for expressions of interest $4000
  • regional consultation meeting to bring together all the local area service clubs and services to develop integration. $1000

If we do not reach our goal we will scale back by doing a smaller feasibility study, by using reduced consultative services on business plan development, and attempting to do our regional consultation meeting at no cost.

Donations of all sizes will be welcome.  Even $10 can help us to reach one more potential small business or innovator looking for space.

    The Impact

     

    The impact of this project will be significant:

    • keeping children in our community for elementary education, where we can all lend our skills, abilities, care and concern as they strive to excell.
    • stimulating economic activity in our region by brining in new businesses
    • bringing together a wide variety of community services in one central location
    • providing a demonstration for other communities facing the same plight


    Risks & Challenges

     We face a number of risks:

    • low/declining student population
    • small resident population base
    • limitations of a volunteer time and energy during the development phase
    • decision-making power lies with external body - the local School Board

    We feel that we are able to mitigate these risks.  We have everything we need as a community to stimulate population and economic growth.  This initiative will be one driving force among others currently at play including: provincial and small business investment in tourism, recent small business revitalization, in-migration of mid career families interested in lifestyle; strong and diverse skill base among community members, passionate interest in this cause from a large portion of the population.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

    • Please help us get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
    • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
    • Visit us on Facebook under "Save Maitland Elementary School"
    • Call to volunteer 902-261-2001

    And that's all there is to it.

story:
Project to the Edge of Space

UPRA Team is formed by students of the Budapest University of Technology and Economics. The Team designed and right now is building its own near space instrumentation. 

Earlier this year, in April we have already had a test-flight with the prototype of the telemetry system. Since then the Team developed a new revision of the flight computer and the capsule.

The goals of our next misson:

  • Take low resolution pictures and stream them back during flight
  • Take high resolution pictures
  • Measure temperature and pressure
  • Measure solar panel characteristics
  • Determine the trajectory of the probe

The new flight computer is in production right now, the probe got its new insulation. Our vision is moving to the launch right now. The launch date is 13-September-2014. Our financial resources are depleted, so we need YOUR help to be able to keep on schedule with the launching.


How can YOU help us?

We build the instrumentation, but it has to be delivered to its destination, to the stratosphere. The easiest way to get there is a Hydrogen or Helium filled balloon. 

Every balloon launch has a cost built up from two major parts. The first part of the launch cost is one time investment. These are the launch site accessories like a small mobile shelter, balloon filling equipment and transportation containers for the accessories. These are durable equipment and can be used through many launches. It would be our second official launch and we only have the very basic equipment right now. With YOUR help, we could upgrade our accessories with a small wind shelter and a proper transportation box.

The other part of the launch cost is cover the consumables of the project like the filling gas and tank rental, lanyard of the payload, cost of the chase (petrol costs), mobile internet and phone costs and of course the weather balloon itself. These costs are applied for every launch and it is more or less constant. After we own the proper launch site equipment, the cost of a balloon launch will contain only the cost of these consumables.

This campaign is aimed at the acquisition of the cost of the balloon launch. The main goal is to purchase the two main "launch consumables", the weather balloon and the filling gas.

We are planned to use Helium. Of course Hydrogen would be cheaper, but we would need permissions to use, transport and buy it here in Hungary. Getting these permissions is long and sometimes expensive, so we choose Helium instead which is easier to get.

The weather balloon we planned to use is a 1000gr. or a 1200gr PAWAN latex balloon. This type has proven itself in our first test-flight and in the other balloon launches we contributed.

These items take the most of the cost. The rest of the founds will go to the launch equipment upgrade. We would like to purchase a proper container for the launch site equipment and the payload to be transported safely. The ideal transportation container has wheels and a divided interior where every accessory find its own place.

The other item we would like to purchase is a small mobile shelter that can be set up at the launch site and provides protection against wind and light rain. The ideal shelter has at least two "walls" and its entrance is big enough for an inflated 1200gr weather balloon to get out.


What YOU get for YOUR help?

Our Team is grateful for any help. If YOU found us here in IndieGogo YOU could choose from these perks:

Honorary Supporter 

Even the smallest matters. Honorary Supporters will appear on our webpage and in other media appearance among project supporters.

Mission Supporter

YOUR founding will help us to finish our next mission. As a Mission Supporter YOUR name will appear on our webpage and in other media appearance among project supporters. YOU will also receive a mission patch similar to the one the Team members wear during the launch and the recovery.

Launch Supporter

YOU are a balloon fanatic. With YOUR help we could provide regular high altitude balloon launches in the future for more and more scientific experiments and measurements. Launch Supporters will appear on our webpage and in other media appearance among project supporters. YOU will not only receive a mission patch, but your name will be printed on a small plate fastened to the high altitude capsule. After the recovery YOU will receive the plate with your name on it that reached the stratosphere. 


Mission Patch


Risks & Challenges

During a near-space flight there is a chance to something goes wrong. We are planning and testing every bit of the mission, but still there is some risks.

At our first test-flight we lost the radio signals of the probe, but fortunately thanks to the contact information on the capsule we got back our instrument. To lower the risks of events like this we will use redundant and independent GPS and telecommunication system.

The main challenge of our next flight is the Sensor Network which didn't fly before. It controls several measurements like

  • outside tepmerature
  • solar rays
  • pressure
  • magnetic field
  • capsule orientation

The On-Board Computer(OBC) and the Communication Unit(COM) will be upgraded versions of the ones that was used on our test-flight in April. We are working on to send back better quality live pictures during flight then before. These will be small resolution pictures, and they can be seen live on our webpage during the flight. Other challenge is to operate a high resolution camera which store the pictures on board. This camera is also could record low resolution video clips.

Testing and verifying the instrumentation is also part of the project. This will happen in our own and in third party laboratories like the labs of the Budapest University of Technology and Economics.

The launch itself is a low risk operation. We had experiences through our first own test-flight and other balloon flights we contributed in.

The flight will be tracked via several ground stations and by the chase team. We had experienced radio operators and chase team. In the following the Hungarian Amateur Radio community will also help us.


YOUR help could bring us above the sky!

Help us reach our goal by founding our project. This is one of the first steps to regular near space flights and more space related projects for our Team.

Please check our webpage for more information about the project, and share this campaign with your friends...with the world!


Godspeed!

story:
Short Summary

We want to be able to get as many signs to people as possible. After many requests, we decided this would be the most efficient way to orchestrate the project. We need $728 to purchase 100 signs. 

What We Need & What You Get 

(Click "Select Perk" below pink contribute now button on the right side of the screen)

If you donate $8 we can guarantee you a yard sign in the next delivery. You have to click "Claim Perk" or "Select Perk" and give us your mailing address (so we know where to drop it off!)
Using this funding model, we have to reach our goal of $728 or we do not get any of the funds. If you feel so inclined you can definitely donate any amount of money, but for your $8 contribution, we can guarantee you will get your sign as soon as they come in. If you want more than one sign, email keating.b@gmail.com and we can try to work something out.

The Impact

We all know how important it is to show solidarity as a community. We also know that the way to win this battle is through outreach and education. What better way to accomplish both than to let everybody who drives through Chatham know where we stand?

Other Ways You Can Help

We will also need volunteers for canvassing and outreach to other communities. Please reach out to Brendan L. Keating for more information. (keating.b@gmail.com)

story:
http://www.thebullyprojectmural.com/index.html

About Our Indiegogo Campaign:  

We are raising money to fund outreach to thousands of schools across the USA, to enlist them to participate, classroom-by-classroom, or school-wide in our 'Bully Project Mural'. 

The 'Bully Project Mural’ is a digital destination where people of all ages can share their art, stories, and perspectives about bullying, its impact on our lives, and ideas for how we can #endbullying together.  Check it out now at: www.thebullyprojectmural.com. We built it together with Adobe and it allows anyone to express their memories or experiences of bullying, and by doing so transform them into a powerful and creative wall of empathy and action!

Our vision is that school participation in the Mural begins with a screening of the film BULLY, followed by classroom discussion using our curriculum or other resources, and concludes with the students developing their own contributions to the Mural. This model will help ensure that the work we do has maximum impact in helping to change school culture, which will be undertaken in a thoughtful and meaningful way. 

By donating to this campaign, you will be giving educators an opportunity to address the problem of bullying in a new way, and helping youth experience first-hand that they are not alone in being bullied or wanting it to end. Together, we can turn the tides on bullying. We like to think of the Mural as a modern version of the AIDS Quilt, a platform for creativity that can change hearts and minds globally.

About Our Project:  

The BULLY Project is a global movement inspired by the award-winning film BULLY. Our goal is to change a culture of bullying into one of empathy and action, to transform kids' lives by creating a safe place for all, and create a tipping point where bullying is no longer tolerated.  We've grown to more then 800,000 Facebook followers, and the Bully Project has helped more then 3 million kids and educators jumpstart change in their schools and communities. 



How Funds Will Be Used:

Contributions to our campaign will be used to fund all aspects of the Mural campaign. Here's how this breaks down: 

Developing Materials:  We will be developing outreach materials and teaching guides that will inspire schools participating in the BULLY Project Mural. Developing a curriculum is tough work and requires bringing in experts and advisors!

Delivery Platform Development: We will develop an online delivery platform where educator's/youth leaders will go to receive instructions about how their students can contribute to The BULLY Project Mural and participate in our campaign. 

Outreach & School Engagement: Our staff will reach out directly to schools, starting with those who've participated in the Bully Project work already, and far beyond, to enlist adult and youth leaders to champion participation in the Mural. 

Provide Technical & Resource Support to Participating Schools:  We want to help ensure that every school-based project staff or youth leader has maximum support to lead this project in their school and have it be successful. This includes: 

- Our staff will be available to them by phone or email (in person if they are nearby our NYC office). 

- In addition, we've developed an "Educators Toolkit" for use in schools that includes the film and wrap-around curriculum focused on social and emotional learning. As part of our ongoing work, we make this Toolkit available to schools at a highly subsidized rate. 

- Last but not least, our staff will be available after the contributions have been made to promote the work on social media platforms, and help ensure that the students work is proudly displayed and celebrated online and in their school community. 

We are really excited about the potential and creativity of this project! We hope you share our enthusiasm and chose to support our work! 

It’s time for you to share your story!

Now, please, check out the one-of-a-kind, beautiful perks you can receive from contributing to this campaign!
story_txt:
http://www.thebullyprojectmural.com/index.html
About Our Indiegogo Campaign:  

We are raising money to fund outreach to thousands of schools across the USA, to enlist them to participate, classroom-by-classroom, or school-wide in our 'Bully Project Mural'. 

The 'Bully Project Mural’ is a digital destination where people of all ages can share their art, stories, and perspectives about bullying, its impact on our lives, and ideas for how we can #endbullying together.  Check it out now at: www.thebullyprojectmural.com. We built it together with Adobe and it allows anyone to express their memories or experiences of bullying, and by doing so transform them into a powerful and creative wall of empathy and action!

Our vision is that school participation in the Mural begins with a screening of the film BULLY, followed by classroom discussion using our curriculum or other resources, and concludes with the students developing their own contributions to the Mural. This model will help ensure that the work we do has maximum impact in helping to change school culture, which will be undertaken in a thoughtful and meaningful way. 

By donating to this campaign, you will be giving educators an opportunity to address the problem of bullying in a new way, and helping youth experience first-hand that they are not alone in being bullied or wanting it to end. Together, we can turn the tides on bullying. We like to think of the Mural as a modern version of the AIDS Quilt, a platform for creativity that can change hearts and minds globally.About Our Project:  The BULLY Project is a global movement inspired by the award-winning film BULLY. Our goal is to change a culture of bullying into one of empathy and action, to transform kids' lives by creating a safe place for all, and create a tipping point where bullying is no longer tolerated.  We've grown to more then 800,000 Facebook followers, and the Bully Project has helped more then 3 million kids and educators jumpstart change in their schools and communities. How Funds Will Be Used:Contributions to our campaign will be used to fund all aspects of the Mural campaign. Here's how this breaks down: Developing Materials:  We will be developing outreach materials and teaching guides that will inspire schools participating in the BULLY Project Mural. Developing a curriculum is tough work and requires bringing in experts and advisors!Delivery Platform Development: We will develop an online delivery platform where educator's/youth leaders will go to receive instructions about how their students can contribute to The BULLY Project Mural and participate in our campaign. Outreach & School Engagement: Our staff will reach out directly to schools, starting with those who've participated in the Bully Project work already, and far beyond, to enlist adult and youth leaders to champion participation in the Mural. Provide Technical & Resource Support to Participating Schools:  We want to help ensure that every school-based project staff or youth leader has maximum support to lead this project in their school and have it be successful. This includes: - Our staff will be available to them by phone or email (in person if they are nearby our NYC office). - In addition, we've developed an "Educators Toolkit" for use in schools that includes the film and wrap-around curriculum focused on social and emotional learning. As part of our ongoing work, we make this Toolkit available to schools at a highly subsidized rate. - Last but not least, our staff will be available after the contributions have been made to promote the work on social media platforms, and help ensure that the students work is proudly displayed and celebrated online and in their school community. We are really excited about the potential and creativity of this project! We hope you share our enthusiasm and chose to support our work! It’s time for you to share your story!Now, please, check out the one-of-a-kind, beautiful perks you can receive from contributing to this campaign!

story:
REbeL

 Changing the definition of beauty and health for every body.

Be Thankful

It is a season for caring and sharing. A time to be thankful.  There are so many things for which to be thankful. But this year, we encourage you to start with being thankful for you.  You are a one of a kind, unique and special you. You are not like anyone else. And wow... Is that something to celebrate and be thankful for!  The things that make you special are your gifts to share with the world.

At REbeL, we spend every month of the year celebrating all of the treasures we each possess. Celebrating our brains. Our creativity. Our heart. Our courage. And much more. We take that a step further this time of year and we encourage everyone to BE thankful for their bodies as they are. 

REbeL is thankful for so many things including: brave students who dare to be different, those who help us spread our message, and you {Yes. We mean you} for reading this campaign.  

We are REbeL.

We are REbeL, a student-driven, peer education program designed to address body image issues and disordered eating.

We drive change – in the way people view themselves, in their self-confidence, in their understanding of beauty. We are a group of students making a profound impact. And we invite you to join the REbeLution by giving via Indiegogo.

Here’s how it works.

REbeL focuses on educating, training and empowering youth.  Students are educated on topics including the prevalence of eating and body image issues, the inefficacy of diets, the impact of negative self-talk, and media literacy.  Using a dissonance-based approach, REbeL members lead the way in developing innovative solutions to the body image concerns facing so many individuals. Through this process, they  move toward healthier relationships with food and their bodies and become agents of positive change in their schools and communities.

  • They teach their peers to rebel against the unrealistic standards of beauty society has set.
  • They teach their peers to reject conformity.
  • They teach them to love their bodies.
  • And they become truly invested in the cause.

Here’s why it matters.

We constantly judge. We constantly compare. We constantly damage our view of self-worth and beauty and often times, in turn, damage everyone around us. From reality TV programs to social media, judgment is rampant. The reality is that low self-esteem, skewed body image, and self-hate are overwhelmingly present in the world around us. And these things are contaminating our society. We don’t take time to be thankful for our bodies and who we are. Don’t believe us?

The statistics speak for themselves.

REbeL is determined to educate and empower students and parents so they don’t become one of these statistics. We’re fighting for a better future where individuals are valued for who they are rather than how they look. With chapters in 13 schools, more than 400 students are involved with REbeL. But we need to do more – we have had requests from more than 50 schools in ten states for REbeL. And to make this growth happen, we need YOUR help.

Here’s how you help.

REbeL relies exclusively on volunteers, donations, and two community-wide events: the Walk to REbeL and the Be You Bash. Our volunteers, our donors, and the events are great but, they’re not enough for the exciting growth we are experiencing.  
So here is what we’re asking of you. We’ve set our fundraising goal at $10,000, funds that will play an important role in developing our programming over the course of the next year and expanding the reach of REbeL to other middle schools and high schools across the nation. In fact, we are  putting the finishing touches on an innovative online portal that will revolutionize the way we can deliver our programming to our chapters. Your donation will allow us to greatly expand our reach into more schools and will also allow us to begin to open chapters in underserved populations.

With your support, we can continue to grow. We can continue to effect change. And we can continue to redefine beauty in a meaningful way.

Please consider making a donation of any size right now! Any size donation, and every dollar you donate will make a difference – $5, $10, $25 or even $100. Make a 100% tax-deductible donation today.  

Want to know more?

  • Visit our website at www.re-bel.org to learn about opportunities for further involvement.
  • Read our BE-log at re-bel.org/blog
  • Share this page with your friends, family and co-workers.
  • And participate in #WhiteBoardWednesday.
  • Like us on Facebook: facebook.com/rebelpeereducationprogram
  • Follow us on Twitter: @RebelBeYoutiful
  • Find us on Instagram: RebelPeerEducation
  • Be a corporate sponsor: Contact Christi Campos at christic@re-bel.org

So, as you head into the holiday season,
remember to:

Be Thankful

BeYOUtiful

Be You!

Share this page with your friends, family and co-workers.

story:
Summary

Hey folks, I'm Adam Restad, Senior Class President of our class of 2005. Myself and a handful of classmates (such fine folks as Jack Grauman, Zach Hunter, and Kat Fischer) are working to put together a great 10 year class reunion. We're shooting for the first or second weekend in August. 

Whether you reveled in your time at Senior or shared in the drudgery of high school distress, we all went through it and now the succeeding 10 years. Let's get together and drink about it.

What We Need 

  • The reunion committee is looking to raise $900. That should supply the class of 2005 with ample funding to reserve and outfit a bbq in Pioneer Park for a family picnic and then rent out a small space that evening at a local brewery for an classmate +1 reunion with drinks and appetizers.
  • Funds will also be used to mail reunion notification postcards to as many classmates as we can find.
  • Any leftover money will either go to help fund our 20 year reunion.

The Impact

  • Your contribution could mean the difference between running a successful organizing campaign to reach ALL of our classmates and put on memorable picnic and get-together or not.
  • Not able to make the reunion? Contributing makes a great way to help support your class. Plus, our various donor levels will let your classmates know where you are and what you're up to.
  • Please, share this fundraising effort with your other friends or family. Whose parents wouldn't want to toss $20 to the memory of their son or daughter graduating high school?

And that's all there is to it. Thanks for your support and see you in August.

story:
Initial goal: $1,500 (one pallet of solar lights...amount required for first shipment)

Secondary goal: $3,000 (two pallets of solar lights)

Ultimate goal: $10,000 (644 lights - one for each student at the school!) 

You could change a child's future...by giving the gift of light!

The people of the village of Pommern hold a special place in my heart. As part of my "Service Gap Year," I spent 6 weeks living, teaching, and volunteering in the community of Pommern, Tanzania. The people of this village are the poorest of the poor and access to electricity is limited to those who may be able to run a generator for a few hours a day. Pomerini Secondary School reserves generator time for 7-10 pm so the students can study; but if a student needs to study later, or can't focus in the tiny classrooms packed with 50+ students, they have to rely on solar lights, which most cannot afford.  Those students are found many nights, sitting outside, attempting to study by the light of the moon.  With just a simple solar light, these student’s futures would be so much brighter! 

My goal is to raise enough money to send a solar light to each and every one of the 644 students at Pomerini Secondary School. Each light costs $15 (includes shipping), and will change the life of the student who receives it.  In order to send an initial shipment of lights to Pommern, I must purchase a pallet at a time (96 lights), so my initial goal is $1,500.  My ultimate goal remains to raise enough to provide every single student with their own solar light.  Regardless of how much is raised, every dollar collected will go directly to the purchase of solar lights for these highly motivated, dedicated, and deserving students.  If you can contribute, I’d greatly appreciate it.  Not only will your gift change the life of a child, but it will impact the community as a whole, showing all of those in Pommern that there is someone, somewhere, who cares about their future. 

Although the national language of Tanzania is Kiswahili and most of the students also speak their native tribal language, these students take all of their classes in English -- as if high school wasn't challenging enough! They're the most dedicated and hard-working group of teenagers and young adults that I've ever met; they have such a drive to learn and a desire to make a difference.  They all have goals they want to achieve: Patrick wants to be a surgeon, Joseph dreams of being a preacher and a pilot, Sarafina aspires to be the doctor in her home village, Rama hopes to be a lawyer, and Toni hopes to come back and teach students at Pomerini Secondary School.  

Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions…I’d love to talk about my experiences and share more information about the community and my project! Even if you are not able to donate, I'd greatly appreciate if you could spread the word with a short Facebook post or a tweet with this link: http://igg.me/at/lightsforlearning 

Rama (one of the students at Pomerini Secondary School) sent me this message upon hearing about the project: 

"I saw your post which you posted about the life of the students of pommerini secondary school and community as whole! I really appreciate you for what you want to do for pommerini students! This shows that you care and you love us, may God bless you for that." 

That message is for each and every person who contributes to this project - YOU are changing the life of a student, YOU are showing that you care, and YOU are telling them that YOU believe that they can reach their dreams!

story:
This March, as part of the University of Virginia School of Law's Alternative Spring Break program, four of us are traveling to Arizona to volunteer with No Mas Muertes: No More Deaths.

The Tucson-based organization No More Deaths aims to stop humanitarian suffering along the U.S.-Mexico border in part by leaving supplies and by providing medical aid to immigrants. According to its website, No More Deaths began in 2004 in the form of a coalition of community and faith groups, dedicated to stepping up efforts to stop the deaths of migrants in the desert and to achieving the enactment of a set of Faith-Based Principles for Immigration Reform.

Abuse documentation

In 2006, while working to provide humanitarian aid to people recently deported to Nogales, Sonora, No More Deaths volunteers began to document stories of abuse, neglect and mistreatment endured by detainees in short-term Border Patrol custody. Since then, trained volunteers in the border cities of Nogales, Agua Prieta and Naco have continued to interview deportees, identifying those who have suffered abuse at the hands of Border Patrol and other law enforcement officials and documenting their stories.

Post-deportation aid

Since 2006, No More Deaths has provided humanitarian aid to individuals deported from the U.S. to cities along the Arizona–Sonora border. No More Deaths does not own or run a migrant aid station in Mexico, but instead works with multiple humanitarian, faith-based, and governmental organizations in northern Sonora that run such facilities, complementing local resources with our own.

Property recovery

This project, another outgrowth of the Nogales project, dates to 2008—the year Operation Streamline was rolled out in Tucson Sector. The project addresses an important humanitarian impact of the Department of Homeland Security’s mass-prosecution and mass-deportation initiatives: mass dispossession. We are helping incarcerated individuals recover their personal belongings from the agency that arrested them, normally Border Patrol/Customs and Border Protection.

We are so appreciative of your support! Know that your contribution is one that will be used to save the lives of others.

If you're interested, check out these links:

No More Deaths:

http://www.nomoredeaths.org/

HBO Documentary about Jon McCain and Ted Kennedy's push for immigration reform:

http://www.hbo.com/documentaries/the-senators-b...

HBO Documentary about migrant children:

http://www.hbo.com/documentaries/the-senators-b...

story:
Hello Everyone,

I was lucky enough to have been chosen to go away on a school trip to Limpopo, South Africa for a Children’s Study course. As a group of 14 students our goal is to raise $ 8,000 for the schools in Limpopo. My individual goal is to raise $500 in 60 days. I would really appreciate any donation!! If you can’t donate please share this, maybe there are other people in your circle that can :) Thank you! Sending lots of LOVE!

Sophia

__________________________________________________________________________

Hola a todos!!!

Les quiero comentar que he tenido la suerte de haber sido seleccionada para participar en un viaje a Sudáfrica, Limpopo. Somos 14 estudiantes de la universidad de York en Toronto y nos hemos propuesto recaudar $8000 para poder ayudar a escuelas de Limpopo. Mi meta personal es recaudar $500 en 60 días; hare todo lo posible para concretarla.

Cualquier monto en cuanto a donación es más que bienvenido; y si en estos momentos no pueden donar, por favor comparta este mensaje en su muro.

Muchísimas gracias 

Sophia

story: I never realized how much teachers give of their own time and money to furnish a classroom with all of the resources necessary to create an effective and comfortable environment. If you choose to donate to my very first classroom the funds will be used to buy classroom supplies, organization tools, student library books, resource materials, craft supplies, and anchor displays. Your support will help me build the resources I need to help students grow for years to come. Thank you!!!!

story:
We are SPARK VENTURES

We can do more together than we can alone.

UPDATE: A generous investor has agreed to contribute $1,000 if we can reach 200 contributors to the campaign. Contributions of ANY AMOUNT count towards our headcount, so just $2 could mean $1002 for our work!!

Thousands of children are living in poverty in Nicaragua, the second poorest country in the Western Hemisphere.  We are here to change that, but we need you.

Spark Ventures is a Chicago-based non-profit that partners with international grassroots organizations to help children in poverty with education, nutrition, and healthcare.  Unlike most organizations, however, we don't believe in just writing a check.  

We call it business driven philanthropy.  
  • We invest time and resources into a new business opportunity.
  • The business creates local jobs & sustainable products.
  • The profits help support high impact programs to lift children out of poverty.

                    



Our next exciting business investment?

A Honeybee Farm

We need:

  1. Honeybee farm location
  2. Good soil
  3. Apiary Management training
  4. Beekeeping techniques
  5. Local partnerships 
  6. You

We've checked off almost everything on our to-do list, but there are a few things we still need...

That's where you come in.

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

Grand Total: $15,000


HOW YOU CAN CONTRIBUTE

Besides knowing you're making a HUGE difference, we've got some sweet stuff for you, too!

$5: #youarethebeesknees

Contribute $5 today and...
  • We'll give you a shout out on social media showing our appreciation!

$15: Honey smacks

Contribute $15 today and...

                                

  • Receive a lip balm infused with sun bleached beeswax - perfect for the dry winter months. (courtesy of our friends at Sweet Beginnings LLC)

$25: Bee Thankful!

Contribute $25 today and...

                                

  • Get a pack of 5 hand-drawn cards from the children in Nicaragua.  They're the perfect way to say thanks this holiday season.

$50: Oh, honey, honey

Contribute $50 today and...

                                 

  • Receive the sun bleached beeswax lip balm (see above)
  • Plus, enjoy this sweet 3 oz jar of honey!
Since our farm hasn't started producing honey yet, we thought you could taste some of our local honey - made right here in Chicago! (courtesy of our friends at Sweet Beginnings LLC)

$60: Happy Honeydays!

Contribute $60 today and...

               

  • Receive a 3 oz jar of honey (Sweet Beginnings LLC)
  • PLUS a wooden bowl handmade in Zambia
  • Only 9 available, get yours now in time for the holidays!

$75: Good Tidings We Bring

Contribute $75 today and...

              

  • Get a 3 oz jar of honey (Sweet Beginnings LLC)
  • Enjoy a unique set of placemats and napkins handmade in Nicaragua (includes 6 of each - colors vary)
  • Only 5 available - perfect for setting your holiday table.

$100: Honeybee Care Package

Contribute $100 today and...

                  

                                            

  • Receive a care package with all your Spark & honey needs. 
  • Includes: Spark Ventures t-shirt
  • Sun bleached beeswax lip balm
  • 3 oz jar of honey (Sweet Beginnings LLC)

$200: Bee Happy

Contribute $200 today and...

                             

  • Smile for your 20 minute headshot session with longtime photographer Lucy Jodlowska!
  • Receive 7-10 images - perfect for young professionals.
  • Check it out! http://www.lucynajodlowska.com/of-you/
                                          (Available in the Chicago area)

$250: Beeautiful

Contribute $250 today and...

                      

  • We'll send you one of these beautiful matted photos of Nicaragua.
  • Dimensions: 12" x 16"

$500: Don't Stop Beelievin'

Contribute $500 today and... 

                 

  • Who's your favorite musician?  Sting?  Bee-52s? Well, check out Sixteen Candles, Chicago's finest 80's cover band.  
  • Get 4 tickets to a Sixteen Candles concert.
  • Enjoy pre-show drinks with Spark cofounder & Sixteen Candles keyboardist Scott Barbeau.
                (excluding New Years Eve show & House of Blues performances)


$500: Picture Perfect

Contribute $500 today and...

              

  • Get this 11"x14" hardcover coffee table photo book.
  • Features professional images from Zambia and Nicaragua.
  • Receive it just in time for the holiday season!

$750: Bee Our Guest

Contribute $750 today and...

                                           

  • Join Spark's CEO & cofounder Rich Johnson for dinner at an exceptional restaurant in Chicago.  
  • Get the inside scoop on business driven philanthropy. 
  • Plus, a sneak peek at what's next for Spark.
(Also available in Washington D.C. or California Bay Area, pending Rich's travel schedule)

$1,000 Meant to Bee

Contribute $1,000 today and...

                   

  • Adopt a Hive! We'll put your name on a plaque on one of our hives. 
  • Receive an official certificate and pictures.
  • Plus, quarterly updates on our honeybee farm's progress.

$2,500: Queen Bee

Contribute $2,500 today and...

                      

  • Get 50% off a trip to Nicaragua with us!
  • Receive the Honeybee Care Package (complete with a Spark Ventures t-shirt, sun bleached beeswax lip balm, and a 3 oz jar of honey - see above!)
  • Name our Queen Bee!
  • Receive an official certificate and pictures.
  • Plus, quarterly updates on our honeybee farm's progress.

$5,000: Bee Calm & Travel On

Contribute $5,000 today and...

               

  • Join us on an exclusive executive trip in Nicaragua! 
  • Travel with Spark's CEO & other business leaders.
  • Spend 4 days experiencing the culture of Nicaragua, learning about our partner organization, volunteering with the children, and see firsthand how Spark and investors are changing lives.  See a sample itinerary here.


AND THE BEST PART...

You're not just writing a check. With our innovative approach to philanthropy, the profits from the honeybee farm will sustain our partner organization, Las Tías, and will help the children of Nicaragua for many years to come. 

               


    THE IMPACT

    Our work in Zambia provides supporters with a proven model of sustainable solutions lifting children out of poverty.

    We invested in a for-profit commercial poultry farm that is currently producing 75,000 chickens each year. The profits sustain a substantial portion of the operations of Hope Community School that now serves over 350 children.

    Since partnering with Asociación Las Tías in 2012, we have invested financial support to increase staff compensation, hire a full time social worker, and ensure the meal program reaches all 150 children served by Las Tías.  There is now a 100% primary graduation rate at our partner facility.   

      Now we just need YOU for our honeybee project to help hundreds of vulnerable                                           children in Nicaragua for years to come.

    OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

    Bee the change you want to see in the world. There are many ways to make a difference!

    • Get the Buzz out! Tweet, Instagram, Facebook, Blog, Buzzfeed? about us!
    • Check out our volunteer trips!
    • Become a sponsor, and donate on a monthly basis!

            How will you SPARK a change in the world?
story_txt:
We are SPARK VENTURES


We can do more together than we can alone.

UPDATE: A generous investor has agreed to contribute $1,000 if we can reach 200 contributors to the campaign. Contributions of ANY AMOUNT count towards our headcount, so just $2 could mean $1002 for our work!!

Thousands of children are living in poverty in Nicaragua, the second poorest country in the Western Hemisphere.  We are here to change that, but we need you.

Spark Ventures is a Chicago-based non-profit that partners with international grassroots organizations to help children in poverty with education, nutrition, and healthcare.  Unlike most organizations, however, we don't believe in just writing a check.  

We call it business driven philanthropy.  


We invest time and resources into a new business opportunity.
The business creates local jobs & sustainable products.
The profits help support high impact programs to lift children out of poverty.

story:
Top Down Car Racing Game

I'm in the process of making a top down racing game.

I want to create images that I own full rights to.

This includes all game elements, menus, and splash screens.

With your help I can achieve this.

Here are some current mock ups:

Above, an original car for the game.

Above an arrow for showing direction on the track.


Above, part of the HUD system.

A mock-up of part of the actual race track.


I'm not after a lot of cash for this project, just $700 and there's some great perks available.

story:
Story

As the father of 12+ children from birth, foster, and adoption, I have worked with both “at risk” children and parents, and I have had the opportunity to see the system in work.  I have noticed a severe gap in the support structure of the current system.  If an adult needs rehabilitation then the system steps in and puts the person in a facility that helps them change the habits that landed them there in the first place.  When this works, the system assists them with living arrangements and a monthly allowance for food and living expenses.  This welfare state is where a lot of them stagnate and basically live off the system for as long as possible.  Children born into this situation often repeat this pattern. A similar situation occurs with children brought into foster care as a teenager.

There are some individuals that, when in the situation where they are being supported by the system, decide that they want to make their own way.  They step out and try to make a go of it on their own.  Lacking the skills and/or education needed for a higher paying careers, they take the only thing available to them; minimum wage jobs.  This is where the system fails them.  If they earn enough of a wage on their own then they are no longer eligible for public assistance or public housing. The problem is that the line for how much they can earn is way below what it takes to actually survive and contribute to society.  It seems as if the system is set up to keep them from making the move to independence.   

  This is where we want to help.  We want to use a little bit more money and time to train “at risk” teens and rehabilitated adults in trade skills, arts, and crafts.  These skills will allow the newly trained to enter the job market with a set of skills that will allow them to provide for themselves.  The time and money used to train these individuals will help remove their need for public assistance.

We are looking for the startup capital to build the classroom, buy tools and materials, and to hire the trainers for the first round of training.  After the facility shows it can work, corporate and government grants will be resourced to continue the training. 

Please donate what you can, share with others, and follow our progress.  I know a lot of people don’t want to support a cause until they see others doing it… Please be one of the ones that goes first.  Our community needs this.

What We Need & What You Get

We need funding to acquire our work space and the tools needed to teach. Your contributions will go to the purchasing of a workshop and tools such as plasma cutters, welders, and similar.

Some things that will be awarded to contributors will be, bracelets, necklaces, free or reduced labor costs, and free lessons for you and your group. Rewards will be determined based on the quantity of the contribution. If you pass a particular checkpoint you will receive all previous awards in addition to that checkpoint.

    The Impact

    In our experience with foster care and rehabilitated adults we've noticed that the programs in place fall short. Foster Care and Rehab facilities give an individual support up until they begin to support themselves. Once someone begins to get back on their feet the support is pulled out from underneath them and they fall back into their old patterns. We want to bridge this gap, we want to give people an opportunity to learn a marketable skill so they can enter the workforce,support themselves, and become a contributing member of society. 

    One of our goals is to sell our crafted items at festivals, fairs, and conventions.  This will give the students the opportunity to sell their crafts and actually reap a reward for their work.  The plan is to "lend" the students the materials and location to work and then they only repay when the items sell.  Along with the crafting sales we plan on teaching some trade skills like auto maintenance, welding, and plumbing. Not only will this fill a need for the students, These "blue collar" jobs will help fill needs in the community also. 

      Risks & Challenges

      We realize that this goal is full of challenges. We know that despite our intentions we can't help everyone. In our minds it is worth the trouble to help one person better themselves.  We will need further funding in the future but plan on seeking federal, state and local grants along with commissions from paying customers. We also are working on getting non-profit charity status so the donations can be tax deductible.  We are fully aware that our skill sets may not fit all potential clients, but with the setup we are considering, there will be plenty of room for other professionals and tradesmen to come teach.

        Other Ways You Can Help

        If you can't contribute please share our goal with your friends, family, co-workers, and anyone who you think would be willing to support our ideas.  If you or your company wants to donate materials, tools, or even time please do not hesitate to contact us through this page.

story:
Dear Friends and Family,

As you may or may not know, I was offered a special invitation to attend the 2014 Global Leadership Awards in Washington D.C.

 At this event, Vital Voices, an organization that was founded 17 years ago Hilary Clinton and  Madeleine Albright,  will pay tribute to visionary leaders on the front-lines of change who safeguard human rights, combat corruption and ignite economic opportunity.

Through my community involvement and connections, the Northwest Chapter of Vital Voices generously offered me a seat at the event, where I will get to meet amazing women like Hillary Clinton and Madeleine Albright.

This is one of the most exciting opportunities I have received so far and it’s so hard to let it go because of financial reasons.

Networking with high caliber and internationally focused professionals could help me tremendously in shaping my career path and open doors for my next steps.

Not to mention the possibility of meeting Hillary Clinton!!!!!

It would mean the world to me if you can help me raise funds for my airline ticket to D.C. Luckily; I have a place to stay for the period of time that I will be in the area. Anything you can give even just $5 would be greatly appreciated.

In return of your contribution, I will babysit your kids, wash your car, clean your house and most importantly love you forever!!!

Thank you for your consideration.

Much love,

Majd
