story:
Short Summary.

My name is Ignatius Wandera, 25 years old from Kenya, currently in my last academic year, 4th year doing Bachelor of Education degree  specializing in mathematics and geography  in one of our local public university here in Kenya called  Masinde Muliro University of Science and Technology.  I joined the university five years ago, 2009,  but I have been experiencing difficulties in getting funds to  for my education. Am appealing to anyone to help raise the $1200 as part of fees required this semester. I am truly hoping with your help I will finally be able to get enough money to supplement with  $300  that I have. Below are scanned documents showing that am still pursuing my education in Masinde Muliro University of Science and Technology  

My student ID

My first admission letter


My Re-admission letter after two years deferment

Dean's letter showing that am still a student of MMUST


My Story

Our degree program take a period of four years of two semesters each. I am currently in my last academic year but in my first semester which runs from 5th September up to December 19th. Thereafter we will go for school practice/attachment from 5th January up to 10th April next year. We will then take a break of about four weeks then we will report back on 5th May for our second semester which will run four 16 weeks up to 21st August. That will now be the end of my four year program which will have taken 6 years because of the deferment of two years i took that was as result of financial hurdles I was facing lack of funds. Last semester which ended just a month ago, was good to me because I did not find any difficulty in paying the college fees because I supplemented your immense contribution with what i had saved. My semester fee requirement is $1,500 and last semester I had around $700 which I had saved. This semester am only having $300 which am hoping to supplement with what I will manage to raise, am actually hoping to raise $1200. For the past one year I've had no any part time work to help me raise any amount that would help me pay for my college fees and am really hoping people will help raise the amount so that i finish the journey i started 5 years ago. That is why I have set a period of 4 weeks so as am able to reach the goal target. Am appealing to everyone to help raise the $1200 as part of fees required this semester. I am truly hoping with your help I will finally be able to get enough money to supplement with  $300  that I have.

The Impact

My university education has always meant the world to me and I never thought I would go through such a rough patch in my life causing me to feel depressed and down on myself. Any amount of money would help me. 

If anyone has any questions about my campaign or would like to talk to me about anything I have written you can contact me via email at iggywan@gmail.com or call +254712539910

Other Ways You Can Help

All I can ask of you if you can not help me is to:

Ask you to get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.

Remind you to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Share it on any social sites that you visit

If you feel contributing online to be unsafe then you can contact me on +254712539910 or iggywan@gmail.com

Any amount will help, thank you.
THANK YOU IN ADVANCE!!!!!

As One hand alone does not clap, I am kindly addressing for

your second hand = Your Donation= YOUR UNCONDITIONAL LOVE

 be able to get enough money to supplement with  $300  that I have. Below are scanned documents showing that am still pursuing my education in Masinde Muliro University of Science and Technology  
My student ID


My first admission letter




My Re-admission letter after two years deferment

Dean's letter showing that am still a student of MMUST


  My Story
Our degree program take a period of four years of two semesters each. I am currently
 in my last academic year but in my first semester which runs from 5th 
September up to December 19th. Thereafter we will go for school 
practice/attachment from 5th January up to 10th April next year. We will
 then take a break of about four weeks then we will report back on 5th 
May for our second semester which will run four 16 weeks up to 21st 
August. That will now be the end of my four year program which will have
 taken 6 years because of the deferment of two years i took that was as 
result of financial hurdles I was facing lack of funds.  Last semester 
which ended just a month ago, was good to me because I did not find any 
difficulty in paying the college fees because I supplemented your 
immense contribution with  what i had saved. My semester fee requirement
 is $1,500 and last semester I had around $700 which I had saved. This 
semester am only having $300 which am hoping to supplement with what I will manage to raise, am actually hoping to raise $1200. For the past 
one year I've had no any part time work to help me raise any amount that
 would help me pay for my college fees and am really hoping people will 
help raise the amount so that i finish the journey i started 5 years 
ago. That is why I have set a period of 4 weeks so as am able to reach 
the goal target. Am appealing to everyone to help raise the $1200 as part of fees
 required this semester. I am truly hoping with your help I will finally
 be able to get enough money to supplement with  $300  that I have.
The Impact 
My university education has always meant the world to me and I never thought I would go through such a rough patch in my life causing me to feel depressed and down on myself. Any amount of money would help me. 
If anyone has any questions about my campaign or would like to talk to me about anything I have written you can contact me via email at iggywan@gmail.com or call +254712539910
  Other Ways You Can Help
All I can ask of you if you can not help me is to:
Ask you to get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.
Remind you to use the Indiegogo share tools!
Share it on any social sites that you visit
If you feel contributing online to be unsafe then you can contact me on +254712539910 or iggywan@gmail.comAny amount will help, thank you.THANK YOU IN ADVANCE!!!!!As One hand alone does not clap, I am kindly addressing for
your second hand = Your Donation= YOUR UNCONDITIONAL LOVE

story:
Didier Ortiz Campaign

Who am I?

I grew up in the City of Fort Lauderdale. I went to school and to a local university. In my formative years, I rode the bus everywhere I went to. I saw the same faces on a regular basis and got to know a lot of the people in my community that way. One constant theme, however, was that I saw a disproportionate amount of single mothers of color raising 3 to 4 children at a time. I decided to run to help out the youth in my community.

What Do I Want To Do?

I want to:
Put a camera on every police officer.
We can, and must, put an end to police brutality. My district is a minority-majority district that has, for too long, known the power of police overreach. A camera would keep the citizenry safe and the police accountable.
'Ban The Box' in Fort Lauderdale.
The 'Ban the Box' campaign seeks to remove the box in job application that ask applicants if they have ever been convicted for a felony. While I believe that an employer has the right to check an employees criminal background, I also understand the struggle that black and brown youth go in looking for employment after being targeted by the futile War on Drugs. Banning the Box would give an opportunity to disadvantaged people at getting an interviewing making their case to an employer. This in turn, would keep our youth aloof from a life of crime.
$15 minimum wage.
We need it. It's coming. Let's make it happen quicker.

What Will I Do With The Funding?

Mailings. My volunteers and I will personally seek to hand-write a letter to all the supervoters (those who always vote) in  my district. We are running a grassroots campaign in an open race. The majority of our mailing budget will go to postage since paper and envelopes are not as costly. We will also set up events to directly reach families and youth in the district.

Who Am I Connected To?

I have not, and will not, seek any backing from corporate interests. I will only take donations from real people like you and me.

story:
*Yes, we have exceeded the campaign goal, BUT it would be amazing to keep this momentum up and double it by the end of the campaign (July 30th)! The basic costs of the camp are now covered,  but now that I am on the ground in northern Lebanon I have identified a serious gap in funding to ensure the camp's lasting impact. YES the week-long camp is looking more and more like it will be an amazing experience for the children as well as the Syrian and Lebanese of all ages involved in terms of music, arts, recreation, environmental activities, teambuilding, cross-culture communication, etc. THAT BEING SAID one of the main objectives is to motivate children who are not in school (and haven't been since the beginning of the crisis in Syria!) and those struggling in school to take advantage or their current educational opportunities in a very self-empowering way. This will be accomplished through fun, engaging educational activities aimed to instill excitement and a more solid foundation in the French language (which the Lebanese curriculum uses). SO with the extra money raised after $6,000 we will be able to fund school-support classes to start after the camp and continue into the school year. These classes are taught by local Lebanese teachers who have already been hired and trained by R&R. So PLEASE consider contributing and sharing this campaign widely so that together we can support a program dedicated to having a lasting impact on the future of Syrian refugee children that otherwise are at risk of becoming part of a "lost generation".

Expense price amount days total
Round trip transportation for mountain trip (~33 kids) $100 1 2 $200
Round trip transportation for mountain trip (~14 kids) $50 1 2 $100
Lunch $4 70 6 $1,680
Fruit and water $1 70 6 $420
Mountain Guide (entire day) $40 2 2 $160
various sports equipment (balls,jump rope, etc.) 200 1 1 $200
baseball caps (for group ID and for sunny hikes) 1 50 1 $50
derbekkes (Arabic drums) 17 15 1 $255
art supplies 200 1 1 $200
Other materials / unexpected costs (first aid, special activities etc.) $752 1 1 $752
breakfast and dinner for volunteers staying for duration of camp 8 15 5 $600
transportation for volunteers 30 1 5 $150
Camp director's flight $1,198 1 1 $1,198
camp director living expenses 200 1 1 $200
school-support classes for two months (summer) 470 2 1 $940
    total $7,105
anything beyond $7,105 will go toward school support classes to continue through the school year ($320 / month).


And here is the original narrative for this project:

Aid agencies have declared the Syrian refugee crisis to be the worst humanitarian disaster in modern times. This is an opportunity for you to directly contribute to the humanitarian response to this disaster by supporting a summer program for youth in northern Lebanon.

Background

In many ways refugee youth are hit the hardest in this crisis—having fled their war-torn country only a small percentage of them are receiving education. Most suffer from conflict-related trauma and their current living conditions leave little room for healthy recreation and creative expression that can help them heal and grow. Syrian families are scattered throughout the country and mixed into the already diverse fabric of sectarian Lebanese society.

From 2013-2014, I became intimately aware of these issues as I developed lasting relationships of trust with both Syrians and Lebanese in northern Lebanon. I established a community-based environmental center (www.facebook.com/AyounCenter) (with a grant from Davis projects for Peace  http://www.davisprojectsforpeace.org/media/view...) and was a volunteer with the Belgian-based international NGO called Relief and Reconciliation for Syria, or R&R Syria (www.reliefandreconciliation.org).

Together with my local partners and the support of R&R, I have been planning this summer camp and the local capacity-building involved with it. Now I’m ready to travel back to Lebanon to fill the crucial role in putting it all into action.


What exactly will I be doing in Lebanon?

  If I meet my goal in this crowdfunding effort, I will return to the north of Lebanon in late July this summer. First I will continue to develop local volunteer groups composed of Lebanese, Syrians, and internationals that I helped establish last year. These groups will allow for dialogue and new understanding among the people now living in the same village and facing the same systemic injustices from governments and other agencies, and also form a committed and motivated support group to carry out the six-day summer camp for children at the end of August.

The summer camp will involve 50-70 Syrian youth between the ages of 10 and 16. The camp will focus on providing fun, educational outlets for Syrian youth in a safe setting where they receive personal attention from leaders. Activities will include interactive French and English education (to help them succeed in school), music, theater, art, recreational activities, and environmental education (hiking, treasure hunts, organic farming, rural food production, natural sciences). There will be at least two days when we take day trips out of the overpopulated and oftentimes chaotic village to the environmental center and breathtaking natural surroundings to carry out activities there.


Where exactly will your money go? (see bottom for specific breakdown)

The unparalleled severity of the Syrian crisis has come in and out of the spotlight of mainstream media and many of us have probably asked ourselves how we can help. This is an opportunity to bypass bureaucratic and potentially tainted conventional aid avenues such that your money will go directly to a project that values lasting impact over temporary relief.

story:
The Mission

My name is Yeisie (jc) Marie Mateo and I have been working in the child protective field for the past 12 years. The welfare of children all over the world has been of high interest for me and my family. I was first introduced to missions work at age 18 and have since been passionate about third world country affairs, mainly associated with our little ones.

Recently, I was privileged to work and be part of two orphanages in Ghana, Africa where 450 orphans are receiving care and attention. Many of the newborn babies were left to die at outhouses without much hope to live and were brought to the orphanage; they are now in better health. Most of the children were found wondering the streets and markets without eating for days.

Even though we have been able to increase the quality of life for our children by providing two meals a day and clean water, the current orphanage is extremely lacking the appropriate space and safety measures to house the amount of children currently there.

Most of the children are sleeping on mats in a cramped small room with no type of ventilation.

The Ghanaian government does not provide any type of shelter for orphans but yet, are threatening to close orphanages that are not up to code. Our current orphanage is not meeting their guidelines; if closed, the children will be left to die in the waste side.

What grew even heavier in my heart was listening to the radio in Ghana and learning that 1.2 million children are currently sold into slavery. What is worst it that these children are overworked, malnourished and without anyone to protect them. 

With your contribution, we will be able to build a new orphanage in a safer area of Ghana and serve more orphans. The land has already been purchased and the foundation has been built. Unfortunately, we are short by $25,000 to complete the three floor building.

This new orphanage will be able to comfortably house a minimum of 550 children. They will have access to clean, functioning bathrooms. They will be able to sleep on mattresses; most of them for the first time. Our kids will have education and the medical attention they need. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are in need of raising $25,000. While we were there this August, we were informed that each floor level would cost $10,000 to build. This is including building materials and labor. Already, we have provided a sum of $5,500 to begin the ground floor.
  • Your contribution goes directly to help build the new orphanage. Depending on the amount you give today you have the option to donate a tile, get that tile personalized all the way to providing enough fund to build a bedroom, bathroom or even a playground. Personalized with your own message of hope or maybe the name of a loved one. Take a look at the list of perks on this page for more details.
  • Even if we do not reach our goal, the funds collected will go directly to the new building efforts. Rest assured every cent will be used to build a new, comfortable and clean home for these children.

The Trip

It’s been approximately a month since I returned from Ghana and my heart remains there. It is easy to disconnect from what we do not see but now that I have seen with my own two eyes, how can I disconnect?

I hope I have given you a glimpse of the need our children in Ghana through my eyes and for you to know how great of a change you can make with the amount you are able to contribute today. 

Prior to the start of this campaign, I was allowed to speak at different functions with the purpose of raising funds and collecting goods for hygiene care and products, medicine and clothing. It is with great joy that we announce that we were able to provide all these items and much more thanks to those contributors. Most of the children in this video were infected with ringworms; they have now been treated for it. 

Challenges

I understand that with every endeavor, comes challenges. We are currently working in collaboration with a team of responsible, hardworking individuals who are completely invested in the well-being of our children in Ghana. We are ready to confront whatever obstacles come our way in order to complete “the big house”! 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know not everyone is able to make a monetary donation but be not dismayed there are other ways you can help and we love all the help we can get. Here are some ways to help.  

  • Spread the word. Tell anyone who will listen about this worthy cause. If you are in need of a flyer to share with your church or other organization please feel free to contact us (info at yeisiemarie.com).
  • Organize a fundraising event. If you are willing and able to organize an event we are more than willing to come and speak and help with the event. Contact us for more info  (info at yeisiemarie.com).
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools! The simplest and easiest way to help. Just click on the social network you wish to spread the word and let your friends and family know of this worthy cause. Adding your own personal message will help even more.

story:
Short Summary

Hello, my name is Kiva Sam. I am a member of the Oglala Sioux Tribe on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, a Dartmouth alum (class of 2012), and a high school social studies teacher at Little Wound High School.

Statistics indicate that for every 100 Native American students graduating from high school, 10 will apply to college, 2 will be accepted, and 1 will graduate with a 4-year college degree. I know these statistics greatly resemble my own educational experience on the reservation as well as an unfortunate reality that persists today. 

It is for this reason that I proposed the “Meaningful College Visit” trip out to the Ivy League schools as a way to bring awareness to the overall college experience.  I want our students to be able to see what top universities can offer them and how their education can lead to positive change on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation.


What We Need & What You Get

In order to take 6 students on a 10 day college visit trip at Columbia, Dartmouth, Harvard, and Upenn, we need to raise $9000.00. We have already secured $2,000 through our own fundraising efforts and have received contributions from College Access and the Gifted and Talented Program at Little Wound High School. Here is a breakdown of our budget:

  • $4500.00 will go on multi-city airfare from Rapid City, SD to Boston, MA and from Philadelphia, PA to Rapid City, SD. 
  • $1800.00 will go on meals.
  • $1550.00 will go on travel between schools and to events.
  • As college is much more than the school itself, the remainder of our budget allows our students to get exposed to the area surrounding these schools (such as museums, Broadway play, sports game, etc.).
While our goal is set at $4,000, we still need to raise around $6,000. In the event that we do not meet our $9,000 goal, we will not be able to take all 6 outstanding students. So any contributions you make will be greatly appreciated!


The Impact

I know that if I didn't have the help and support from others, I may not have graduated from Dartmouth nor returned home to teach at Little Wound High School. I am extremely thankful for those who have taken a chance in supporting my academic endeavors.

Upon completion of the trip, selected students will be required to present information regarding their meetings with admissions and financial aid officers, current college students, as well as their notes about the opportunities and resources offered by each of the Ivy League schools to the entire Little Wound High school student body.

These students who were selected for the trip all have the ability to gain acceptance into one of these schools and all share the desire to utilize their education to help create a lasting impact in their communities. 

I believe that our children are our future, and unless we take the time to invest in their education, we may not see progress on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot make a donation, you can still help us meet our goal. Please share our message with others at school, at work, or through Facebook. 

Thank you for all of your help in making this trip a reality for our students!

Pilamaya ye (Thank you),

Upon completion of the trip, selected students will be
required to present information regarding their meetings with admissions and
financial aid officers, current college students, as well as their notes about
the opportunities and resources offered by each of the Ivy League schools to
the entire Little Wound High school student body.
These students who were selected for the trip all have the ability to gain acceptance into one of these schools and all share the desire to utilize their education to help create a lasting impact in their communities. I believe that our children are our future, and unless we take the time to invest in their education, we may not see progress on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation. Other Ways You Can HelpEven if you cannot make a donation, you can still help us meet our goal. Please share our message with others at school, at work, or through Facebook. Thank you for all of your help in making this trip a reality for our students!Pilamaya ye (Thank you),

story:
Generations of students were directly supported by Charles V. Willie at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, now is our chance to give back and honor him for the support, guidance and intellectual space he created for his "scholars". 


A group of alumni have come together to launch the inaugural Charles V. Willie Keynote address at the 2015 Harvard Graduate School of Education Alumni of Color Conference. 

The Conference will be held on Friday, February 27 and Saturday, February 28, 2015.

We hope to be able to establish this as an annual event that will honor other faculty, staff, alumni and current students but are beginning with 2015. 

If you can contribute to this cause, please donate. If you are interested in helping beyond your financial contribution, please be in contact.

Please share this campaign with other alumni, people who appreciate Dr. Willie's work and impact and with all those concerned with equity, justice and social action.

There is so much more that can be done, and so much that each of us is doing in their own way. While not everyone can attend, let's come together via this campaign to celebrate, recommit and renew ourselves for the fights ahead. We are always stronger in community and it has been too long since we were together. 

To use a quote that has come back into fashion, "Because of Them, We Can..."

story:
This campaign marks the launch of the Japanese Earthen Plaster Exchange, a project to support and spread Japan’s rich tradition of earthen architecture. The JEPE will send three craftspeople from the U.S. to Japan to study under experts in the ancient tradition of Japanese plastering which, using earth and straw, has produced the walls of enduring castles, peaceful temples, and simple elegant tea houses for many centuries. These earthen walls have a modern sensibility, masking the ages-old skill involved in their creation.  That’s the beauty of it.  You can't tell it's clay, but it is. And the use of earth has many beneficial consequences for our health.  It feels wonderful to be inside these health-giving spaces.

Essentially, we want to bring the outdoors in for everyone.  Scientific studies show that clays hold negative ionic charges, and we know that we need negative ions for optimal health.  This research article does a good job of gathering studies that have recognized various benefits, from fostering simple feel-good sensations to actually enhancing our immune system.  We gain these benefits when earthen plasters are the skins of our rooms, releasing negative ions into the air as they absorb moisture from our daily activities.

While the existence of an earthen plastering tradition is largely unknown outside Japan, it unfortunately is nearly obsolete in its industrialized homeland.  There is an urgent need to learn to use the tools and techniques of Japan’s earthen plastering tradition, and share them with the West's building trade.  We believe that Japanese-style earthen walls will appeal to the Western public.  By increasing exposure to these beautiful earthen surfaces, and making "earthen plasters" a household term, we can help soothe the anxiety that pervades our modern age, and improve individual health. 

The results of our training can also improve upon Japanese gardens in the U.S., whose structures too often lack the authentic surfaces which are traditionally a defining characteristic of these serene spaces.  The healing qualities of these gardens will be enhanced by ensuring this aspect is not missing.

Please visit our website for further details of the project's health benefits, its motivations, and its team members. 

Thanks to swift and generous supporters, we have reached our primary goal of raising $1,000 for our first campaign.  The purpose of this campaign has been to fulfill our sponsor Fractured Atlas’s requirement: to prove there is a public out there who wants our project to succeed.  Securing grants will be critical in raising nearly $250,000, the amount we need to comply with Japan’s visa restrictions during our training.  Now that we have reached our initial goal of proving public support, we have the green light to approach grant-makers (THANK YOU!).  From this point, the more we raise, the more we demonstrate we are embarking on a worthy and important mission recognized by the public: you.  And we want to know who, and how many of you, there are!  Just a $1 donation from each of you will help make that happen.

TRAINING: Emily will begin a two year apprenticeship in Kyoto in April 2016, with Shikkui Asahara, a company that works exclusively with traditional methods and materials, primarily to maintain cultural heritage structures.  That October, Wolfgang and Angela will begin a full-time six-month training program at a plaster school in Kyoto, the only school in the country that offers training in traditional earthen techniques.  During this time and after their course, they will also seek to connect to, and learn from, earthen builders practicing actively in Japan.  Upon returning to the U.S. all three of us will integrate this experience into our own work.  We will utilize public media and hold workshops to spread this knowledge both within the mainstream building industry and among the tight-knit, and only three-decades-young, natural building community. We will build bridges so others can access this knowledge directly, and spread the benefits of earthen plasters.

Your support fuels our success.  Every contribution counts, and is deeply appreciated.

May you know the joy of earthen plasters.

With gratitude,

the Japanese Earthen Plaster Exchange team

thejepe.org
*****   *****   *****   *****   *****   *****   *****   *****   *****   *****   *****   *****

Here are images of some of our gifts for your generous donations!

Handmade Journals:


Japan's Clay Walls book:

story:
Be sure to watch our video...

Association for Human-Animal Bond Studies has recently formed a partnership with the Braille Institute - San Diego to offer the Critter Companions series of classes.

What is Critter Companions?

Critter Companions classes teach people how to take care of a small pet.

The Impact

As part of the Braille Institute's Life Skills series of classes we are offering Critter Companions to students free of charge.  We will reach approximately 30 students per week for a 16-week semester.

Our Challenge

At the end of the semester the cost to the Association for Human-Animal Bond Studies will be anywhere from $9,600 to $10,000 which covers the entire cost of materials and care for the animals, as well.  With your help, we can continue to offer these classes beyond the initial semester and begin to include adult students.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Guitars are something that entice people of all age, ethnicity, gender, and race.  Constructing one is an activity that covers a vast array of science, technology, engineering, art, & mathematics (STEAM).  It is a huge movement in American education right now that engages young learners in a hands on class that immediately teaches applications of learned skills and concepts from other disciplines.

The funding that we are seeking is to purchase a CNC Router for our school to further our existing STEAM Guitar Building class.  It is very popular, and with a CNC Router we could add the next level of education by including the CAD (Computer-Aided-Design) programming and manufacturing portion of the build.   A CNC router is a computer controlled cutting machine.  Instead of hand-held routing, or purchasing parts cut from a company with a CNC (what we currently do), we would design and manufacture the parts ourselves.   Having this sophisticated piece of equipment will allow us to reduce our costs of creating the guitar kits used by students and will teach students more skills of technical drawing, engineering, & manufacture.
Every dollar raised will go to purchasing this special and specific piece of equipment.  If we do not reach our goal then the funds will be used to purchase other of the very specific luthier (guitar building) tools necessary that are of lower price tag, as well as being used to purchase materials to build with for students that cannot afford their own.
Your contribution will impact teen learners of various economic and social backgrounds in developing a deep connection between the skills learned in High School and beyond to the types of creative careers available in the job market of today.

    Even if you cannot contribute to our cause, perhaps you know of an American business that would love to have sharp young minds with these engineering skills come into their workplace and you'd like to make them aware of our cause.  Or perhaps you know other individuals that may be interested in our fundraiser & you can pass the information to them.  That can be extremely helpful in making the dream come true.

    Don't forget your Indiegogo share tools!

      Thank you so much for supporting our youth.

story:
Who is AVEC?

AVEC International is a registered Charity and non- governmental organization (Reg no. 10561). With its head office in Kampala,Uganda.

It was started in April 2013 by a group of Social Workers motivated by the social work principle of restoring the social functioning and improvement of the quality of life and well-being of individuals, groups and communities in Uganda and the world at large.

Initial assessment meant to identify key local problems and conditions of the elderly and vulnerable children was carried out in Mityana, Wakiso, Kayunga, Gulu (Northern Uganda which was affected by Joseph KONY Rebels LRA), Kamuli and Kampala districts of Uganda in early 2013. This provided basis for evidence-based decision making process as a fundamental principle upon which the organization was formed and operates.

Your can check on our website for more information: www.http://avecinternational.org/about-us.html


Help build a classroom for children in Africa is a campaign to build classrooms in two schools in Mugoye - Kalangalo Sub-county,Mityana District-Uganda. One of the objectives of AVEC International is to promote education and this is done through soliciting for funds to improve the poor  conditions in which the children are studying in order to improve their performance and therefore their future. During a needs assessment carried out by AVEC international it was found out that the children were affected by the poor  conditions in which they studied.These study  in structures made from trees and papyrus mats,both rain and sunshine affects the children leading to poor performance

Your Impact

More than ever children in Africa urgently need your help. They are asking us not for aid, but to teach them to fish by giving them an education. Please browse our campaign and donate today. Thank you for your gift and for helping us reach children in Africa with a lifelong gift of education.



What You Get in Return


  • Website Acknowledgement ( www.avecinternational.org )
  • personalized African bracelets
  • African Print  T-shirt
  • Hand made woven Mat
  • African Picnic Baskets
  • African bread baskets


Our Mission: 

is to wholly transform the lives of elderly people and vulnerable children in societies in but not limited to Uganda.

Our Vision:

To improve the quality of life of elderly people and vulnerable children by providing integrated family care and community based services to enable them become self reliant and productive members of society both economically and socially.

Our core values are:-

i)  Team work

ii)  Transparency; and

iii)  Accountability

iv)  Integrity



Other Ways You Can Help

As we move forward we require the assistance of knowledgeable parties with the development and or implementation of our education and outreach project. Organizations with expertise on a particular issue in education facilitation of AVEC International community are requested to help identify topics that should be used to improve education programs in Uganda.

Individuals are welcome to join as members of AVEC International to volunteer or to simply stay connected. Partner Organizations including non-profits, businesses and government agencies will support our vision and mission as noted above and will communicate our goals to their staff and potentially the wider community. Should your organization be interested in partnering with AVEC International e-mail to us: admin@avectional.org and volunteers should . e-mail tovolunteer@avecinternational.org

Please share this campaign with family, friends, co-workers, and whomever else you think would be interested in helping out.

story:
What kind of shape is learning?
How can learning be shaped?


The learning tangram is an easy visual tool to reflect about learning.  
Learning tangram invites you to sit calmly and reflect about the relationship between learning and space in a playful way.

One of the previous project I worked on was the creation of the Compass Card Decks. This is a portable set of cards that collect 60 participatory knowledge methods that trainers can use during training.  

Following on this project, I tried to organize all the information that I've collected in a new participatory game that permits to reflect about learning style and spaces.

I like a visual style of learning.

I was curious to visualize what kind of learner I was.  I understood how I liked to learn and how various different approaches appealed to my sensitivities but did not have an effective way to visualize this.  I developed the learning tangram as a tool to help me achieve this.

Learning Tangram represents a new way for considering the role of different learning aspects such as space and environment, issues that are often superficially overlooked.
Instead of having to read a manual or paper, the Learning Tangram invites you to reflect about and then visualize your personal relationship with how you learn.

How does it work?

How I visualized my learning needs:


While I was studying Architecture at Politecnico di Milano I found myself in a really creative space.  When designing the Learning Tangram I wanted to visualize my learning experience during this time.

So, I took the Learning Tangram and I started to play.
First I paired each learning aspect with a shape in the tangram, then I ordered the shapes according to which aspects most reflected how I like to learn.

When I had finished I had the discovered the seven shapes that best respested the way I liked to learn.  I then began arranging the shapes I had selected into a design that I could allow me to visualise how I liked to learn. I moved the seven elements around the table in several different combinations.  Finally the seven elements came together into the shape of a home, this reminded me of my studies in architecture and I felt I had discovered the perfect visual representation of how I like to learn.

When can I use the Learning Tangram? 

The learning tangram is a game and tool that realizes that learning is a fluid and always changing process. Different people learn in different ways and understand how you learn is key to success.  Its purpose is to figure out how people perceived the educational process, and at the same time, embrace or create new learning patterns.  And it is fun.

 The Learning Tangram can be used by anyone but is primarily aimed at people involved in educational process: students, learners, teachers and trainers.  
In this context it would be perfect for workshops and team sessions.


For example, the Learning Tangram activity could be used before a training course as a means to establish what kind of learners are going to be attending and which methods are likely to achieve the best results.  

The Learning tangram can also be used during course: when you want introduce the learning topic in an unconventional way; or just use it to reflect about the different learning styles.

Use the Learning Tangram after the course: when you want to evaluate a learning activity or why a training has perhaps not had the impact hoped for.

Now it is the time to play.


Learning updates: 

As an added value to the campaign I will be offering ongoing updates about my research on the role of physical space and the learning process. During the campaign period you will be able to attend five micro lessons on the following topics:

  1. What does the Learnscape mean?

  2. How learning is changing. From formal models towards informal patterns.

  3. The third trainer. Why and how space affects learning.

  4. Design with patterns. The architectural pattern

  5. Build a new learning environment. Tips and tools.


What We Need & What You Get

Everything is ready: I have the mock-up and the instructions booklet. But this kind of product really needs an high quality production that will last around two months: then I'll start to pack and ship in order to let you receive your Learning Tangram around the middle of February.

story: N/A

Dinosaur Hunter, Teacher, Science Advocate

I am the recent recipient of the Presidential Award for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching, representing New York State. As a kindergarten teacher who brings paleontology into my classroom through research and a simulated dinosaur dig each year based on my own experiences in the field, I realize there is a great need to provide young children with early exposure to science concepts that integrate many disciplines, including technology, engineering, and mathematics. This became clear when I asked my students how scientists in the field would transport a 600 pound fossil down a hillside safely, which led to great discussion. In order to develop problem-solving skills and collaboration among students, I am developing a series of lessons in a unit that teach children as young as five to write code and program user-friendly robots to complete a series of challenges. I want to harness my students' curiosity and innovation in a way that empowers them as learners and helps them develop analytical and social skills.

Kid-friendly Technology

With your support, early childhood classrooms like mine would have access to Play-i robots, a new design available in the next few months from www.play-i.com, as well as Bee-Bots. The robots, Bo and Yana, can work independently or interactively to follow the programming done by students on Bluetooth-enabled devices, such as iPads. Students will work in small groups to develop solutions to problems involving structures, elements of force and motion, and navigation through mazes, building higher-order thinking. Yana tells stories and both robots have attachments that connect to Legos or costume features. After learning the basics in coding via a Bluetooth-based platform and the functions of the Play-i robots, Bo and Yana, as well as Bee-Bots, students will engage in a series of problem-solving design groups to address needs that involve a function, such as cleaning up a pile of Legos, creating a structure such as a bridge that can withstand a particular weight, negotiating a maze-like path without disrupting a block structure,  and establishing a creative design, such as choreography of a mini-skit with characters and dialogue designed for the robots. As one of the first projects to incorporate coding with science, mathematics, literacy, and art, this innovative approach to teaching will empower five-year-olds to problem-solve and work collaboratively as they engage in real-world situations using fundamental skills they will need in the growing global economy.
If our project is not fully-funded, students will use the portion that is funded to build a maker-space in the classroom that will incorporate features of Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, and Mathematics.


Planning It All Out

Taking real-life scenarios and presenting them as problems to solve takes time to plan, as does learning the coding format and coordinating groups as they use them. I intend to collaborate with experts in the field, including the robot designers, to best design a framework for teaching using this uncharted approach to so many disciplines. It will take time and reflection as a teacher, and many hours of preparation and trials.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please get the word out to get this project successfully-funded, via email and social media. Pass it on to friends, family, and co-workers.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Together, we can help give young learners the tools they need to succeed.

Thank you.
story_txt:
Dinosaur Hunter, Teacher, Science Advocate
I am the recent recipient of the Presidential Award for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching, representing New York State. As a kindergarten teacher who brings paleontology into my classroom through research and a simulated dinosaur dig each year based on my own experiences in the field, I realize there is a great need to provide young children with early exposure to science concepts that integrate many disciplines, including technology, engineering, and mathematics. This became clear when I asked my students how scientists in the field would transport a 600 pound fossil down a hillside safely, which led to great discussion. In order to develop problem-solving skills and collaboration among students, I am developing a series of lessons in a unit that teach children as young as five to write code and program user-friendly robots to complete a series of challenges. I want to harness my students' curiosity and innovation in a way that empowers them as learners and helps them develop analytical and social skills.   Kid-friendly Technology
With your support, early childhood classrooms like mine would have access to Play-i robots, a new design available in the next few months from www.play-i.com, as well as Bee-Bots. As one of the first projects to incorporate coding with science, mathematics, literacy, and art, this innovative approach to teaching will empower five-year-olds to problem-solve and work collaboratively as they engage in real-world situations using fundamental skills they will need in the growing global economy.

If our project is not fully-funded, students will use the portion that is funded to build a maker-space in the classroom that will incorporate features of Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, and Mathematics.

I intend to collaborate with experts in the field, including the robot designers, to best design a framework for teaching using this uncharted approach to so many disciplines. It will take time and reflection as a teacher, and many hours of preparation and trials.
  Other Ways You Can Help 
Please get the word out to get this project successfully-funded, via email and social media. Pass it on to friends, family, and co-workers. Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools! 
 Together, we can help give young learners the tools they need to succeed.Thank you.

story:
Roboter in Not - Investieren Sie jetzt in Ihre Zukunft

In Filmen und Computerspielen haben sie längst die Hauptrolle ergriffen; Ex Machina, I robot und Star Wars sind vielleicht die bekanntesten Beispiele. Es steht außer Frage, dass Roboter in der Zukunft eine wichtige Rolle in unserem Leben spielen werden.

Heutzutage haben wir die Chance, selber Roboter zu bauen und zu programmieren, und das ist genau das, was wir vom Königin-Katharina Stift in Stuttgart im Rahmen des FTC-Wettbewerbes getan haben. Ein Wettbewerb, bei dem Schüler eigenständig einen Roboter konstruieren und bauen müssen, der eine Aufgaben erledigt. Im Vordergrund steht dabei nicht nur die Qualität, mit welcher der Roboter letztendlich die Aufgaben erledigt, sondern auch die Planung und Teamarbeit des antretenden Teams. So wurde die über ein 6 Monate dauernde Konstruktion und Bau des Roboters genauestens in einem Teamtagebuch dokumentiert, bis wir endlich im Wettbewerb unser Können zeigen konnten. Willkürlich gebildete Allianzen aus zwei Teams traten gegen eine andere an, wichtig dabei war strategisches Handeln, gegenseitige Rücksicht sowiezusammenpassende Teamarbeit. Dieses Jahr stand ein Roboter auf dem Programm, der in einer autonomen Phase automatisch nach einer vorprogrammierten Handlung und anschließend menschlich gesteuert, Bälle verschiedenster Art in diverse, sich in Höhe und Aussehen unterscheidende Auffangbehälter befördert. Das Prinzip ist einfach, doch die Umsetzung ist schwer und zeitaufwendig, und dennoch, solche „einfachen“ Roboter sind die Grundlage weiterer Entwicklung und daher unverzichtbar.

Doch was haben SIE von all dem Ganzen?

Ganz einfach, unterstützen Sie junge und begeisterte Schüler beim Forschen für die Zukunft und für ein besseres Leben. Helfen Sie uns, auch weiterhin an Robotern zu basteln, indem Sie uns finanziell die Teilnahme am FTC-Wettbewerb ermöglichen. Denn die Jugend von Heute sind die Forscher von morgen!!!

Worum geht es in dem Projekt?

Das Königin-Katharina-Stift nimmt seit 3 Jahren an der First-Tech-Challenge teil, einem weltweiten Roboterwettbewerb für Schüler ab 14 Jahren.Jugendliche im Alter von 14 bis 20 Jahren bauen und programmieren im Team einen Roboter und treten am Wettbewerbstag gegeneinander an. In der Vorbereitung arbeiten die Jugendlichen wie echte Ingenieure – sie planen, bauen, programmieren und dokumentieren im Team. Sie erwerben dabei lösungsorientierte, handwerkliche, organisatorische und soziale Kompetenzen.

Bisher wurden die Roboter über einen Lego-NXT und ein dazugehöriges WLAN-Modul gesteuert. Ab der kommenden Saison (Sep. '15) wird verpflichtend auf spezielle Android-Geräte (spezielles Smartphone mit Snapdragon-Prozessor) umgestellt. Allein die Umstellung auf das neue System kostet für die zwei Teams vom Königin-Katharina-Stift zusammen mindestens 1000Euro. Da bei den letzten Wettbewerben mehrere Motoren durchgebrannt sind und wir noch weitere (in Europa nur schwer oder gar nicht zu beschaffende) Teile dringend benötigen, um gegen die Teams aus Russland, USA, Saudi-Arabien, Italien einigermaßen konkurrenzfähig zu sein benötigen wir noch zusätzlich ca. 1500Euro.

Was sind die Ziele und wer die Zielgruppe?

Das Geld kommt Schülern des Königin-Katharina-Stifts zugute, die in bisher zwei Teams an der First-Tech-Challenge (http://www.first-tech-challenge.org/de/ und http://firsttechchallenge.nl/  in Paderborn und Eindhoven) teilnehmen und ihre Erfahrungen aus dem letzten Jahr verbessern und neue Ideen umsetzen wollen.

Was bekommen SIE dafür?

Sie erhalten die Möglichkeit, uns als Werbeträger zu nutzen, wenn wir mit Ihrem Logo auf dem T-Shirt (je nach Höhe des Untertützungsbetrages  unter Umständen auch auf dem Roboter) bei den Wettbewerben in Paderborn und Eindhoven (und vllt sogar in St. Louis im Weltfinale??) unterwegs sind.



Andere Wege, wie man helfen kann

Manche können einfach keinen Beitrag leisten, das heißt aber nicht, dass sie nicht helfen können:

  • Bitte darum, dass man über deine Kampagne spricht und sie so bekannt macht.
  • Erinnere daran, das Tool von Indiegogo dafür zu nutzen!

Das war es auch schon.

story:
We started a community feeding scheme about four months ago, serving the children in rural communities that get raised in poverty. These kids go to school hungry all too often. We believe that these children are our futures, but the average income for parents that are working is usually less than $7 per day, and for those without work, well they are facing an almost impossible fight for them to support even the most basic of needs to their children.

We started the feeding program in just one rural location, and fed around 220 kids in the first few weeks. Word got around about the project and numbers increased. We started with another location, but because this is a personal funding project, can only go that far.

Seeing these children's faces for the most simple of foods, the gratitude, the friendship, the need, inspired us to try and increase our capability to expand to more than just the two current locations. We urge you to look into your hearts and ask yourself, what if that was my future?

If our goal targets would to be reached, we would like to purchase more supplies to cook food with and deploy more people to become part of our goal. We would need another vehicle to service the other two planned locations we have researched. We would also use the funding to supply more purchases of food supply stocks. $15000 would be spent at around $1000 - $1200 per month throughout the year, in hopes of achieving an new level of numbers we feed. We are currently as mentioned before, feeding between 180 - 260 kids per location during every session.

We would like to see these numbers grow to around 1000 - 1200 with this foundation funding target. Keeping in mind that we have other expenses also, we only pushed for a goal target of $15000 as this is the first time we are using such a platform.

We would however like to see this target be obliterated for the project to expand as far as funding would allow it. People always ask me why i do what i do?...., there are so many reasons, but the one that stands out to me the most, is the humility these poor little children have when they receive a meal and the gratitude that shines off their little faces, this makes me believe that there is no other answer but, its our duty to get involved and love our neighbours.. I believe, this is what Christ meant, when He said; you are to "love thy Neighbour".

Currently we can only carry out our project 3 times per week and we simply don't have the funds or the extra transportation to do this more often than that. We can sustain an extra 500 - 650 kids in the other two locations at around $300 - 350 per week, and our goal is to not only do this 3 times per week, but every morning before school(5days per week), and if our project grows large enough, every afternoon as well. We can however only make this possible with whatever resources we have available to use.

Research shows that breakfast is the most important meal of the day, and most of these children we are in service for, can afford to live on sometimes only one slice of bread for the day. How do we think we would ever make this world a better place, if the ones who carry our futures are suffering beyond measure?. Research also shows that the human body needs to be sustained properly for concentration levels to be raised. We would like to see all children go to school with a sustainable meal and not go hungry.

If you want to help us achieve this goal, and have made a contribution to the cause, we would like to thank you immensely.

Kindest Regards

Bardo

story:
We are seeking funding to expand our current "Minds That Matter" youth Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) program which is a part of our DFW Technical Outreach Community Help (T.O.R.C.H.) Center. The program is designed to cultivate the minds of youth, grades 6 through 8, in the areas of STEM leadership development and public speaking. The approach to reach this goal will include: Skills assessments, academic counseling and mentoring, exposure to strategic thinking methodologies and different levels of recognition. The program is designed to excite student's interest in career fields that they may not otherwise consider viable. Weekly sessions/workshops are held at our center and meals are provided to all students.


Sample Curriculum 

 
  • Construct a Truss Bridge (Civil Engineering)
  • Efficiency Improvement of Systems (Industrial Engineering)
  • Make an Electromagnet (Electrical Engineering)
  • Internal Combustion Engine (Mechanical Engineering)
  • Model Airplanes/Rockets (Aerospace Engineering)
  • Hydrodynamic Building Set (Environmental)


Metrics: Information regarding the demographics of participants are collected at each session and signed by parents/guardians. We also gauge how much students have learned by administering a pre-test and post-test at every workshop/session. These results are then compiled, analyzed and used to modify various components of the applicable curriculum topic. In the future we plan to work closely with Dallas Independent School District (DISD) administrators to collect student academic report cards for further tailor the program to meet the needs for our student participants.


Each month will also include a workshop for students regarding career searches, college prep, standardized testing exam prep., and presentation skills. With the support of the NSBE Alumni Chapter membership each student will also have the opportunity to meet with a professional in their field of interest. Our members work for companies such as Lockheed Martin, Texas Instruments, 3M, Boeing, Chevron, Google, and Dell.


The Need

Science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) are becoming increasingly important in today's career paths but Dallas students are still struggling to reach proficiency with these subjects. According to 2013-2014 scores:

  • An average of 36% 6th garde students are partially or not proficient in math
  • An average of 38% 8th grade students are partially or not proficient in science
  • Averages are even worse in select North Texas Counties
*See more detailed STAAR and SAT Scores here.
There is a clear need for STEM in the DFW area and the NSBE TORCH Center pushes to make these subjects accessible, fun, and inspirational.


Careers in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) are plentiful, but there aren’t enough qualified workers to meet the demand. (Photo by NCES Digest of Education Statistics; Science and Engineering Indicators 2008)



Educational Partners

The goal of this campaign is to increase our impact by decreasing barriers to STEM education. Some of partners and collaborators for this initiative include the following:






Thank you for supporting the National Society of Black Engineers Professionals (Alumni Chapter) and the youth all over DFW.


Donation Perks (Items)


Silver Level Sponsor

Coffee Mug


Gold Level Sponsor

NSBE Messenger Bag and Coffee Mug (see perks for additional details) 


Platinum Level Sponsor

NSBE Fleece and Coffee Mug (see perks for additional details)

story:
Short Summary

Rusalya is a Bulgarian non-profit association with years of experience working with socially disadvantaged children. We have achieved 8 projects in 17 social institutions with over 1300 children at risk aged 3 to 18.

Our new project is a school for arts and crafts for socially disadvantaged children from different ethnicities. We provide free of charge quality education and safe environment (boarding school) for gifted children from extremely poor families. 

Our goal is to develop children's creative and intellectual potential which is our investment in their future.

What We Need & What You Get

The funding we ask for will be invested in building an outdoor sports facility.This would greatly benefit our children's living quality, giving them the opportunity to exercise and play. It would also add to the overall experience in our school, creating a better environment for creativity and self-expression.

The Impact

We give children from poor families with different ethnicities the opportunity to develop their unique qualities and talents. We believe that our efforts will impact not only the communities they come from, but the society as a whole.

Risks & Challenges

The greatest challenge we face on our way to achieving our goal is to overcome the children's social background. Our strategy for solving these challenges is based on our years of experience, clear vision of what we want to achieve and the selection of highly-qualified team, who are fully-committed to the cause. 
Considering the fact that our school is the first one not only in Bulgaria, but also in Eastern Europe, the risks we face are not a few. In addition to that, ensuring the financial stability is something that is an everyday struggle by itself.

story:
The Story So Far

So Here's The Deal...

After applying last year for US citizenship, I finally received the much anticipated letter inviting me to attend the final interview at the end of April. I thought I was just going to get a quick laugh by posting a photo of this suit on my Facebook feed and suggesting in fun that I should wear it to the interview. But after chatting with a friend of mine who has been advocating for her underserved, inner-city school, I thought - well, why not? I'll happily make a (greater) fool of myself if it can raise some support for this very good cause.

Dearborn Park International School

Dearborn Park International School is a K-5 elementary in Seattle's Mid Beacon Hill neighborhood.  Dearborn is a vibrant, happy place with amazingly dedicated teachers and staff. It is home to students and families from many nations and ethnic groups, with many languages spoken by families and children, at home and at PTA meetings, school dinners, and morning drop-off.

Dearborn's student population has a 89.5% rate of Free and Reduced Price Lunch Eligibility, among the highest in the city and state. (For comparison, a Title 1 school only needs 40% eligibility to qualify for additional funds.) Yet there's a lot of motivation in the school: you can see from their website how much they invest in their students.

One full-time counselor is extremely busy, and her position has been cut to half time for next year. The teachers unanimously agreed to forgo school supplies, field trip buses, and other essentials such as photocopying in order to scrape together the money to fund the counselor full time next year.

What I Need

It's simple. I'll make a complete fool of myself and wear the suit to the USCIS for my interview in return for my friends generously donating money to the school to help them fill the shortfall. The money will go directly to their PTA, which is a registered 501(c)3.

Risks & Challenges

 Clearly there are many risks and challenges associated with this, not limited to:
  • Deportation
  • Imprisonment
  • Others having a jolly good laugh at my expense
Nevertheless, I'm willing to put myself at great personal risk in the service of Dearborn's school supplies.

Update 4/19/15

The suit has arrived!

How can I not win over even the most po-faced immigration officer looking so... American? In fact, I fear I will intimidate them into questioning whether their own love of their country. This is what the founding fathers would have worn if polyester was invented in the 1700s. 

It's not too late to give. The more money you offer to this incredibly worthy cause, the more you demonstrate your own love of our great nation. If you just enjoy my humiliation without giving, you're as bad as an NPR listener who refuses the cloying pleas of the annual pledge drive and just mooches slightly liberal conversation without paying. So, please give :)

Update 4/29/15

Today is the day! I was up early this morning to get dressed in my full outfit. My wife has more or less disowned me at this point; she's ready to bail me out from the county jail but that's about it. The children are genuinely worried that we'll be moving back to the UK in the next couple of weeks after my green card is revoked.

I want to just take a moment to thank you all so much for your generosity so far. At the close of the campaign, we've together raised nearly $1,300 for Dearborn Park, which will truly make a considerable impact. This isn't like many of the schools on the Eastside, with a PTA who can raise a six figure sum of money with a school auction. It's great to be able to support a community who needs an advocate or two - and so I'm immensely grateful for so many folk from around the world who've been willing to stand in the gap. THANK YOU!

story:
Professor Sarah Redfield who is a professor at the University of New Hampshire School of Law, currently teaches at Northeastern, and is also a member of the ABA's Coalition on Racial and Ethnic Justice contacted SUFEO to discuss our work in hopes of replicating SUFEO in Chicago as well as having myself and a couple of other members sit on a panel regarding the school to prison pipeline.

The panel will focus on the role that lawyers and law students can play in addressing the school to prison pipeline and the disproportionate number of students of color who are being classified as special ed and who are being pushed out of school.

They would like to hear from groups like SUFEO who are actively representing students through clinic programs or student groups in disciplinary proceedings. Professor Redfield asked asked whether a member of SUFEO could speak on a panel at the first town hall meeting in Chicago on February 7th. 

This is an AMAZING opportunity for Tulane, JJPL and of course SUFEO. Unfortunately Tulane may not be willing to fund this venture. Therefore, I am reaching out to you, the law students and core group of SUFEO, to see if any of you would be interested in helping fund this opportunity.

story:
About Plateau English

Plateau English Education Group is a small team of teachers dedicated to providing education across the Tibetan Plateau.  We mainly focus on materials development, teacher training, and providing university-level ESL classes.  Plateau English emphasizes the need for culturally appropriate materials and methods.   

Help us to go above and beyond

Plateau English members are currently developing textbooks and a website in addition to maintaining their normal teaching and training schedule. In order to go above and beyond, they would like to support a foreign volunteer and hire a program assistant to manage daily accounting, etc.  Additionally, they would like to develop, print sample copies, edit, and pilot their textbooks before sending them to the publishers.  A breakdown of expenses is as follows:

  • materials development $3,000
  • volunteer $6,000 for 6 months
  • program assistant $2,000 for 6 months

The Impacts

The success of this project will impact English language learning across the plateau in several ways:

  • Specialized, trilingual materials will be made available to K-12 teachers across the plateau
  • Local teachers (K-12 and Plateau English) will be trained in current ESL teaching techniques
  • Plateau English will continue teaching approximately 150 BA students

story:
About Foothills Fest

Foothills Fest 2014 aspires to be more than an event. This festival has been created to help growth within the community, both creatively and economically. We are a community of young artists and entrepreneurs willing to go the extra mile in order to benefit the place we call home.

With generous contribution opportunities available, we have set this event up to bring in as many small, local businesses as possible, as well as increasing the communication between small businesses. Better communication leads to better opportunities for growth, which will benefit both the community and the business community. Foothills Fest is important to everyone involved. It gives us the chance to team up and share the same goal:  Raise awareness on supporting local businesses, and helping each other. Let's help small business grow!

Contributors aren't just donating to obtain the perks. They're getting directly involved with the economic and creative growth of the community we call home. We are not just creating a one-day event for people to enjoy, we are creating a one-of-a-kind networking opportunity for small businesses to get involved and reap the benefits. The benefits are endless.

What We Need & What You Get

We have set our IndieGoGo goal at $10,000 to insure our bare minimum expenses, but to also give the community of Marshall another way to help contribute and be a part of the growth of the town’s culture. The overall budget we need to make this year’s Foothills Fest all that it can be is $15,545. The amount we’ve set for ourselves would allow us to fully use our resources and supply the event with entertainment, day-long activities, food & refreshments, merchandise, and much more. We also have to take into account the magnitude of an event like this, with costs of insurance, venue, and utilities. Even if we don’t reach our goal of $10,000, we will prioritize costs and all money contributed will be a huge help in making Foothills Fest happen!

  Budget:

  Marshall Is Music™ Scholarship - $1000
  Venue - $500
  T-Shirts/Merchandise - $1500
  Sponsorship Marketing - $2850
  Insurance - $500
  Marketing - $2545
  Stages & Lighting - $3000
  Band Guarantees - $3650

  Total: $15,545


The Impact

Foothills Fest 2014 is valuable to the contributor in more ways than one. You get to be directly involved with the growth of not only the creative culture, but the community's economy as well. Alongside that, the contributor gets a little piece of FF14 to physically hold and remember the times had & effort spent to create such a beneficial event. Foothills Fest aims to continuously grow a community of hard working, creative individuals willing to go the extra mile to benefit their community. As we grow and reach more of an audience, the benefits will have a unique effect on the world.

When we team up, they have over 5 decades of experience with skills in booking, management, marketing, promotion, community growth, team work, local economic benefits, and more. With over 4 months of effort to make this happen, we just ask for your help in order to make this even better for everyone involved.

Last year the FF community was put in one of the least desirable positions and still prevailed through flash floods, as the crew packed up the entire festival and moved it across town to an indoor venue to ensure a strong finish.


Risks and Challenges

When hosting an event of this magnitude, there are a lot of precautions: bands canceling, lack of cooperation with vendors or artists, weather, insurance, safety, and paperwork. We have set our goal high and eliminated the thought of expectation in order to route us to success most efficiently and in a mentally beneficial fashion. We have taken a whole year to prepare for all that will and could happen. With one of us has traveling across the country researching events alike, meeting with coordinators, living the experiences, and helping them grow, we're taking notes on how to make Foothills Fest thrive.

Solutions to some of these possible challenges have been thought out and carefully prepared for. For example, bands sign on to give a fair 30-day warning if they have to drop off the festival, keeping us from losing financially. Another example is weather. The stages will all be raised and covered this year, with plenty of shelter available.

Safety is principle. Just for this reason, we have implemented a cost friendly camping area in order to refrain from drunk driving. We also have free shuttle service to and from the event. Along with these precautions, our countless hours of dedication has built up our teamwork skills to be solution-based and efficient, as prepared for the worst that could happen.


Other Ways You Can Help!

Spreading the word is always a huge way to help out! Whether it's by word of mouth, or your favorite social media site, you can always lend a helping hand by letting others know about Foothills Fest. Such actions have a boundless impact on the turnout of the festival.

If you are looking to get your business involved and would like to talk about sponsorship opportunities, or any other information, email us at foothillsfest@gmail.com

www.foothillsfestmo.com
www.facebook.com/foothillsfest

story:
Short Summary

My name is Kevin Donovan and I am a volunteer and advisory board member for an organization known as L.E.A.D., which stands for "Launch, Expose, Advise, Direct".  L.E.A.D. is a small but highly successful 501c3 organization that works closely with the Atlanta Public School System to develop the next generation of business and civic leaders through a set of programs that target inner city youth.  By applying the life lessons of baseball, we promote a set of core values that result in self-reliant, empowered and accountable high school graduates who are prepared for college and oriented toward future leadership.

L.E.A.D successfully launched their first "Live Big Dream Big" program this past spring.  Two exemplary young men were provided with an all expense paid trip to the Braves' spring training in Orlando, Florida.  The program showcased the young men's value as role models and will now inspire the other members of our high school and middle school programs to achieve the same goals and rewards.  In 2015, we would like to bring at least four of our youth to Spring Training and increase the promotional reach of this inspirational program.

Since we will be able to fund and promote these trips for less than the requested $25K, any additional funds that we are fortunate enough to receive will be dedicated to L.E.A.D. operations, specifically transportation, equipment, field maintenance, staffing and other high priority needs of the organization.

I have been with L.E.A.D. for five years now and I have seen its ability to transform these kids into strong and inspiring young adults.  Our founders, C.J. and Kelli Stewart, have managed to crack the code on what makes an effective youth-focused organization, and for that reason, a contribution to L.E.A.D. translates directly to a positive impact, not just for our kids, but for our entire community.

What We Need & What You Get

Our $25,000 will go to the following

  • The Live Big Dream Big Program, which will include flights, meals and hotels for four high performing L.E.A.D. members and their chaperones (parents), along with a videographer and the executive director of L.E.A.D.
  • Advance and post promotion of the program
  • L.E.A.D. operational needs - transportation, equipment, staffing and maintenance.

If we do not reach our goal, we will bring as many kids to Spring Training as we can afford.  Our hope is that we can grow the program and select more deserving young men each year.

The Impact

In addition to making the dreams of four young men come true, the Live Big Dream Big Program is a promotional vehicle for prospective sponsors and a funding mechanism to drive ongoing support and contributions to L.E.A.D.  The impact of L.E.A.D. is both measurable and astounding. Since 2008, the L.E.A.D "Ambassadors" have achieved the following:

  • 100% High School Graduation Rate
  • 100% College Enrollment Rate
  • 92% College Scholarship Rate
  • Thousands of Community Service Hours

The ability to direct our at-risk youth away from activities like gang affiliation and toward a path of long term success translates to positive long term financial benefits to the city and state.

Other Ways You Can Help

L.E.A.D. is always looking for volunteers in the Atlanta area, and we welcome any donations of baseball equipment or apparel for our kids.  Some day we hope to replicate the program in other cities and we are open to any support from individuals or organizations that share our values and commitment to our youth.  

Anyone who has had the pleasure of shaking the hands and receiving the thanks of our young men is forever changed.  Keep us in mind, and thank you for your support! - Kevin

story:
The Human Interaction Lab is requirement for acceptance into the HSI Masters Program and is just beyond my reach financially!  Any little bit you are willing/able to contribute would mean the world to me. Here is a link to the details of the Human Interaction Lab, the costs are listed under the "register online" tab:

http://chrcs.concordia.ca/programs/certificate_human.php

This Human Interaction Laboratory is a six-day (five night) residential program. Its unique experiential design consists of small and large group sessions whereby a semi-structured learning environment will assist you in developing your competencies in the following areas:

  • Increase your ability to understand yourself and others in the context of work/ task-focused relationships
  • Increase personal and task effectiveness in a diverse, multicultural environment
  • Enhance your understanding of group functioning and effectiveness
  • Enhance your understanding of your role in effective and productive groups
  • Demonstrate the capacity to give and receive feedback with care and accountability
  • Gain a deeper understanding of group development and group dynamics to achieve success
  • Open new paths of communication and personal insight
  • Increase your awareness of the impact you have on others and how others impact you
