story:
“I’m a firm believer in doing. Theory is great, but it doesn’t help students unless you put it into action. So I founded Yellow Wood with a vision—to provide an educational setting where young people can start discovering their real talents in a less stressful environment. No grading, no ranking, more thinking, less memorization, more guidance, fewer rules. A place where teens don’t just learn, they thrive.”                                                                    

                                                                                        ~ Judith Hurst, Founder

Let’s be honest—the traditional school model isn’t working for many young people.Yellow Wood Learning Community is different, and we’re making a difference. We’re a 501c(3) nonprofit organization designed to further the education and goals of 13- to 18-year-olds who want to learn and explore ideas in a setting other than the traditional school model.

Yellow Wood's founder, Judith Hurst, is a lifelong educator. During her many years of teaching, she encountered systemic challenges in both public and private schools—high-pressure standardized tests, lowest quartile stigmas, inflated grades. All that judgment. Yuck!

In the summer of 2012, Judith attended the Alternative Education Resource Organization (AERO) conference for the first time. At AERO, she found what she was looking for—fellow educators who were passionate about transforming education, and were taking action. Free schools, alternative schools, and thriving, successful models such a North Star Teens inspired her to begin Yellow Wood in her own community.

In addition to Yellow Wood’s full-time program, Judith's long-term vision includes workshops after school for all teens in the community. Tai Chi, Tango, Poetry … the sky's the limit!

A National Board Certified Educator (English), Judith holds a Master’s degree in Educational Psychology and is a lifelong learner. She oversees all aspects of the learning community, and facilitates classes in Literature, Writing, Poetry, Photography, Creative Commerce, and Philosophy.

Our 501c3 nonprofit education resource center is open Monday through Friday, offering classes, self-directed learning, tutoring, games, community meetings, and more.

One student may be in class studying literary allusions, while another is getting private SAT help. One morning, we may all be working together to design and paint an incredible mural. Afterward, several students might head to a local farm to volunteer, learning about animal husbandry and organic farming.

Each teen has an individualized schedule. While we offer traditional classes such as Geometry, French, Chemistry, and Writing, Yellow Wood also offers classes you wouldn't normally find in a traditional school, including Recon (a class where discarded materials are re-purposed and re-imagined into furniture and other objects) Skateboarding, Cosmetics, Special Effects, Raspberry Pi computer building and coding, and the Sociology of Animated Television Shows.

We don’t receive federal funding, and we don’t have pots of gold—we’ve looked!

Diversity and opportunity are extremely important to us, and we operate on a (sometimes frighteningly) tight budget so that we can open our doors to every eligible student. Many families can’t afford membership fees.

With sufficient funds, we’re also hoping to offer a summer program for all interested teens, making the Yellow Wood model of learning and exploration available to everyone, even students who attend traditional schools.

Your contributions support an organization that puts students first. Here’s some of what we do.

We offer:

·  An enriching environment for in-depth exploration of skills and ideas

•  A free and open space to make every student’s voice heard.

•  Weekly workshops led by a variety of professionals from the community, including the renowned Julia Perlowski's Macbeth Workshop, and the remarkable musician Richard Brookens' World Music demo day.

•  Drawing and painting classes where students learn about everything from elements of art such as textures, value, color, space to implementing these to caricature, tattoo art, and skateboard design.

•   Socratic dialogues about everything from applying Upton Sinclair's argument in The Jungle to today’s globalized and modern economy to asking what it means to be a young female in America

•    Our budding community arts program, which has painted abstract murals and dabbled in projects for Animal Hero Kids, an organization dedicated to using humane education tools to create more compassion and empathy toward all animals  

·  A mentoring program to ensure each student receives individualized guidance

·  Location Learning Trips—we’ve explored alternative healing at Thrive Alternative Medicine, studied Piotr Uklanski’s work at the Bass Museum of Art, and visited the Stonewall Museum after researching the history of the LGBT community

•   Project-Based Learning—so far, we’ve studied the architectural influences behind the sustainable Earthship buildings in a local Maker Space garden, designed and crafted for-sale products in our Creative Commerce class, and contributed to the Broward County Environmental Agency’s dune restoration project at John U. Lloyd Park

Your amazing contributions will help us to grow and do more of the above! Know that you contributed to an organization that really does put students first!

Visit our website to learn more of what we're all about: http://ywlc.org

Love our model of learning and want to help in other ways?

Like us, follow us, and totally stalk us! Visit our YWLC Facebook Page and stay up to speed on all of the amazing projects and trips at Yellow Wood!

Want to contribute your time and energy? At Yellow Wood, we value dedicated individuals' time too! We are currently accepting applications for volunteers.

If you have any questions about visiting, volunteering, or even joining our passionate, eclectic, and compassionate crew, please email Judith Hurst at JUDITH@YWLC.org or reach us via phone at 954-253-9563.

THANK YOU FOR HELPING US GROW!

believer in doing. Theory is great,
but it doesn’t help students unless you put it into action. So I founded Yellow
Wood with a vision—to provide an educational setting where young people can
start discovering their real talents
in a less stressful environment. No grading, no ranking, more thinking, less
memorization, more guidance, fewer rules. A place where teens don’t just learn,
they thrive.”                                                                                                                                                             ~ Judith Hurst, FounderLet’s be honest—the traditional
school model isn’t working for many young people.Yellow Wood Learning Community is
different, and we’re making a difference. We’re a 501c(3) nonprofit organization designed to further the education
and goals of 13- to 18-year-olds who want to learn and explore ideas in a
setting other than the traditional school model.
Yellow Wood's founder,
Judith Hurst, is a lifelong educator. During her many years of teaching,
she encountered systemic challenges in both public and private schools—high-pressure
standardized tests, lowest quartile stigmas, inflated grades. All that
judgment. Yuck! 

In the summer of 2012, Judith
attended the Alternative Education Resource Organization (AERO) conference for
the first time. At AERO, she found what she was looking for—fellow
educators who were passionate about transforming education, and were taking action. Free schools,
alternative schools, and thriving, successful models such a North Star Teens
inspired her to begin Yellow Wood in her own community.
In addition to Yellow Wood’s
full-time program, Judith's long-term vision includes workshops after school
for all teens in the community. Tai

story:
WINTER CAMPAIGN

1. Buy New Vehicles​

To better serve the children in the Yangon Province the purchase of a vehicle is necessary investment. This will allow them to purchase classroom necessaties and provide transportation for the children.

2. Finish Construction​

Currently the walls of the classroom are unfinished and still in the process of being built. This is necessary to protect the children and keep the rain out in the rainy season.

3. Level walkway to the school​​

The current walkway up to the school is very uneven, cracked, and floods during the rainy season which makes the school unaccesible. We want to expand and even the walkway.

4. Pay 2 teachers salaries​

In order for our students to recieve the best education we need the ability to hire more teachers. We are currently raising money for the salary of 2 more teachers to bring on staff.

story:
“Attending Lyra was one of the most inspirational, transformative, and exciting experiences I have ever had.  Playing music and being with some of the nicest, funniest students, and most supportive staff members changed how I felt about myself and my life.  What was even more amazing for me was the way my progress was appreciated. The excitement and encouragement of the staff helped me to enjoy playing and performing, because I felt conﬁdent instead of scared or unhappy with my playing. It was incredibly freeing to work hard, and then ﬁnd happiness in the result.”  --  Ella, Lyra scholarship student

Short Summary

In 2010, two old friends, both pianists, teachers, and graduates from Manhattan School of Music, got together for a friend's birthday and started talking about teaching piano.  We, Mary Prescott and Akiko Sasaki, discussed how we wanted to keep up the momentum of learning piano despite the busy schedules of our students, and wished that there was some way that we could work with them on a daily basis.  We wanted to show our students how much potential they truly possessed, and how much they could improve in a short time.  A lot more discussion and a day later, we started taking our first steps toward the Lyra Summer Music Workshop.

Now in our 6th season, the Lyra Summer Music Workshop has been operating in beautiful Randolph, VT, where string and piano students of any age or level come to immerse themselves in a supportive yet intensive conservatory-style music camp. Along with daily private lessons and chamber music coachings, Lyra rounds out the days with group classes, performances, and social recreation. We also host a concurrent festival of top-notch classical musicians, who give concerts at Lyra's home music hall, Chandler Center for the Arts; and who also work one-on-one with Lyra students in masterclasses open to the public.  Our incredible guest artists visit from such prestigious institutions as the NY Philharmonic, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, the Pacifica Quartet, and the MN Orchestra, to name just a few.

One of the hallmarks of Lyra is our incredibly low student:teacher ratio.  We have capped our enrollment at 5 students per teacher, so that everyone who attends receives a huge amount of individual attention and mentorship.  This is truly rare, indeed!  With such a close-knit group of students and staff, Lyra has been able to maintain a wonderful, nurturing environment that is supportive rather than competitive.  Our students learn not only their exceptional musical identities, but their personal ones as well.  

Many of our students come back year after year, and have often expressed how much they love and miss Lyra.  Some of our students have gone on to study at top music conservatories, while others make music a priority in their daily lives.  All of our students finish their final Lyra performance with a feeling of catharsis, accomplishment and renewal.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goals are to keep the high quality of our program, maintain our low student:teacher ratio, pay our faculty and artists fairly, and keep up with our expenses.  On top of that, we try to make Lyra possible to students from all economic backgrounds by giving scholarships to those with financial need. 

But running a non-profit that values quality over quantity does not come easily.  Aside from the obvious expenses, like faculty fees and room & board, we have facility fees, liability insurance, piano rentals & moving, administrative fees, and transportation, amongst many other ongoing costs that add up quickly!  We appreciate the immense support from friends, family, and music-lovers that we have received in the past; and we hope that you will join them in giving to Lyra Music!

In the fall of 2014, we proudly received our 501(c)3 non-profit tax-exempt status, which means that anything you donate to us will entitle you to a tax-deduction to the full extent of the law. That in and of itself is a great incentive to donate!

We also have many fun perks to choose from at all giving levels, including all-natural handmade lip balm created just for Lyra from Ondine&Gaspard, CDs from our good friends at The Harlem String Quartet (some of whom have been Lyra Guest Artists), exclusive Lyra t-shirts, and more!  For donations at higher levels, we are offering a chance to sponsor a full scholarship for a student with financial need, sponsor a distinguished Lyra Guest Artist, or even underwrite the 2016 Lyra Music Youth Competition!  No matter at what level you are able to give, your donation will make a lasting impact on the future of Lyra.

The Impact

When you decide to donate, you can feel confident that your gift will go toward a worthy music education organization that supports not only the future of classical music, but also kids' self-esteem, confidence and discipline.  Lyra is a celebration of how classical music can bring us together, understand and learn from one another, and teach us to give of ourselves for each other.

Other Ways You Can Help

We truly appreciate every gift that we receive, and we understand that even though you might not be able to make a financial contribution, you still want to help.  You can be a part of the cause by sharing our campaign with your friends, and letting them know that Lyra Music is worth their donation.  Please email our Indiegogo campaign to your friends and family, and share it on Facebook or Twitter.  Indiegogo has some great tools to help you do so.  Thank you for taking the time to help Lyra Music!

story:
A New Book

A book packed with games and exercises that will enable you to work on group dynamics in a practical way, while having fun and learning something about music.

In the Summer of 2014 Tine Fris and Kristoffer Fynbo Thorning from Postyr Project will publish their first book with Icebreakers and we need your support to help us make the book as perfect as possible.

The book will be published by Postyr Project and has been supported by funding from The Danish Arts Council and SYNG.

How Can You Help

We want to print the book with a really cool layout and with a bunch of explanatory and inspiring pictures to the many icebreakers.

We need your help to reach the 1000€ goal and on this page you can decide how much you want to help us by pre-buying our book.

This will affect how much promotion and marketing we can do and therefore make the book successful and get it to as many people as possible.

Your contribution will also make a big impact in the production costs: the more we print, the lower the per cost book is.

Since we're doing this apart from our 'normal' jobs as musicians and teachers, your help will enable us to speed up the process in finishing the book.

The illustrations are a crucial part of the educational part og this book and helps to describe the different games and exercises. With your support we can afford more illustrations and thereby enhance the books quality content.

We're gonna make the book no matter how much funding we get from you, but the finish and look of the book, how much the production will cost and how many illustrations we can afford, depend heavily on how many backers we get here on Indiegogo.

Icebreakers, what is it?

Icebreaker is an overall term for games and exercises that can be used to bring people of all ages together.

Through the icebreakers the participants share new experiences, which create a positive atmosphere, boost the feeling of fellowship and strengthen the social bonds in the group.

Furthermore, many icebreakers also include musical aspects, and can as such also be used as a means to work with musical pulse, sense of musical period, groove, imitation, improvisation, solo and group singing, body awareness, coordination, playfulness and creativity.

Get Involved

You can follow the development of the book here.

If you are curious to learn more about Postyr Project's music, sheet music and workshops you can find more info here www.postyrproject.com

If you don't need an Icebreaker book right now, you should help us spread the word by sharing this site on Facebook, Twitter or Google+. Just click the icons on this page. It would mean the world to us. Thanks!

story:
Why 3D Printers at the Elementary School?


Students’ learning is focused on rich tasks that activate and provoke their thinking by making, producing, designing, collaborating, analyzing and creating cross curricular connections to learning.


Embedding technology and its benefits in everyday learning has provided these opportunities for the students. Students using and designing with 3D printers could further enhance and give opportunities to apply knowledge and spark more  thinking with a purpose of designing. Many cross curricular possibilities like visual literacy to describe, to analyze and to explain how and why the  printed object could relate to experiences in Social Studies, Science and Math. Curriculum needs to integrate the thinking of coding, designing, scripting and making to apply and enhance learning skills in new experiences that will be the future of our students’ learning.


3D printing would unlock the creativity and let students experiment with challenges and collaborate by designing projects that could actually be real and be used for real purposes of promoting thinking.


Luc Lalande, who promotes interactive learning through 3D printing and who has been promoting these experiences to communities and schools around Ottawa,  will be able to support students’ and teachers’ learning.


"The most gratifying aspect of this maker space for me is seeing how many students are excited to learn, to push their limits, to collaborate with their peers, and it's extending well beyond the school day," Eric Sheninger,  principal New Milford High School



Students tinker with learning in the makerspace at New Milford High School in New Jersey. | New Milford High School

story:
Hawaii Appleseed is a non-profit organization affiliated with the Appleseed Network that advocates for systemic change to give Hawaii’s underprivileged residents the opportunities necessary to rise out of poverty. This year marks a decade of Hawaii Appleseed's advocacy, and we are running this campaign so that this important work can continue for years to come.

Hawaii is a tropical paradise that draws travelers from all over the world, thanks to its natural beauty and cultural richness. Yet the extremely high cost of living, combined with the relatively low wages paid in a tourism-based economy, conceals the struggles of its low-income communities. All too often, Hawaii’s families struggle to provide their children with quality nutrition, find affordable housing, and access health care.

Hawaii Appleseed receives generous support from its loyal donors, but we still critically need funding to finance our advocacy efforts to improve the lives of Hawaii's residents in need. 

    Our Goal and the Impact

    Hawaii Appleseed is seeking to raise $15,000 in order to continue our efforts to help families in Hawaii. 

    Much of the work we do—namely impact litigation and legislative advocacy on behalf of the poor—is rarely undertaken in Hawaii because of restrictions placed on organizations receiving governmental funding. Moreover, foundations will rarely support litigation or lobbying. 

    Hawaii Appleseed’s freedom to use the most effective tools available to zealously advocate for those in need comes at a price. Without traditional, stable sources of funding for our work, we must rely heavily on donations from individuals and businesses who believe in the importance of our work. 

    Your donations truly make a difference. Whatever amount you can give is magnified many times over by Hawaii Appleseed. Operating on a shoestring budget in partnership with many other nonprofits in the community, we serve as a catalyst for improving the lives of low-income and marginalized people in Hawaii. Hawaii Appleseed needs your support to continue our important work toward breaking generational cycles of poverty by ensuring that low-income families have access to safe and healthy homes, sufficient food, good schools, and meaningful opportunities for self-achievement and economic security.

    How We Help - Everyday

    Here’s a sampling of some of our recent accomplishments:

    Improving dangerous and unhealthy conditions in public housing 

    One of Hawaii Appleseed's recent cases resulted in the complete rehabilitation of the state's largest public housing project through the leveraging of $150 million in federal tax credits. Residents of Kuhio Park Terrace had suffered from atrocious conditions for years—fire hazards, frequent sewage backups, unsanitary trash disposal, vermin infestations, and chronically failing elevators that left disabled residents confined to their units or stuck for hours on the ground floor below. A similar case at the second largest project in the state is ongoing and has already resulted in significant repairs and upgrades.

    Ensuring that children and families do not go hungry  

    Hawaii Appleseed is partnering with schools to implement Breakfast in the Classroom, a proven model that gives low-income school children access to a healthy breakfast every school day. Countless studies have shown that eating breakfast supports academic achievement and improves children’s health and well-being. 

    Our advocacy has also helped ensure that families are able to access food stamps. Due to a backlog of applications, the State of Hawaii forced families to wait for months to get critically needed food assistance. Thanks to Hawaii Appleseed's work, families now receive their benefits in a timely manner, helping them avoid hunger.

    Providing access to education for homeless students

    Hawaii Appleseed protected the rights of students who were being forced out of their schools after they had became homeless, in violation of federal law, This advocacy ensured that hundreds of homeless K-12 students would avoid the significant educational setbacks and trauma associated with being displaced from their schools at the same time as they lost their homes. 

    Ensuring access to health care

    Hawaii Appleseed prevented the state from cutting critical health care services such as dialysis and chemotherapy for thousands of Micronesian migrants legally residing in Hawaii. Our 2010 lawsuit initially halted these cuts, but the litigation continues. We need ongoing support to continue Hawaii Appleseed's efforts to maintain access to life-sustaining medical care. 

      Recent News Stories

      Non-profit firm that helps others is in need themselves, Hawaii News Now, September 18, 2014.

      Kona Charter School Now Serving Universal Free Breakfast to Students, Honolulu Civil Beat, August 18, 2014

      Chasm widens between rent, median wages, Honolulu Star-Advertiser, August 2, 2014 (PDF)

      Foster parents raises' fail to stop lawsuit, Honolulu Star-Advertiser, July 30, 2014 (PDF)

      Isles Rate Medium for Kids, Honolulu Star-Advertiser, July 22, 2014 (PDF)

      Victor Geminiani Takes on One Social Cause After Another, Civil Beat, June 17, 2014

      Perks

      Check out more information about our awesome perks below! They include items that represent the artistry and vibrancy of Hawaii, as well as items that have been donated to our campaign. 

      $10 - Thank You Public Recognition
      This perk is a personal shout-out on our website sponsorship page saying that you helped keep our doors open. All of our funders that donate $10 or more will receive this perk. We are truly grateful for your support!

      $25 - Handwritten THANK YOU card!
      A handwritten card from Hawaii Appleseed staffers thanking you for your donation. All of our funders who donate $25 or more to our campaign will receive this perk. Thank you so much for your support!

      $30 - Red Hawaiian Sea Salt
      Red Hawaiian sea salt is used in Hawaiian dishes such as kalua pork, jerky, and more. It enhances the flavor of any dish that calls for traditional sea salt. This perk includes one 16 oz. bag.

      $35 - Breakfast at DC Restaurant - 3 -- SOLD 

      $50 - Maui Healing Soap
      This soap, made in small batches by an artisan in Maui, is made from creamy goats milk. The oils from this soap are believed to have healing and antiseptic qualities.

      $50 - Hawaiian Bead Necklace
      Want a beautiful Hawaiian necklace but haven't had the opportunity to visit Hawaii? Choose this perk and support our cause at the same time!


      $75 - Maui Gold Pineapples
      Biting into one of these extra sweet, low acid pineapples will make you feel like you are soaking up a cool evening in Maui, right from the comfort of your own home.

      $75 - Kona Coffee
      Hawaii's own Kona coffee makes some of the best coffee in the world! This perk includes one 7 oz. bag of Kona coffee for you to enjoy at your home or office.

      $75 - Car Service to/from San Francisco Airport
      Taking a trip to Hawaii (or anywhere else)? This perk is a voucher that gives you a ride to/from any city in the San Francisco Bay area to San Francisco International Airport, courtesy of Travel Limo. 

      $75 - Timbuk2 Messenger Bag or Backpack --SOLD

      $100 - Breakfast at DC Restaurant -1 --SOLD 

      $100 - T-Shirts from Quality Peoples

      Sport one of these ultra-soft, stylish shirts from Hawaii's hottest t-shirt shop, Quality Peoples. If you are interested in this perk, please contact us and we can provide you with images of the shirts we have available. (Men's large only.)

      $150 - Breakfast at DC Restaurant - 4 --SOLD

      $200 - Personalized Stationary (Set of 100)

      You can work with one of our designers to develop a set of 100 personalized stationary cards for yourself or your business. We will take care of all of the designing and printing for you.

      $200 - Stay at the Aqua Palms Waikiki Hotel

      Enjoy a two night stay at the Aqua Palms Waikiki hotel ! Please contact us for terms and conditions.

      $250 - Acacia Koa Box --SOLD


      $250 - Koa Wood Cufflinks

      These koa wood and tungsten cufflinks are made in Hawaii and will never scratch or dull. 


      $250 - Breakfast at DC Restaurant - 2 -- SOLD


      $500 (Reduced)$250 - Marketing Bootcamp

      Are you a small business or solo practitioner in need of marketing help? Sign up for this bootcamp donated by Mike Gluck, owner of Gluckworks, Inc. Mike is an award-winning writer with nearly 20 years of experience working with clients including the Cleveland Cavaliers, Comcast, Fisher-Price, and many more.

      $2000 $1000 (THIS WEEK ONLY)- Signed Landscape Print --SOLD


      Thank you so much for taking the time to read our story! 
      Please contact us if you'd like more information about our perks and their delivery dates.

      Our Campaign Team

      Our campaign team is made up of individuals from Hawaii Appleseed and Edgeworth Economics, an economics consulting firm headquartered in Washington, DC, that regularly works with Hawaii Appleseed and the Appleseed Network on a pro bono basis. Both Hawaii Appleseed and Edgeworth have put together this fundraising campaign, with 100% of donations going to Hawaii Appleseed.
story_txt:
Hawaii Appleseed is a non-profit organization affiliated
with the Appleseed Network that advocates for systemic change to give Hawaii’s
underprivileged residents the opportunities necessary to rise out of poverty. This year marks a decade of Hawaii Appleseed's advocacy, and we are running this campaign so that this important work can continue for years to come.


Hawaii is a tropical paradise that draws travelers from
all over the world, thanks to its natural beauty and cultural richness. Yet the
extremely high cost of living, combined with the relatively low wages paid in a
tourism-based economy, conceals the struggles of its low-income communities.
All too often, Hawaii’s families struggle to provide their children with
quality nutrition, find affordable housing, and access health care.
Hawaii Appleseed receives generous support from its loyal donors, but we still critically need funding to finance our advocacy efforts to
improve the lives of Hawaii's residents in need. 
  Our Goal and the Impact 
Hawaii Appleseed is seeking to raise $15,000 in order to continue our efforts to help families in Hawaii. 
Much of the
work we do—namely impact litigation and legislative advocacy on behalf
of the poor—is rarely undertaken in Hawaii because of restrictions placed on organizations receiving governmental funding. Moreover, foundations will rarely support litigation or lobbying. 
Hawaii Appleseed’s
freedom to use the most effective tools available to zealously advocate for
those in need comes at a price. Without traditional, stable sources of funding
for our work, we must rely heavily on donations from individuals and businesses who believe in the importance of our work. 
Your
donations truly make a difference. Whatever amount you can give is magnified
many times over by Hawaii Appleseed. Operating on a shoestring budget in partnership with many other nonprofits in the community, we serve as a catalyst for improving the lives of low-income and
marginalized people in Hawaii. Hawaii Appleseed needs your support to continue
our important work toward breaking generational cycles of poverty by ensuring
that low-income families have access to safe and healthy homes, sufficient
food, good schools, and meaningful opportunities for self-achievement and
economic security.
  How We Help - Everyday 
Here’s a sampling of some of our recent accomplishments:
Improving dangerous and unhealthy conditions in public housing 
One of Hawaii Appleseed's recent cases resulted in the complete rehabilitation of the state's largest public housing project through the
leveraging of $150 million in federal tax credits. Residents of Kuhio Park Terrace had suffered from atrocious conditions for years—fire hazards, frequent sewage
backups, unsanitary trash disposal, vermin infestations, and chronically
failing elevators that left disabled residents confined to their units or stuck
for hours on the ground floor below. A similar case at the second largest project in the state is ongoing and has already resulted in significant repairs and upgrades.
Ensuring that children and families do not go hungry  
Hawaii Appleseed is partnering with schools to implement Breakfast in the Classroom, a proven model that gives low-income school children access to a healthy breakfast every school day. Countless studies have shown that eating breakfast supports academic achievement and improves
children’s health and well-being. 
Our advocacy has also helped ensure that families are able to access food stamps. Due to a backlog of applications, the State of Hawaii forced families to wait for months to get critically needed food assistance. Thanks to Hawaii Appleseed's work, families now receive their benefits in a timely manner, helping them avoid hunger.
Providing access to education for homeless students

Hawaii Appleseed protected the rights of students who were being forced out of their schools after they had became homeless, in violation of federal law, This advocacy ensured that hundreds of homeless K-12 students would avoid the significant educational setbacks and trauma associated with being displaced from their schools at the same time as they lost their homes. 
Ensuring access to health care
Hawaii Appleseed prevented the state from cutting critical health care services such as dialysis and chemotherapy for thousands of Micronesian migrants legally residing in Hawaii. Our 2010 lawsuit initially halted these cuts, but the litigation continues. We need ongoing support to continue Hawaii Appleseed's efforts to maintain access to life-sustaining medical care.

Foster parents raises' fail to stop lawsuit, Honolulu Star-Advertiser, July 30, 2014 (PDF)
Isles Rate Medium for Kids, Honolulu Star-Advertiser, July 22, 2014 (PDF)
Victor Geminiani Takes on One Social Cause After Another, Civil Beat, June 17, 2014

story:
What is the Rainbow Conference?

Rainbow Conference is a cerebral conference geared toward four days of panels, workshops, discussions, and fun for QUILTBAG readers, authors, artists, and publishers. From April 17th, 2014 until April 20th, 2014, we'd like to gather 300 QUILTBAG attendees to dig into the meat of writing, creating, and consuming QUILTBAG fiction, non-fiction, art, and media! It's a wonderful opportunity to share and learn and grow in our artistic endeavors while helping others around us to learn and grow in their own.

QUILTBAG? What the heck is QUILTBAG?

It's an awesome acronym to describe what is historically called LGBT, but is so much more inclusive and welcoming. QULTBAG stands for Queer/Questioning, Undecided, Intersexed, Lesbian, Transsexual/Transgender, Bisexual, Asexual, and Gay/Genderqueer. It's a large umbrella term that includes all sexual and gender identifications, and it's the one we prefer to use.

Why Rainbow Conference?

We found that, within the QUILTBAG artistic community, there was a severe lacking of this sort of gathering. It was something we wanted to attend, but was never offered by others. So, in the spirit of jumping head first into shallow water, we founded the Rainbow Conference and hit the ground running! So far, there has been a wonderful response from our little corner of the literary world, but we'd love to see the Rainbow Conference's reach go further and touch more people.

Why is Rainbow Conference needed?

All professional communities need gatherings like Rainbow Conference to help mingle ideas and spark more creativity. The support Rainbow Conference will bring the QUILTBAG writing community is large, and we hope to put readers in touch with their favorite authors and artists, and authors and artists in touch with their favorite publishers. Furthermore, the need for an all inclusive event that encourages diversity and debate is intense, and we want to see that need met and exceeded by Rainbow Conference.

Rainbow Conference is not merely a convention. This is something contributors, attendees, vendors, and sponsors will help bring to the QUILTBAG community. With Rainbow Conference, we hope to benefit equality charities, foster more social awareness, encourage tolerance, and educate not only ourselves, but those who might only be distantly aware of the wide artistic talents of the straight and QUILTBAG creators of incredible art and literature.

✥✥✥

The cost of running a conference--even a small one like the Rainbow Conference--is large. While registration has helped put a dent in those costs, we find ourselves with a large gap between the amount we need and the amount we have raised thus far. Many people have expressed excitement for Rainbow Conference and what it could mean for the QUILTBAG art community, but the cost or timing is bad for them. This is why we've launched this campaign: folks who wanted to help make Rainbow Conference a success and guarantee a 2015 event can now contribute what they can afford and get some awesome things in return!

We have some awesome, fun stuff for contributors like glass pendants with the Rainbow Conference logo (decked out in colorful glitter), official conference T-shirts, a chance to ask the organizers anything you want, individually written fiction for you to enjoy, free face or body painting for attendees of the conference, and even general registrations with personal recognition at our Welcome Event. For those with deeper pockets, we've offered RainbowCon Bucks, vouchers you can use in our dealers room to buy merchandise you want so that all money goes into the QUILTBAG artistic community!

If we don't reach our goal, the money we have collected will still go into the conference, and we'll make every dollar contributors offer stretch.

If we exceed our goal, every contributor will be sent a personal thank you note from the organizers with a special gift sent along with our eternal gratitude.

✥✥✥

The world is in a state of flux right now, and while QUILTBAG rights have come a long way, there's still a lot of work to do. Equality is something everyone should be given, and it should never be based on how a person identifies. No one is less because of who they love, the body they have, or the body they want in order to feel whole. So much damage is done from within and without, and Rainbow Conference is trying to help combat that with our existence.

We have a young adult track that will welcome adolescents and teens to talk about what it is like to identify within the QUILTBAG, open up dialogue about media representations and bullying. Our writer track will debate and discuss the social benefits and drawbacks of being within the QUILTBAG community. We will expose prejudiced and try to help each other take a few steps forward in self-awareness and social advocacy.

Our charity for 2014 is Equality Florida, a non-profit group that helps fight for equality in Florida for QUILTBAG persons. They're a wonderful group of people who fight a hard war, and we'd like to help them win a few battles. We will hold a charity raffle over the conference's four days to raise money for Equality Florida. All money raised through the raffle will go to them; Rainbow Conference keeps none of it.

Rainbow Conference's goal is to educate, promote, support, and help QUILTBAG persons and allies in their artistic fields while advancing equality, tolerance, and diversity in the world, and with help from contributors like you, we think we can make one heck of a splash!

✥✥✥

With the global economy suffering like it is in so many ways, we understand that even $1 can sometimes be too much. It's all right! If you don't have the money to spare to help us along, then all we ask is you spread the word about Rainbow Conference and our campaign. Use social media or chat up your friends! IndieGoGo has some great sharing tools, making signal boosting quick and easy!

story:
MUSICIANSSUPPORT.ORG


Musicians Support is a new nonprofit charity for music education. Our organization raises funds for school and community music programs in the city of Los Angeles. We help provide the much needed resources that keeps music alive in our community.

Founders Marc Bernal and Devin Baird, are musicians who grew up in L.A. and have worked in music and entertainment for over a decade. The concept for Musicians Support came from a desire to provide a network platform for musicians, students and industry professionals to benefit the community by supporting school and community music programs.

This Startup campaign is to fund the necessary costs involved in establishing and promoting a 501 c3 nonprofit charity. Musicians Support is passionate about bringing the community together through music.

With your support we can:

  • Provide funds, instruments and equipment to schools in need.
  • Provide funding and support for community music programs.
  • Provide support and opportunity for music educators.
  • Provide free resources and opportunity to musicians and students.
  • Provide free music performances and events in our community.
  • Provide a platform for musicians and industry professionals to support school and community music programs.





Musicians Support needs $30,000 to fund our Startup.


Your support and donations will go to:

Musicians Support Startup will help us raise funds for the following three programs.


   Music Education program (code name Music 101)

     Support the Los Angeles Unified School District with funding and resources for music programs. When school budgets get squeezed as they often do, the music department is one of the first to get hit. Your donations help our schools receive the continued funding needed to provide quality education and inspiration to our music students.


   Music Center program (code name Hollyrock)

     Build a community music center in Hollywood California. The center would provide a safe, fun space for students and musicians. Music students will be encouraged to develop their talent after school in a proper rehearsal space.


The center would include a performance area, rehearsal rooms and a learning space for students. The center would also offer community education courses in the arts. Fun classes would be provided for parents and their children to explore music together. The performance space would be available on weekends for community events.

The center will be a perfect platform for industry professionals to provide free workshops, seminars and product training to students and musicians.


   Charity Network program (code name Harmony)

     Support and network with other nonprofit charities. There are many great opportunities for cooperation between organizations. Working together will help ensure success.




Sponsors will receive the following perks at various levels:



Help us reach our goal! Make a contribution today.

We believe your passion and support for music will ensure success. Should we fall short of our target, all funds raised will still play a vital part in supporting our cause. Thank you for your consideration.

Get involved. You can benefit the community by spreading the word on your favorite social sites! Use the Indiegogo.com social share tools. Please help get the word out.

Design and custom graphics for crowdfunding campaign provided by
Web Graphic Guy

story:
I am writing to ask for the opportunity to submit our project, outlined below and in our Proposal for Funding, for support by you or your organization. This is a most unusual and innovative undertaking, involving young men from at-risk neighborhoods in an educational enterprise to build their confidence, leadership skills, community involvement and educational progress.

Ukwaluka: South Africa 2013 Project, in its maiden year, plans to take 10 African-American, African, Caribbean, and Latino students in their senior year of high school to South Africa for approximately two weeks, to engage them in educational, community-based activities and give them in-depth exposure to South African culture, diversity and institutions. The purpose of this, as outlined in the Proposal, is to uplift and empower these young men, in the absence of appropriate male role models, and help them to develop the inner resources to advance their education and become socially responsible leaders.  The following are objectives for this project, addressed in great detail in the proposal:

  • Create equity among students. 
  • Improve college readiness and employment marketability. 
  • Mentor students in becoming global citizens who contribute to all communities. 
  • Enhance school culture and build incentives for current and prospective students. 
  • Establish partnerships with South African organizations such as Afrika Tikkum and Robben Island for ongoing program/opportunity. 

Included in this curriculum is a three-day public service project in the townships, an overnight stay and private tour of Robben Island prison, including meetings with past political prisoners, a trip to the African bush, as well as a seminar about the HIV epidemic in South Africa with a leading clinician.

Funding for the travel and lodging portion of this trip is our greatest priority, as well as building an endowment that will allow this project to continue and expand. A contribution from you will give us the jumpstart we need while we continue to implement a recently developed series of fundraisers. We believe that this program can make a significant difference for young men who right now find themselves limited by their neighborhoods and income from moving out into the world and expanding their horizons and contributions.

Here are some examples of what your donation can do:

$ 4,000 will fund the entire trip for one student
$ 2,000 will finance both the international and internal flight for one 
student.
$ 1,500 will finance all lodging and activities for one student.
$ 500 will finance all activities in Cape Town for one student
$ 100 will finance an overnight stay on Robben Island, the prison where 
Nelson Mandela was jailed for 18 years and private tour by an ex 
political prisoner.
$ 50 will pay for transportation to and from the townships where the 
students will spend four days engaged in social responsibility and 
leadership activities with young kids and students from 
poverty-stricken areas in South Africa.

We are close to reaching our goal!  With the help of many wonderful individuals and a major corporation, we need $7,000 more to make this powerful initiative a reality.

We believe that our program is consistent with your mission and vision and hope you will support this program. If I can provide additional information to encourage consideration of our request, please feel free to contact me at JBell6871@gmail.com or 347-389-0816. I would also be happy to personally meet with you or your committee to present this proposal.

 

Most Sincerely,                                                                                        


Jordana Bell   

Department Chair, History and Law  

Harry S Truman High School

750 Baychester Ave

Bronx, NY 10475                                                Funding Proposal Upon Request
story_txt:
I am writing to ask for the opportunity to submit our project, outlined below and in our Proposal for Funding, for support by you or your organization. This is a most unusual and innovative undertaking, involving young men from at-risk neighborhoods in an educational enterprise to build their confidence, leadership skills, community involvement and educational progress.
Ukwaluka: South Africa 2013 Project, in its maiden year, plans to take 10 African-American, African, Caribbean, and Latino students in their senior year of high school to South Africa for approximately two weeks, to engage them in educational, community-based activities and give them in-depth exposure to South African culture, diversity and institutions. The purpose of this, as outlined in the Proposal, is to uplift and empower these young men, in the absence of appropriate male role models, and help them to develop the inner resources to advance their education and become socially responsible leaders.  The following are objectives for this project, addressed in great detail in the proposal:


Create equity among students. 

Improve college readiness and employment marketability. 

Mentor students in becoming global citizens who contribute to all communities. 

Enhance school culture and build incentives for current and prospective students. 

Establish partnerships with South African organizations such as Afrika Tikkum and Robben Island for ongoing program/opportunity. 


Included in this curriculum is a three-day public service project in the townships, an overnight stay and private tour of Robben Island prison, including meetings with past political prisoners, a trip to the African bush, as well as a seminar about the HIV epidemic in South Africa with a leading clinician.
Funding for the travel and lodging portion of this trip is our greatest priority, as well as building an endowment that will allow this project to continue and expand. A contribution from you will give us the jumpstart we need while we continue to implement a recently developed series of fundraisers. We believe that this program can make a significant difference for young men who right now find themselves limited by their neighborhoods and income from moving out into the world and expanding their horizons and contributions.

reality.

story:
About the Alan R. Pearlman Foundation & ARPchives

My name is Dina Pearlman.  I'm the daughter of the late Alan R. Pearlman, inventor of ARP Synthesizers - groundbreaking electronic synthesizers that changed the face of music forever.

Why It's Important

Since the death of my father in January 2019, I have seen overwhelming evidence that there needs to be a thoroughly reexamined history of his work because his story and that of ARP Synthesizers is relevant to the history and  understanding of modern music.

Even more importantly, because of the high cost of education and vintage electronic music instruments, we want to offer opportunities for musicians, particularly young and underfunded musicians to have educational and artistic opportunities - something that Alan was passionate about. 

This is why the Alan R. Pearlman Foundation was formed - to honor his legacy as an inventor, a musician, an entrepreneur, an engineer and a mentor... to make his innovative inventions publicly accessible, and help inspire future generations to imagine and create through charitable projects.

 

Getting Started

Before we can start our projects, we need to get the word out about our Foundation and our Mission. 

Last January we were given an opportunity to introduce the Foundation to the music instrument industry at the hugely popular NAMM (National Association of Music Merchants) show  . You, the supporters of the Foundation helped us, the foundation board members to promote the Foundation, its mission and its charitable projects to electronic musicians, engineers, potential donors and the press. We had an extremely successful show and made hundreds of contacts as well as raise money and awareness for our projects.

News and New Activities

The Foundation is now a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization!

We received our status at the end of this past March! What a surprise in this year of unprecendented events.

Due to the worldwide pandemic, our major fundraising event was cancelled, and of course, like all of you, we did not attend the variety of trade shows that were originally scheduled for this year. 

Like everyone, we have adjusted our original projects to adapt to the current climate. We persevered with live streams,  videos and a well-attended ARP 2500 Webinar with opening remarks by Jean-Michel Jarre!

We have an exciting 2021 planned for you.

NEW PROGRAM! ARP Studio Living Collection: We are partnering with a non-profit recording studio to create a recording and creating ARP-centric studio environment. We have the space, and the beginning of a collection, and plan on launching next year.

NEW LEARNING: We are working on an exciting, never-before seen series of instructional videos, that will be released on a pay-as-you-can subscription.

Two New Webinars date TBA: The 2600 and a summit with Women in Synthesis

2020 Achievements: We have been hosting a series of online educational opportunities and live stream 'studio visits' called ARPchives LIVE!50th Anniversary of ARP Synthesizers Celebration: This  included a series of recordings, live streams, commemorative artifacts and most exciting: an ARP 2500 ROUND-TABLE

Subscribe  to our mailing list, ARPeggio, to keep up with news. 

How You Can Make a Difference

Though the Foundation is in its infancy, we are now a 501 (c)(3) not-for-profit. We are seeking funding to cover some of our costs to create online learning materials, purchase technology for our future online programs, marketing for the concert and scanning materials for the digital archives. 

We need help from people like you! Music lovers, synth lovers, creators and believers in perpetuating educational and creative opportunities.

 

What You Get

Besides knowing that you're helping our Foundation make a difference in the lives of, we have some goodies for you. 

(IMPORTANT NOTE: Don’t forget to pick your perk, shirt size and download if applicable! We do want to give back!)

NEW! 2021 Calendar!

ARP Stickers

3 ARP stickers commemorating the 50-year anniversary of the 2500!

 

 

Downloads

Music downloads from Lisa Bella Donna, David Baron and David Mash, a download of the remarkable synth documentary "Bright Sparks" - with accompanying album, and a Signature 2600 Patchbook by David Frederick Jr, part of the original ARP Family! (Includes vintage photos from the first NAMM shows!)

NEW: We have added a new perk! 

Drew Schlesinger and David Torn's CD: Summer Synthesis 1978 featuring the ARP Avatar!

 

Tees! New Styles!

A commemorative Tee celebrating the 50-year anniversary of the 2500, a v-neck with  the original Vintage Tonus ARP logo, and the all-time favorite, Vintage, now in summer colors!

 

Rare Vintage ARP Pin

A now-rare pin, originally given to dealers and distributors in the 1970's.

 

Risks & Challenges

This is our first year. We have much interest in our Mission, and the help of several organizations and companies,  but no funding to-date for offering scholarships, funding artistic programs or covering overhead expenditures. 

  • We have the interest of quite a few colleges and universities who would love to give more funding to their students.
  • We also have several recording facilities that would like to co-create opportunities to offer professional recording environments filled with vintage ARPs as well as state-of-the-art audio engineering. 
  • Our foundation and and advisory team includes experts in the fields of music education, and performance; technical expertise and marketing professionals. We have a winning group and are looking to expand this group even further next year.

 

Many Ways You Can Help

No amount is too small! We will accept all donations. If funding isn't an option, you can still contribute. Here's how you can help:

Get the word out !!! Tell your friends, share on social media. It's easy using IndieGogo share tools.

NOTE: Any funds raised above our goal will be used to further fund the Foundation and it's future projects.

Legal Stuff

* “The Alan R. Pearlman Foundation, Inc. is a New York not-for-profit corporation formed on June 14, 2019. 

Our application for tax exempt status under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code  has was approved by the Internal Revenue Service on March 30, 2020, and it valid retroactively!

All donations made to the Foundation since June 14, 2019 will qualify as a tax exempt charitable contribution.”

THANK YOU for Being a Part of The Alan R. Pearlman Foundation!

Executive Director,
The Alan R. Pearlman Foundation

Dina Pearlman

 

Acknowledgements and Kudos for this Fundraiser (so far).

Perk People Lisa Bella Donna, David Baron and David Mash,  Dave Spiers  "Bright Sparks" - David Frederick Jr  (Patchbook), Steve Horelink (Ask Video), Drew Schlesinger & David Torn  & Mary Lock!!!

Website, Video, Graphics and IndieGogo

Mark Marshall & Sharon Wasko 

General Advice, endless listening and ruminating....

The Board of Directors, The ARPostles, Don Slepian, Vince Pupillo Jr., Drew Raison, (EMEAPP) Phillip Charles, Lee Sebel, Michelle Moog-Koussa (Bob Moog Foundation), Lucy Swenson, Cynthia Delconte , Marc Doty, Mark Vail, Mark Wilcox, Tom Rhea, Drew Schlesinger, Brian Kehew and Alex Ball.

story:
UPDATE: I am officially going to Spain & I will be studying abroad summer 2013. A wonderful woman called me recently & told me that she believes in me enough to be one of my biggest supporters for this trip! She told me that she knew I would be somebody who will make a difference in the life of many. She brought me to tears. She believes in me & to me that means more than anything. She lent me $1200 for the rest of the airfare money I needed to make before the deadline. This woman would like to remain anonymous but out of everyone who could have helped me she was the last person I thought of.  Now I know this trip was meant to be. I have a contract with her to pay her back within 5 years but with help of my funders on here I hope to pay her back sooner. I am still in need to come up with at least $500 for the expenses I will have in Spain this summer.

Hi my name is Cecilia I'm a 26 year old single independent mom of a 7 year old son named Raul Jr. I am a proud single mom. I want to make this dream of mine to come true, I want to study abroad in Spain! Life is never easy & we all have our own struggles in our own ways, my struggle is a bit different I have a disease called Crohn's Disease & Ulcerative Colitis which both are debilitating at times. There is no cure for both disease. It's an auto immune system disease that affects the digestive tract. I like to live positive instead of negative even if I was given a life expectancy of age 45 years old.

I don't want my disabilities to stop me from living up to my potential. I want to be the best I can be! I was also recently diagnosed with Fibermyalgia which makes a lot of sense because I feel the crohnic pain everyday. I am a fight, please help me fight to live life to the fullest.My life consists of believing in myself & being the best I can be. I love life & I don’t take life for granite. I have made many mistakes & don't regret anything in life for every step I have taken has brought me to be the woman I am today. I try to live positive instead of negative! I treat other how I want to be treated & I am well mannered. I am confident in who I am & in my personality! I hold myself well & I am very professional when the time is needed to be.

I am a full time parent & a full time college student so life stays busy. I am raising my child the only way I know how alone. I am 2nd youngest of 12 siblings first generation college student & first generation in America. I am proud to be Mexican-American with the opportunities of going to college & being the best I can be. I want to make a difference in this world not for fame but for change! I grew up around gangs & violence which made me have the passion to go into Criminal Justice & Law. I am currently working on my AA- transfer degree & my International Studies Certificate in Spanish. I want to transfer to a 4 year university to obtain my Bachelor’s degree in Criminology, my Master of Public Administration & my PhD in Public Affairs. I want to work in juvenile probation as a probation officer or correctional officer after I get my Bachelor’s degree. I also want to get my law degree in immigration law. 

This campaign is important to me because I feel that this trip will benefit my career path in the future. Where is the best place to learn something? Spanish originated from Spain & I want to learn Spanish in Spain! The money I raise with this fundraiser will go to my expenses I have in Spain for 3 weeks.

I know this world needs people like me to stand up and make a difference! Not everyone has determination like I do to be the best I can be in this life. I want to change the way our youth grow up into adults we are there destiny, what we teach them now will affect them forever. I believe I am someone who can make a difference in many lives but I need to be well rounded & educated. I am currently working on that but I need to make my Spanish better & to do so this trip will help me prepare my life for my second language.

 

If you can't support me financially I ask if you can share my event with your family, friends, co-workers, neighbor's, colleagues and anyone who you think would be interested in hearing my story!

story:
Hello! We're so glad that you have come to our donation page to learn more about our goal to provide vitamin gummies and coolers to the underprivileged families in the slums of Philippines. My friend Matthew Wai and myself, Kyle DeGuzman, are UCLA college students and have been given a unique opportunity to use our summer for a greater purpose: a medical missions trip. Besides the fact that we are not supported by a larger medical organization, what really sets us apart is our unique opportunity to build strong personal relationships with the patients we will be serving, as well as the doctors serving alongside us. Even more so, this gives us the chance to continue a relationship with our patients even after our work is done, allowing them to update us on their personal circumstances and daily struggles. Still, we are only two college students-so we truly need all the help we can get! We would wholeheartedly appreciate any amount of donation, small or large! Thank you for listening to our vision for this upcoming summer!

What We Need

All money raised will be solely used to buy:

Vitamin gummies: Vitamin deficiency is the result of poor diet and malnourishment.

Coolers: Families do not have the resources to refreigerate which forces them to eat spoiled food. Providing coolers would prevent food poisoning and sickness.

We hope you can help us make the most out of this trip by supporting us through donations!

story:
What would you do if your child was transgender? Because you're looking at a transgender video project on Indiegogo, I'll assume it would probably be okay with you. You'd love him unconditionally and do your very best to help that child grow up to reach his highest potential.

Unfortunately that's not the norm. Many thousands of parents in America will part ways with their child when they discover that their child is transgender. If the child is too young yet to be abandoned, they mistreat and bully him into conforming unnaturally to the role of his outward gender. And this ultimately leads to years of frustration, confusion, pain and hopelessness for the transgender child.

What these parents don't understand is that being transgender is not "choosing to be a weirdo," as one parent put it, but a natural, biological occurrence - the phenomenon of a girl's brain, heart, and emotions born prisoner in a boy's body, or vice versa. But in America, especially rural America, and in many churches, transgender young people are literally demonized, run out of town, and in many cases, murdered or driven to commit suicide.

The lack of familial and communal acceptance is why 40% of transgender people don't make it to age 30. Transgender people are probably the most misunderstood and wrongly persecuted section of humanity in America.

The root of the problem is simple. It's misunderstanding. And what people don't understand, they fear, hate, shun and condemn.

My film Transgendervention will prevent parents from rejecting and ejecting their transgender children by bridging these gaps in understanding with upfront and in-depth medical, biological, and psychological information from doctors, scientists and therapists who specialize in the study and treatment of transgender people. This documentary will provide vital and current information especially for transgender youth and their families in the hopes that by illuminating and educating them, families will not turn their backs on their transgender children, but continue to love and support them, and have enough knowledge to be able to spread understanding, themselves.

Many transgender adolescents who may be in the position of "coming out" have a narrow and extremely critical window of opportunity to either win the understanding and acceptance of their families or lose those relationships forever. It is my goal, my mission, to provide a film that will explain to these parents what their child is experiencing and why and how these kids can grow up to lead happy and productive lives within a loving and supportive family, and not out on the street. It will be a way they can come out without getting kicked out.

Through interviews with doctors and experts, I will present the biological and physiological reasons why a transgender child may feel that they are "in the wrong body" and unable to conform to gender norms. I will present the importance and benefits of aiding transgender kids in their transition at an earlier age so that they can be who they are, and not have to suppress their self-identities throughout their young lives. My interviews will also provide ample, sound advice on bullying, social situations, personal safety considerations, religious opposition and transgender-specific legal issues.

Finally we will demonstrate that there has always been this "third sex" of people and briefly give some examples of societal acceptance and admiration of transgender people in other cultures.

This documentary will be a one-stop, best bet source of education for families starting on the path of transition, and will provide them with the resources, knowledge, and reassurance to continue loving and caring for their child.

It is my sincerest hope that this documentary will reach any misguided families of transgender children before they throw their children out of their homes like so many before them, and be a source of light and guidance for others who may have little or no access to the resources and information presented in this film.

Before its release, I will test this film on numerous conservative, uptight, backwards, prejudiced audiences to see if it can bridge the gap in their understanding of trans people as these will be its target demographics and the type of audiences on which it most needs to reach.

This is a monumentally important project. I just need your financial support to make it happen! 

Your money will go to fund travel expenses for my interviews of doctors, therapists, and experts in the field of gender dysphoria, and interviews of model families of transgender children. Your money will pay for production, equipment rental, studio time, editing, post-production, music scoring, and distribution costs. I also need funds to enter this documentary in film festivals, not necessarily to win them, but to let people know it is available to them.

The more funds I can raise, the better this film will be. So please, donate.

Additionally, Josh Lehrer, the amazing photographer who did the project "Becoming Visible: Portraits of Homeless Transgender Teens" has agreed to let me to use some of his beautiful and heart-rending photographs taken on the streets of NYC in presenting the statistics on transgender homelessness and mortality. Thank you, Josh!

Please support this project right now! Together, we can make a huge difference in the lives of transgender children.

And finally, please know that I am open to your suggestions. If you know something you think I should know, please msg me any time!

PLEASE SHARE THIS PROJECT WITH YOUR FRIENDS!
story_txt:
What would you do if your child was transgender? Because you're looking at a transgender video project on Indiegogo, I'll assume it would probably be okay with you. You'd love him unconditionally and do your very best to help that child grow up to reach his highest potential.
Unfortunately that's not the norm. Many thousands of parents in America will part ways with their child when they discover that their child is transgender. If the child is too young yet to be abandoned, they mistreat and bully him into conforming unnaturally to the role of his outward gender. And this ultimately leads to years of frustration, confusion, pain and hopelessness for the transgender child.
What these parents don't understand is that being transgender is not "choosing to be a weirdo," as one parent put it, but a natural, biological occurrence - the phenomenon of a girl's brain, heart, and emotions born prisoner in a boy's body, or vice versa. But in America, especially rural America, and in many churches, transgender young people are literally demonized, run out of town, and in many cases, murdered or driven to commit suicide.
The lack of familial and communal acceptance is why 40% of transgender people don't make it to age 30. Transgender people are probably the most misunderstood and wrongly persecuted section of humanity in America.
The root of the problem is simple. It's misunderstanding. And what people don't understand, they fear, hate, shun and condemn.
My film Transgendervention will prevent parents from rejecting and ejecting their transgender children by bridging these gaps in understanding with upfront and in-depth medical, biological, and psychological information from doctors, scientists and therapists who specialize in the study and treatment of transgender people. This documentary will provide vital and current information especially for transgender youth and their families in the hopes that by illuminating and educating them, families will not turn their backs on their transgender children, but continue to love and support them, and have enough knowledge to be able to spread understanding, themselves.
Many transgender adolescents who may be in the position of "coming out" have a narrow and extremely critical window of opportunity to either win the understanding and acceptance of their families or lose those relationships forever. It is my goal, my mission, to provide a film that will explain to these parents what their child is experiencing and why and how these kids can grow up to lead happy and productive lives within a loving and supportive family, and not out on the street. It will be a way they can come out without getting kicked out.
Through interviews with doctors and experts, I will present the biological and physiological reasons why a transgender child may feel that they are "in the wrong body" and unable to conform to gender norms. I will present the importance and benefits of aiding transgender kids in their transition at an earlier age so that they can be who they are, and not have to suppress their self-identities throughout their young lives. My interviews will also provide ample, sound advice on bullying, social situations, personal safety considerations, religious opposition and transgender-specific legal issues.
Finally we will demonstrate that there has always been this "third sex" of people and briefly give some examples of societal acceptance and admiration of transgender people in other cultures.
This documentary will be a one-stop, best bet source of education for families starting on the path of transition, and will provide them with the resources, knowledge, and reassurance to continue loving and caring for their child.
It is my sincerest hope that this documentary will reach any misguided families of transgender children before they throw their children out of their homes like so many before them, and be a source of light and guidance for others who may have little or no access to the resources and information presented in this film.
Before its release, I will test this film on numerous conservative, uptight, backwards, prejudiced audiences to see if it can bridge the gap in their understanding of trans people as these will be its target demographics and the type of audiences on which it most needs to reach.
This is a monumentally important project. I just need your financial support to make it happen! 
Your money will go to fund travel expenses for my interviews of doctors, therapists, and experts in the field of gender dysphoria, and interviews of model families of transgender children. Your money will pay for production, equipment rental, studio time, editing, post-production, music scoring, and distribution costs. I also need funds to enter this documentary in film festivals, not necessarily to win them, but to let people know it is available to them.
The more funds I can raise, the better this film will be. So please, donate.
Additionally, Josh Lehrer, the amazing photographer who did the project "Becoming Visible: Portraits of Homeless Transgender Teens" has agreed to let me to use some of his beautiful and heart-rending photographs taken on the streets of NYC in presenting the statistics on transgender homelessness and mortality. Thank you, Josh!

story:
About us

Muslim Association of Lehigh Valley is guided by a vision to preserve and perpetuate the Islamic heritage and uphold ethical and intellectual standards. The pursuit of this vision and gradual growth are among the main factors that have transformed our community from a small nucleus to over 500+ families.

The Muslim Association of the Lehigh Valley (MALV) was established in the early 1980s.  Our first home was a 1,500 square foot building in Emmaus, PA that provided worship space for about 100 community members. By 1990, we had outgrown this space and decided to build a new masjid in Whitehall, PA; a busy suburb located at the center of the Lehigh Valley region. Through the generous donations of the Islamic community and by the grace of Allah (SWT), we were able to construct our current home, a beautiful 14,000 square foot structure on over seven acres of land. Facilities include a prayer hall, full-time and weekend school, Islamic library, social hall, kitchen, and playground. We have a current membership of about 250 families and an average attendance of over 500 for Juma prayer. On Eid, we usually have close to 1,500 brothers and sisters offering their prayers at our masjid.

The Need

We have been blessed with tremendous growth in the past 5 years, thanks to Allah (SWT) and are committed to establishing Pennsylvania's finest islamic school and expanding our community center, so our children can develop into exemplary Muslim Americans. The completion of school expansion and community center project will provide an Islamic environment in which our children may flourish into healthy, intelligent, and valuable American citizens. 

The Project

The project is designed to be built in multiple phases and would provide facilities for additional classrooms and community center. The project would add 20,800 square feet of classroom space on two levels, next to the current school building, and would add a 8,200 square feet community center which will include a gymnasium, full-size basketball court, game/exercise room, school cafeteria, commercial kitchen and also serve as a multipurpose social hall for all community events.

  • 20,800 sq. ft. of school building & 8,200 sq. ft. of community center
  • 20 new classrooms with sizes varying from 475 sq. ft. to 550 sq. ft.
  • An art room, technology lab, science lab, nurses office, administrative
  • & principal’s office
  • A 845 sq. ft. library and game room in community center

The cost of the complete project is estimated to be $3.8 Million, we've till date raised about $1 Million from local community and now we need to reach out.  We had a groundbreaking ceremony on August 11th 2012 by Imam Sirraj Wahhaj and Ustadh Khalil Moore and our immediate goal is to raise $100,000 from outside our community to supplement our local efforts.

While our ambitions are lofty, we also recognize our inability to do this without help.  We first ask Allah to support us in this endeavor and ask you to help us in our hour of need.  Without this expansion, our students will have no recourse but to attend public school after fourth grade.  Every contribution, great or small, will have a share in the reward from the benefits offered from this institution.

The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: ' Whoever starts a good thing and is followed by others, will have his own reward and a reward equal to that of those who follow him, without it detracting from their reward in any way'.  Furthermore, Allah has also guaranteed a reward for those who sincerely give for His cause. "Those who spend their possessions (for the sake of God) by night and by day, secretly and openly, shall have their reward with their Sustainer; and no fear need they have, and neither shall they grieve."  (2:274)

How can you help us

You can help us realize our dream to have islamic school and community center.  

  • Contribute financially. No amount is too small in the sight of Allah.
  • Sponsor a classroom or laboratory in the name of an individual.
  • Give a Qarz-e-Hasan (Interest-free loan) to be repaid within 5-10 years.
  • Forward this request to friends and family.
  • Donations are Zakat-eligible and Tax Deductible.
  • Pray for the success of this project.
  • Share our IndieGoGo fundraising link with your social networks

Please consider a tax-deductable donation towards this project and we pray that Allah accept it as Sadaqah Jaariyah.

“Those who spend their possessions [for the sake of God] by night and by day, secretly and openly, shall have their reward with their Sustainer; and no fear need they have, and neither shall they grieve” [Quran 2:274]

story:
Would you like to give the voiceless a voice?


Are you tired of charity and want to be a part of something that empower people?


Give them their birthright to change their lives and at the same time many others.


Great People Media is a non-profit media foundation that plan to

start educating groups of people that are invisible in media unless as victims.


Help them to show their strength and creativity by contributing to our pilot project in Uganda and Kenya.


Professional journalists and photographers are educating poor

young people in one of the biggest slumarea in Africa,Nairobi Kenya.


We are also educating disabled Women in Uganda. They Will

become media workers producing inspirational stories from their

own country.


Stories will be sold to TV companies all over the world and the inspirational grassroot reporters will earn money from it. That means they will take themselves out of poverty and become an inspiration to family/friends and others.

We will also make a documentary about this project that will benefit more victimized people in the world.


Give the voiceless a change and become a part of changing the world.

All contributions are valuable. Thank you from our hearts.

story:
Short Summary or How two young girls are going againts the odds:

Hi! We are two girls that are just starting our own business with really limited financial resources (considering our country isn't pro entrepreneuship).

But, since we belive in our idea and don't want to give up on our dreams we are trying as hard as we can to do all the things that would help our business.

One of those things is the upcoming Pioneers Festival that is held in Vienna, Austria on 29th- 31st of October, 2012. - the biggest Start up conference of the year (http://pioneersfestival.com/).

What We Need & What You Get or How one click will help to girls actually go againts the odds:

We need 900 $ for our trip and Pioneers Festival fee. Although, it will mean a world to us to get the opportunity to connect with all the awsome start ups and others in PF, we aren't in the position to fund it ourselves. That's why we need your help!

If you have even a bit of something enterpreneurial in yourself, you know how we are feeling.

We will be more than grateful for any kind of your help and the perks are listed down bellow.

You are just one click away from making our dream come true, so what else are you waiting for?

THANK YOU! :))
