story:
Every day, time ticks indelibly further; the past recedes beyond living memory as an unknown future beckons.  And as we go forward we are not alone, as time etches its decay not only on individuals, but on cultures, their artefacts, and their histories.

 

Who I Am

 

My name is Erik Farrell, and I have a passion for fine art, history, and the preservation thereof. Beginning in October of 2012, I will be attending Durham University in England working towards a Master’s degree in Conservation of Archaeological and Museum Objects.

 

Archaeological and artifact conservation is a demanding field which requires skills in archaeology, history, fine arts, and chemistry all rolled together in a single, integrated package.  I have been admitted to a Global Top-100 university whose Archaeology program was ranked number 1 in the 2010 Times Guide, and I have the background to be successful. I have Summa Cum Laude BAs in Archaeology and Anthropology, have studied Organic and Inorganic chemistry at the university level, and have over a decade of experience working with fine art ceramics.

 

 

Why Conservation is Important

 

Every day we hear about the declining yield of natural resources, speculation of just how long before fossil fuels run out. There is, however, another decline, one which – like oil – cannot be rescued once destroyed. Our collective material-cultural heritage is decaying. Three times since 2010, a building or wall has collapsed in Pompeii, one of the world’s most famous archaeological sites. The Taj Mahal’s shimmering white marble is slowly yellowing from exposure to air pollution. Hundreds of thousands of artefacts from all over the world and all periods in time are improperly stored, have been poorly conserved in centuries past, or have never been consolidated to begin with, and these artefacts are decaying. There are not enough conservators to properly preserve the collective heritage of humanity, and I would like to help rectify that.

 

 

What I am Asking For, and What You Get

 

I am asking for assistance with expenses in my studies. I have received grants and loans which, along with my own savings and assistance from family members, will pay a great deal of my costs. Conservation, however, is an expensive career to pursue; I am still seeking funds to put towards transportation costs, lab fees and materials, and housing costs during required internship periods. Because of the rather intangible nature of what I am seeking assistance for, I am falling back on my ceramics background as a means of thanking donors.  Anyone who donates $50 will receive a coffee mug (pictured athttp://imgur.com/weheQ ). Donors giving $200 or more will receive a sgraffito decorated plate (http://imgur.com/9NdtT or http://imgur.com/IDzeE ), signed and numbered from a limited edition run, the design of which I will retire.  The first donor to give $750 will receive a large sgraffito plate (http://imgur.com/lyb2X ). All items which I am offering in thanks to donors are handmade and decorated by me. All pieces carry my personal stamp (used only on limited runs, gallery works, and items for my own personal use), and the plates are all individually signed as well.

 

 

Other Ways to Assist

 

As someone of limited means I know that not everyone can help financially, even with causes that they find merit in. Please, if you cannot afford to donate, spread the word; let your friends, family, and coworkers know. If you are unwilling to donate to assist with my own contribution to material-cultural heritage, but still wish to help preserve cultural resources, please consider donating to UNESCO’s World Heritage fund at http://whc.unesco.org/en/donation/.

story:
Who is Frank?

Frank is the perfect example of what happens when you take a chance on a kid. At 10 years old he was on the streets in Moshi, trying to find a way to better his life. By getting involved with a street kids center, he was able to get an education and a place to stay. One of the volunteers saw something in Frank and sponsored him to go to university where he got a degree in Tourism and Travel.
 
And he came back. He didn't go off to a better, more prosperous city. He came back to Moshi to give back to the community. His dream is to start a preliminary school for orphaned children and those living in poverty. We have secured the location and have started work on it, but in the meantime, Frank has no income. Every penny raised so far has gone back into the school.
 
I was lucky enough to meet Frank when I went to Tanzania on a volunteer trip. At the time, he was the "team leader" at the volunteer house which basically means babysitter to us volunteers who had no knowledge of the language, very little of the culture, and were used to things like hot water and consistent power. :) He was great and made sure we were taken care of. I've been in contact with Frank since I left and we have teamed up to get this school going. We will need about $50k and the doors will open in January! But until we have enough donations to pay staff, he's staying with friends and living on pennies. He's a very private man and would be terribly embarrassed and humbled that I set this fundraiser up- but if we are to get the school started, Frank needs to be able to survive while he's coordinating efforts.

What We Need

The minimum Frank needs to pay bills and eat would be $400/month for 6 months. That's where the goal of $2400 comes in. That is nothing to most of us, but to Frank, this will mean the difference of being able to focus on his dream full time or part time. If that goal is surpassed, we will not only increase Frank's wages to $500/month but anything over that will go to the school fund!  Painting, maintenance on the building, chairs, tables, toys, supplies.... you will have a hand in getting the school started!

The Impact

There is no free education in Tanzania. There are over 2 million orphans in Tanzania due to AIDS or malaria with 58% of the population living on less than $1/day. What will happen to them if they do not get a chance at a better life?  Many of Frank's peers who have the same story of poverty never made it to adulthood. Because someone took a chance on Frank, he will start a school that will help hundreds and hundreds of children living in poverty.  The school will impact the lives of 400 children living in poverty over 5 years as well as offer education on child development and advocacy to parents. Helping one man can change the lives of many.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help financially, please:

  • Send this to all of your friends!
  • Post this on your facebook page
  • If you have any connections with businesses that would like to donate toys, clothes, or computers, please leave a comment and I'll be in touch.
Are you still reading???? Fantastic! haha thank you.  A little bit goes a long way in Moshi. Please give what you can. It will certainly have an impact.

There are over 2 million orphans in Tanzania due to AIDS or malaria with 58% of the population living on less than $1/day. What will happen to them if they do not get a chance at a better life?  Many of Frank's peers who have the same story of poverty never made it to adulthood. Because someone took a chance on Frank, he will start a school that will help hundreds and hundreds of children living in poverty.  The school will impact the lives of 400 children living in poverty over 5 years as well as offer education on child development and advocacy to parents. Helping one man can change the lives of many. 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't help financially, please:

Send this to all of your friends!
Post this on your facebook page
If you have any connections with businesses that would like to donate toys, clothes, or computers, please leave a comment and I'll be in touch.

Are you still reading???? Fantastic! haha thank you.  A little bit goes a long way in Moshi. Please give what you can. It will certainly have an impact.

story:
What is The Butterfly Project?

15,000 children passed through Terezin Concentration Camp during the Holocaust, less than 100 survived.  The children of Wolf Performing Arts Center will honor the memory of these children through The Butterfly Project. Wolf Performing Arts Center, located in Wynnewood, PA, (near Philadelphia) is dedicated to enriching the lives of young people through learning, experiencing, and creating theatre.

During the 2012-13 season, The Butterfly Project will travel to schools, churches, synagogues, retirement communities and cultural centers throughout the Greater Philadelphia Area with a touring production of the play I Never Saw Another Butterfly.  Wolf PAC’s goal is to offer this project to the community FREE OF CHARGE. 

**The Butterfly Project successfully launched with five amazing performances at the National Museum of American Jewish History in April/May 2012, and has been invited to perform at the The Kimmel Center's Philadelphia International Festival of the Arts in April of 2013...

Our goal is to offer at least 40 free performances at various venues throughout the region, but we can't do it without your help!***

Wolf PAC’s primary aim with The Butterfly Project is to offer this universal message of hope and survival as a service to the community. The project includes the performance of Celeste Raspanti's play I Never Saw Another Butterfly by Wolf PAC’s young actors, talk-backs between cast members and audiences, post-show discussion with survivors and liberators, and the opportunity to create one of 15,000 hand-crafted butterflies being collected throughout the duration of the project.  Each butterfly will honor the memory of one child who passed through Terezin. The touring performances will be available FREE OF CHARGE. 

The Butterfly Project will honor the power of art, memory and children.  Through art, music, poetry, and live performance, the casts of children will bring the message of I Never Saw Another Butterfly to audiences throughout the Greater Philadelphia Area.   With your support,we can ensure The Butterfly Project will promote this universal message of hope and survival free of charge to thousands of audience members.

What We Need & What You Get

Wolf PAC is seeking $10,000 to support production and artistic expenses for I Never Saw Another Butterfly, the performance component of The Butterfly Project.  This sum will cover only a portion of the total budget for the project;  Wolf PAC is working to ensure funds from other sources in order to reach the necessary $88,000 overall budget goal.

The production and artistic expenses include stipends for the artistic and production staff, as well as the cost of rent, costumes, set pieces, props, sound equipment, and the anticipated up-keep that will be necessary over the course of a 5 month tour.

Meeting this initial $10,000 goal will mean we will have a production ready to travel throughout the region, and we will not have to sell tickets to audiences.

Please take a moment to look over the perks we are offering on the right in return for your generous donation, and know that you will be making a huge difference in the lives of the tens of thousands who will be able to attend these performances thanks to your generosity.

The Impact

The Butterfly Project will be educational theatre at its best.  Young actors will serve as teachers of history sharing the powerful message of hope and survival through art, poetry, music and live performance.  This project will bring to light important lessons about diversity, the strength of the human heart and the healing power of art.  

As the survivors dwindle and those who deny the Holocaust gain a platform, it is essential for our entire community to learn, remember and truly understand the importance of “Never Again.”  By supporting The Butterfly Project we can ensure that our children will promote this universal message and be the witnesses for the next generation. 

The Butterfly Project launched with a special premiere production in Philadelphia on April 19th at the National Museum of American Jewish History on Holocaust Remembrance Day 2012, followed by four additional performances which were offered free of charge at NMAJH. These inaugural performances alone already reached over 1000 people. Wolf PAC reached the fundraising goal needed to launch this project by tapping into Wolf PAC board members, parents, and local supporters.  It is time to reach out to a broader community in order to reach an overall fundraising goal that is almost 3-times the funds needed for the premiere.  Success through IndieGoGo will make a significant dent in this major fundraising effort.  We exceeded our initial fundraising goals to premiere the project, and we know we can at least meet our next goal, especially with a successful IndieGoGo campaign.

Please Help Us Reach Our Goal!

Whether your contribution is one thousand dollars or one penny, every single effort will help us reach our goal so we may reach out to our entire community, and, we hope, beyond.  If you believe in this project and take action today, The Butterfly Project can spread its wings.  Do you believe in Butterflies?

story:
My Story

Hi All! As some of you know and others not, I am a member of a group of young innovators called Sandbox. Sandbox looks to bring together the best and brightest innovators under 30 years old to solve the worlds problems and create a family that supports and educates each other. This year, Sandbox is bringing together our community for a 3 day Summit in Lisbon, Portugal full of classes, speakers, working sessions, and problem solving. It is sure to be an amazing and enlightening trip where we will laugh, cry, grow, and develop life long friendships (and drink a bit).

The Impact

This is a really big opportunity for me. 

Sandbox started in 2008 and is now the foremost global community of extraordinary young achievers below 30. It brings together young people worldwide that already have an impressive impact at a very young age, no matter in what field or industry. The growing community counts 600 young leaders in 48 different countries. Over the past 2 years, Sandbox has organized over 300 local and regional events in more than 18 cities in the US, in Europe, in Africa and in Asia.

For the first time now, Sandbox is organizing an event that will bring together its members on a global scale in one physical location â€“ the Sandbox Global Summit. On January 20-22, 2012, Sandboxers from all over the world will come together in Lisbon, Portugal and turn the city into the melting pot of the most innovative thinking, fresh ideas, and the full passion and energy of Generation Y. Imagine the possibilities. Key issues faced by Sandboxers and the world will be questioned, analyzed, and brainstormed, and solutions will be put into action. Lifetime friendships will be forged.

The Summit will have a concrete outcome as well: the Sandbox Playbook. Sandboxers may come from very different backgrounds and be engaged in different fields, but they have one thing in common: they donâ€™t play by the rules, but rather try to change them. Some of them have already done so, others have a vision of how to make it happen. In Lisbon and on giant paper, the rules that Sandboxers live and act by, the rules that change the game, will be captured. With so many young changemakers finally coming together in one place, it is a critical moment to bring these rules forward and capture them for others to share as well. The final creation will be edited into a hardcopy that will live beyond the event so that other leaders and multipliers can also benefit and apply the rules to generate new ideas, propel their ventures forward and drive impact on a global scale.

What We Need & What You Get

As you may guessed, flights to Lisbon are not cheap and the EURO IS A PAIN IN THE BUTT. CHECK OUT MY BUDGET BELOW:


$700: Flight to Lisbon

$500: Summit Ticket

$200: Accommodations while there

$100: Ground Travel


Other Ways You Can Help

I realize you may not be able to help with cash, but odds are if you are a friend or family of mine you have a HUGE MOUTH AND EVEN BIGGER HEART! Share this page with friends, please!

story:
Short Summary

Dr. Kelly has dedicated her life to help students succeed in school. She would like to give other parents the joy of attending their child's high school graduation as well as equip more disadvantaged children with the knowledge and skills needed to lead successful and productive lives. Dr. Shirley Kelly holds five degrees including a Master of Education and a doctorate in Educational Psychology. She holds membership in the American Psychological Association and the International Reading Association. She has taught at the post-secondary and elementary levels. She knows the difficulties that minority, low income, and disabled students face in obtaining an education and has designed a program to help at-rsk students succeed in school. Let us work together to abate the dropout epidemic among disadvantaged students in American and Canadian public schools.

What We Need & What You Get

Funds are needed to train and provide mentoring opportunities for high-achieving university and high school students. Mentors will support the learning needs of struggling high school students. Mentors will help mentees develop strong reading, writing, and learning skills. We will also provide students with opportunities to visit sites with guardian escorts to develop their families knowledge about American & Canadian History and Government, Science and Nature, Culture, Industry, and Community. Your donation can be as low as $1. There is no maximum amount for donations. Our projected budgetary expenses follow:
 
   Projected Monthly Budgetary    
    Expenses      
           

 

Mentor Salaries (1 university & 1 high school Student)
 
$  1,000.00 
Office Supplies (Stationery, stamps etc)    $     100.00
Guardian Escorted trips  $     300.00
Miscellaneous Expenses      $     100.00
Total Monthly expenses      $  1,500.00
           
Program Expenses (October 1, 2012 - June 30, 2013)  $12,000.00

The Impact

In the short term, we will show students and their families that we care, provide them with hope, and offer part-time job opportunities for students. In the long term, we will help reduce high school drop out rates, crime rates, strengthen the economy, and lessen the need for expensive social programs. Hence, more government monies can be redirected to stimulating the economy in terms of job creation via the development of infrastructures, new technologies, and related industries.

story:
~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~**~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*

"When I stand before God at the end of my life, I would hope that I would not have a single bit of talent left, and could say, "I used everything you gave me."

 

Hi There,

My name is Tiffany T. Smith, and I am a college student currently studying Acting at The Theatre School at DePaul University. Since I was a little girl it has always been my  dream to flourish into a well-rounded and disciplined artist by fully implementing and cultivating my Acting, Singing and Dance gifts. 

I am thrilled to say that I’ve been given an amazing opportunity to make that dream come true! I  was recently accepted into CAP21's Summer Professional Musical Theatre Training Program, to be held in New York this June - August. CAP21's Summer Professional Musical Theatre Training Program is a 6-week intensive program designed to develop the skills needed to become a well-balanced performer in all disciplines of musical theatre. I will be trained in courses such as Acting/Scene Study, Musical Scene Study, Vocal Performance, Vocal Technique, Dance (jazz/theatre dance, tap, and ballet), Music Theory, Audition Technique, and Business of Theatre. 

Unfortunately, my current financial obligations for college do not allow me  to support my full entry into this program. That’s where you all come in, #TEAMTIFFANY Woot Woot :):) It will mean the world to me if you support the development of my Artistry by donating to my campaign today! Your assistance will mean the world to me, not just financially, but emotionally. It is every artist deepest desire to know that they have a group of supporters that believe in their Dream so much that they’ll do whatever they can to help secure their success. Will YOU be the blessing that this young emerging artist needs to secure a successful fundraiser?

What I Need & Where It's Going

  • The remaining Tuition- $2,030
  • Housing- $1,200
  • Round Trip from Chicago to New York-Approximately $375
  • Out of pocket expenses for 6 weeks (Dance Attire, Subway Fare, Meals/Groceries, Toiletries,etc)- $450

       TOTAL: $4,055

Every dollar makes a tremendous difference!!! Should I raise more money than my goal, the extra money will go directly towards helping me survive in an expensive place like New York without an income for 2 months.

Be sure to check out the perks on the right for helping my out guys! =) >>>>>>>>>>>

Other Ways You Can Help

If you wish to contribute in other ways, your help is still greatly appreciated!

Please spread the word to friends and family

~Keep me in your Prayers

~Like & Share on your Facebook/Twitter Pages, Google+

~Use the Indiegogo share tools

*FYI The sharing tools just below my campaign video make speading the word easy! :):)

 

I am beyond excited to have been chosen to train at CAP21's Summer Professional Musical Theatre Training Program in New York this summer!!! Thank you all very much for being apart of this journey with me♥♥♥

CHEERS,
Tiffany T. Smith

story:
Short Summary

Hello!

My name is April Buddin and I am over Youth & program ministries at my church.

I have a group of kids that are very passionate about Christ and want to serve for Him and learn more about Him. These kids have to earn what we call youth points all year to be able to attend this Mission/Retreat. We have had several fund raisers and the kids have been working hard for this opportunity to serve God and learn more about Him. We are a little short for our trip and are going the idiegogo route as our final fund raiser for thuis trip!

What We Need & What You Get

We need about $2000 more to be able to go on this trip

The total trip is $8000 and we have fundraised by having a taco lunch, talent show where the youth served the tables for tips, we had a casserole sale, and a car wash. These kids have been working hard!!

What this money specifically goes for:

Each kid to receive Christian programming from Lake Junaluska for 4 days

A full day of serving the community of Asheville NC and the surrounding areas.

(Focus on helping homeless people and feeding hungry people)

Food and lodging, and a half day trip of rafting for recreation!

& travel to and from Lake Junaluska

The Impact

You will be helping Youth show God's love, learn more about God and help hungry and homeless people in the area.

Other Ways You Can Help

If your not able to donate money, we glady take prayers for our retreat, mission, and what God is doing in the lives of our Youth and al other people. We also challenge you to help hungry people & homeless people in your area. Thank you for any contribution small, big, ALL!

story:
Our Story

For the last nine years,  the London Teenage Poetry SLAM project has provided an annual exchange program for deserving and underprivileged young poets.  Chicagoan poets, educators and students opened their arms to those London poets, and over seven days of workshops, visits to local schools, performances and late-night conversations, we've built an international poetry community.  The week is often seen as life changing. 


One British poet described the exchange in Chicago: "That week I experienced how powerful poetry is; how it can bring all kinds of people together in the most unexpected places. I went out a new and nervous writer, and came back a poet."

 

This year, for the Olympic year and 10th year of this powerful collaborative experience,  we want to make it happen again with a twist by having the Chicago area poets go London. Weâ€™re aiming to send four young poets ages 18-24 and one chaperone across the Atlantic for a week of writing, learning, teaching and international exchange.

 

Volunteers will be donating their time to make this happen, and poets and teachers will be welcoming us in their homes to keep costs to a minimum. However, to ensure the trip happens, we need to cover the cost of the airfare.  


The Poets

The poets were selected from the applications from a highly competitive pool of Oak Park and River Forest alumnus. All of the poets participated in the Spoken Word club, led by Peter Kahn, during their tenure at OPRFHS.  They also were members of the elite Slam Team, which competes in the world's largest youth poetry slam, Louder than a Bomb. Meet them here:

Novana Venerable is a senior at Smith College graduating in May of 2012 with a degree in Psychology and in Spanish Language and Literature. She was able to compete in the national poetry competition, Brave New Voices, her sophomore year in high school and has since been featured in the documentary Louder Than A Bomb. As a subject of the film, Novana has traveled to a wide variety of cities, including Toronto and Palm Springs, to teach writing workshops to high school children in hopes of starting new poetry clubs and slam competitions. Novana has inspired many youth to write and perform poetry and is hoping to be able to coach a Spoken Word Club of her own after college.


Tabitha Watson is a senior at Boston University who will be graduating in May with a Bachelor of Science in Journalism, and a Bachelor of Arts in Political Science with a minor in Spanish. She was a Gwendolyn Brooks Poetry Competition finalist and has recently been published in the Boston Globe.

Asia Calcagno is attending Connecticut College on a full-tuition leadership scholarship from the Posse Foundation. She is currently a sophomore majoring in English with a concentration in creative writing and is receiving her certification in secondary education. Asia was a dedicated member of her high schoolâ€™s spoken word club for three years and was extremely excited to continue her performing and writing in college. She is currently the Vice President of a thriving and popular spoken word/poetry club on her college campus where she runs writing and performance workshops weekly. Asia has competed in Brave New Voices poetry festival as a member of the Illinois All Star team. Along with a close friend on campus, Asia has recently started an after school spoken word/poetry club at the Science and Technology Magnet School in New London, CT to provide a writing community for the high school students.

Kyndall Jones, currently a senior at Oak Park River Forest High School has performed in seven showcases appearing before crowds in excess of 350 people. She has been a captain of her performance group for six showcases. She has performed for her entire school of nearly 3,200 during the annual Martin Luther King assembly. This year she is a part Oak Parkâ€™s Louder Than A Bomb Slam Team (The largest youth poetry slam in the country). Kyndall has helped lead poetry workshops at The University of Illinois-Chicago in 2011 and 2012. She also helped lead a workshop at Urban Prep High School in Chicago. Kyndall Jones has participated in writing workshops lead by Terrance Hayes (National Book Awards Winner), Roger Bonair-Agard (National Poetry Slam Champion) and Marty McConnell (Def Poetry Jam). 


Ms. Jessica Stovall is an English and Reading teacher at Oak Park and River Forest High School. She has hosted London Teenage Poetry slam poets and their poet coaches for the last five years, and has attended almost every OPRF Spoken Word showcase and Louder than a Bomb competition since she moved to Chicago in 2007.  She has also been a judge for the National Spoken Word competition, Brave New Voices.  Although an amateur poet herself, she is inspired by the deep impact the spoken word has had on herself and her beloveds.  After finishing her graduate thesis at Northwestern University early this summer, she feels that this opportunity will be a hug to her soul.


The Impact


Nova says, â€œI am excited to be able to work in a new location. Culture has a big influence in the way people write. Style, content, sentiment and importance are framed by the way a nation functions. I am interested in writing from the view point of others and shaping a story from a perspective that may not always be heard or listened to. The opportunity to go to another country, to learn another culture and to gain a point of view that is different from the one Americans seem to find themselves stuck without change will give me a new idea of how writing can connect people from all different backgrounds and how to incorporate another culture and these foreign experiences into my own perspective in order to life a better quality life.â€


Tabitha says, â€œIâ€™m a traveler. I love to meet new people and experience new cultures. This love helps me to not only grow as a person, but also as a writer. It gives me new perspectives to write from, and insight into stories that I have never heard before. Traveling challenges and stretches me outside of my boundaries. It makes me uncomfortable, and yet a stronger person. This trip to London will allow me to go to a different place and meet others who, like myself, are travelers. Iâ€™m just excited to write memories on napkins or etch stories on my hand so that I could remember the experience forever. I want to write in a place where my story will be too inspired to become bland.â€

Asia says, "My inspiration as a writer is culture, but what inspires me to write are differences. I have never been outside of the country, and by exposing myself to an atmosphere different than what I am familiar with, I am sure that my writing will grow far outside of its comfort zone. I am anxious to come face to face with a different culture, dialogue, location and atmosphere while I grow relationships that last a lifetime. As a writer, it is important to me expose myself to differences for the rest of my life because it is easy for a writer to fall into the â€œI know everything alreadyâ€ mind-set. It is important for me to constantly expose myself to writers of different cultures and continue learning and challenging myself and my art. By this trip, education, challenge, exposure and development will be wrapped into one. I am hoping that my writing is pushed to the edge and I will finally be ready to finish my first chap-book of poetry by the end of the trip."

Kyndall says, "In my three years as an OPRFHS Spoken Word member, my most challenging experience came as a senior. I was given the leadership of a group that consisted of all rookies and a girl with autism. I had to learn to adjust to the personal needs of someone who has a learning disability, and handling those needs while paying attention to the rest of the group. By showcase time, we had bonded as a group and we were able to put on an amazing performance. Through that experience I learned discipline and patience. Since joining Spoken Word, Iâ€™ve been exposed to a diverse group of students. This has allowed me to develop leadership skills that will assist me in my future and the different experiences of my peers have made me a stronger writer. This trip will impact me because it will expose to me a writing Iâ€™ve never experienced, and new people who will push my leadership ability. I am very excited to grow even more as a writer and as a leader. Going to London will give me the chance to understand new cultures and share my own, broadening my connections through poetry. What I look forward to most from this trip is fostering new relationships in London that will help me develop as a writer and leader. I have never left the United States and look forward to gaining a broader perspective about the world."


What We Need & What You Get

Help us fly!  Any money made beyond the $6,000 will go towards food and transportation in London.  Your donation means a lot to us, and we will personally thank you for helping us on this dream experience.  


Other Ways You Can Help

It's not just about the funding, it's also about spreading the word. Let your friends know! Tell the world you support us by posting on Facebook, e-mailing, and telling the person sitting next to you on the bus. We appreciate your support!


In addition, e-mail us at 2012LondonExchange@gmail.com if you have any questions, comments, or ideas.  


Thank you so much for getting involved!
story_txt:
Our Story

For the last nine years,  the London Teenage Poetry SLAM project has provided an annual exchange program for deserving and underprivileged young poets.  Chicagoan poets, educators and students opened their arms to those London poets, and over seven days of workshops, visits to local schools, performances and late-night conversations, we've built an international poetry community.  The week is often seen as life changing. 

One British poet described the exchange in Chicago: "That week I experienced how powerful poetry is; how it can bring all kinds of people together in the most unexpected places. I went out a new and nervous writer, and came back a poet."
 
This year, for the Olympic year and 10th year of this powerful collaborative experience,  we want to make it happen again with a twist by having the Chicago area poets go London. Weâ€™re aiming to send four young poets ages 18-24 and one chaperone across the Atlantic for a week of writing, learning, teaching and international exchange.
 
Volunteers will be donating their time to make this happen, and poets and teachers will be welcoming us in their homes to keep costs to a minimum. However, to ensure the trip happens, we need to cover the cost of the airfare.  


The Poets
The poets were selected from the applications from a highly competitive pool of Oak Park and River Forest alumnus. All of the poets participated in the Spoken Word club, led by Peter Kahn, during their tenure at OPRFHS.  They also were members of the elite Slam Team, which competes in the world's largest youth poetry slam, Louder than a Bomb. Meet them here:


Novana Venerable is a senior at Smith College graduating in May of 2012 with a degree in Psychology and in Spanish Language and Literature. She was able to compete in the national poetry competition, Brave New Voices, her sophomore year in high school and has since been featured in the documentary Louder Than A Bomb. As a subject of the film, Novana has traveled to a wide variety of cities, including Toronto and Palm Springs, to teach writing workshops to high school children in hopes of starting new poetry clubs and slam competitions. Novana has inspired many youth to write and perform poetry and is hoping to be able to coach a Spoken Word Club of her own after college.

Tabitha Watson is a senior at Boston University who will be graduating in May with a Bachelor of Science in Journalism, and a Bachelor of Arts in Political Science with a minor in Spanish. She was a Gwendolyn Brooks Poetry Competition finalist and has recently been published in the Boston Globe.


Asia Calcagno is attending Connecticut College on a full-tuition leadership scholarship from the Posse Foundation. She is currently a sophomore majoring in English with a concentration in creative writing and is receiving her certification in secondary education. story:
Eight years ago, a beautiful spirit, Carrie L. Williams, left this earth from breast cancer.  She was a mother, a sister, a friend and so much more.  Carrie L. Williams devoted her life to being a blessing to others through her family, her church and anyone who knew her.  She was an avid believer in educating young minds and it is my mission that her death will not be in vain.  It is my hope that with your support she will continue to bless others through this scholarship fund. 

 It is with great pleasure that I invite you to join me in supporting The Carrie L. Williams Pink Scholarship.  This $1000 scholarship is designed to aid a minority high school senior who is interested in becoming a business major in college.  This scholarship will be presented to one student who has excelled in their high school and community alike.  The Carrie L. Williams Pink Scholarship will be awarded in April 2014.  We all realize that secondary education can be very costly.  With that in mind, we know that we are blessed so that we can be a blessing to others.  This scholarship will aid in a deserving young person’s preparation to fulfilling his/her dreams.  It will also make a difference in the life of a new generation of leaders. 

 To contribute to this worthy cause is simple.  Any donation will be accepted and greatly appreciated.  However, we are asking to be a sponsor you donate $100.  These gracious benefactors will get a Carrie L. Williams Pink Scholarship T-Shirt with your name proudly displayed on the back. 

 

If you need any additional information or have questions, please contact me at juliagreen24@yahoo.com or by telephone at 706 513 4310.

 

On behalf of Carrie L. Williams, I look forward to hearing from you.  Again, thank you for your support and believing as I do that “a mind is a terrible thing to waste”.

 

With warm regards,

 

Julia Green , Chair                                      

Tijwanna Ketter, Co-Chair

story:
I am a Belgian student called Maxime. I am 20 years old and I am currently studying at ICHEC Brussels Management School. I am doing a bachelor’s degree in Business Administration. 

The Housing Project is a project that has existed for over 20 years in this Business School. It is a development project in 3 countries namely India, Burkina Faso and Benin that takes place every year in July. The idea of this project is to provide participants with a life experience that allows them to have an insight into another culture. Taking part in this project will help participants understand what developing countries (southern countries) have to face every day. 

By choosing to become a part of the development project, we are also asked to participate financially and physically. For instance, reforestation sites in the region of Abomey in Benin, building homes for families in poverty and building classes for disabled children in India, construction of water reservoirs in order to provide water access in Burkina Faso. 

ICHEC works with several local partners such as the ONG SEVAI in India, the ONG ASMADE and the ASBL GEFED in Burkina Faso, the ONG ALPIDE and RAJES in Benin. 

The Housing Project has objectives and impacts in the short and long term. It will make us better managers that are capable to face challenges. We become open-minded and are able to work in teams in a new environment. It will also make us better world citizen, aware of the realities happening between North and South. 

In order to carry out this project, ICHEC asks its participants to be engage financially. An essential dimension of the Housing Project is the full funding by participants. To achieve that goal, we need to individually collect the amount of 1,700 euros (used to cover the costs of travel and accommodation + donation to our local partners). Moreover, we will have to raise 1,000 euros per team that will go to our local partners. 

I will be grateful for any help you can give.

story:
Hafa adai from Creative Indeed on the beautiful island of Guam! 

My name is Michelle Pier, and I am the organizer of the annual Luna Festival, through my business Creative Indeed. I am an artist with a passion for ALL the creative arts (and sciences) on Guam, striving to promote the value and sustainability of our local talent, organizations and small business entrepreneurs as much as possible. The Luna Festival was inspired by this passion. 


The Luna Festival is a creative arts celebration with a Guam style woven into the festivities. My goal is to keep the event free to the public by fundraising enough moola to pay for all the event logistics (including but not limited to: marketing and advertising, production and media, hiring for DJ, MC, event crew, canopies/chairs/tables, supplies & equipment, etc.). 

This year my goal is to give stipends to ALL creative talent who step forward and showcase their creativity, most of whom volunteer their gifts to the show. This aspect is going to depend entirely on the amount of funds raised. The more funds raised, the higher the stipend amounts. I really want to demonstrate the value of our creative artists by paying all who participate, even if they are enthusiastic about volunteering. 


This fundraising effort is specifically to be able to give stipends to all participating creative talent at the Luna Festival. $2000 will be able to pay 5-10 talent showcases a creative stipend between $50-$200 (depending whether individual or group). 

YOUR support, even in the smallest amount, will make a HUGE difference in the overall outcome of this important event for Guam. Si Yu'us ma'ase for all support you've shown for the Luna Festival! 

Have an amazing day! THANK YOU!
Official LUNA FESTIVAL event page: http://creativeindeed.net/events/annual-luna-festival-of-creative-arts/
LUNA FESTIVAL on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/events/1473455182965513/

story:
This is Khalil Reidah from the Gaza Strip, a volunteer activist who spends much of his time helping impoverished children and families. And there are many of those in Gaza. 

In the last Israeli offensive on Gaza last year, over 2200 Palestinians died, including over 500 children. Thousands of families were made homeless, their houses reduced to rubble and dust by the jets and tanks of the Israeli army. Death and destruction had also been inflicted on a massive scale in 2009 and 2012, and the people of Gaza had been given little chance to recover before the next round of devastation.

Life in Gaza is difficult not only because so much has been destroyed, but also because the blockade imposed by Israel all but prevents reconstruction and chokes the economy. Fishermen are shot at by gunboats before they can approach the areas several miles out where the best catches are to be had, building supplies are not let in, few exports are let out, and people are only granted exits, if at all, after laborious and unnecessarily complicated bureaucratic procedures that take months and often fail for no valid reason. In short, the people of Gaza are prevented from living normal, free lives and have to struggle for the simplest things. 

But even among those who are suffering, there are people like Khalil who want to help their fellow Gazans - especially the most vulnerable, namely children. He collects donations and helps families by getting essentials such as food, clothes or school supplies for them. One can sometimes be wary of donating to charities because one's unsure if the money really reaches the people on the ground who need it, but thanks to Khalil, anyone can help directly. As both a gesture of thanks and a way of showing how the money has been used, Khalil always prints a poster and takes a picture displaying exactly what he did with the donation. As a result, he has gained the trust of a number of people who know that he does exactly what he says he will. 

So if you would like to help Khalil continue helping the needy in Gaza, please donate to this campaign. You can be sure that all money will be dealt with in a trustworthy way and used to help directly.

story:
Finding More than I Ever Imagined

Three months ago, I quit my job and moved to Argentina with my boyfriend, Jimi. It was scary and exhilarating; I had no idea what to expect. My boyfriend's parents lived in the city of Tucumán and we planned to use their home as "home base" for our travels. Initially, Tucumán was little more than a free place to stay and some delicious homemade meals.

But then something changed all that. Marlene, Jimi's mom, started a program seven years ago called "Children at Risk" (or "Centro Integral de Ayuda A La Familia y Los Niños") that works with children in a really poor part of the city. One Tuesday evening, she invited me to come along with her to help. After spending an hour crossing the city by bus, we arrived at a local church facility and I helped the other volunteers set up tables and prepare snacks.

At 6 o'clock a van pulled up and the kids flooded out. Dozens of children raced towards us, hugging the volunteers. Some even came up and politely kissed me on the cheek. The next two hours flew by as we played with the kids and helped them with their homework. I was surprised by how far I could stretch my elementary Spanish when it came to basic math and spelling!

For three months, I have had the pleasure of returning time and again to help with these children. They have completely captured my heart with their smiles and hugs. The stories I hear about their living conditions at home feel like punches in the stomach. Many don't have running water or roofs on their houses. One girl recently suffered a broken arm at the hand of her mother. Several of the older boys have dropped out of school. These kids fall through the cracks in the system in Argentina, where the government does a lot for children who are orphaned or disabled, but very little for those who have parents (regardless of the level of poverty, abuse, or addiction).


A New Hope

The church that hosts "Children at Risk" recently donated a plot of land and some money to begin building a facility for the kids. It is a huge blessing, as Marlene has been working with these families for nearly a decade. She quickly brought in a construction crew and was able to build a classroom in less than two months.

It is amazing for the kids to finally have a space of their own. Unfortunately, the nearest bathrooms are in the main church building-- a good city block away. They also do not have access to a kitchen, which limits the type of snacks they can provide for the kids. Marlene hopes to raise enough money to begin the process of expanding the room and providing more facilities.

Where You Come In

We are hoping to raise $5,000 in order to construct bathroom and kitchen facilities. All donations to this campaign will go directly towards that building project. Any excess funds will be used towards other expansions and amenities, including books, tables, and chairs.

We want you to know how important your donation is to these kids. If you donate $25 or more, we will send you a handwritten thank-you note from one of the children. You are making a huge difference by providing them with a safe place to learn and grow. The more time they are able to spend in this facility, the less time they are spending on the streets.

This is a really unique way to spread joy around the world during this holiday season. Please, spread the word about Children at Risk!


{Note: I will be receiving the funds from this campaign and giving them directly to Marlene during my stay in Argentina. If you are interested in donating, but would prefer to send money through a non-profit organization for tax purposes, please donate to the "Children at Risk" fund at WorldVenture: https://www.worldventure.com/give/select.php?id...}

Finding More than I Ever Imagined


Three months ago, I quit my job and moved to Argentina with my boyfriend, Jimi. It was scary and exhilarating; I had no idea what to expect. My boyfriend's parents lived in the city of Tucumán and we planned to use their home as "home base" for our travels. Initially, Tucumán was little more than a free place to stay and some delicious homemade meals. 
But then something changed all that. Marlene, Jimi's mom, started a program seven years ago called "Children at Risk" (or "Centro Integral de Ayuda A La Familia y Los Niños") that works with children in a really poor part of the city. One Tuesday evening, she invited me to come along with her to help. After spending an hour crossing the city by bus, we arrived at a local church facility and I helped the other volunteers set up tables and prepare snacks. 
At 6 o'clock a van pulled up and the kids flooded out. Dozens of children raced towards us, hugging the volunteers. Some even came up and politely kissed me on the cheek. The next two hours flew by as we played with the kids and helped them with their homework. I was surprised by how far I could stretch my elementary Spanish when it came to basic math and spelling! 
For three months, I have had the pleasure of returning time and again to help with these children. They have completely captured my heart with their smiles and hugs. The stories I hear about their living conditions at home feel like punches in the stomach. Many don't have running water or roofs on their houses. One girl recently suffered a broken arm at the hand of her mother. Several of the older boys have dropped out of school. These kids fall through the cracks in the system in Argentina, where the government does a lot for children who are orphaned or disabled, but very little for those who have parents (regardless of the level of poverty, abuse, or addiction). 


A New Hope
The church that hosts "Children at Risk" recently donated a plot of land and some money to begin building a facility for the kids. It is a huge blessing, as Marlene has been working with these families for nearly a decade. She quickly brought in a construction crew and was able to build a classroom in less than two months. It is amazing for the kids to finally have a space of their own. Unfortunately, the nearest bathrooms are in the main church building-- a good city block away. They also do not have access to a kitchen, which limits the type of snacks they can provide for the kids. Marlene hopes to raise enough money to begin the process of expanding the room and providing more facilities.
  Where You Come In
 We are hoping to raise $5,000 in order to construct bathroom and kitchen facilities. All donations to this campaign will go directly towards that building project. Any excess funds will be used towards other expansions and amenities, including books, tables, and chairs. We want you to know how important your donation is to these kids. If you donate $25 or more, we will send you a handwritten thank-you note from one of the children. You are making a huge difference by providing them with a safe place to learn and grow. The more time they are able to spend in this facility, the less time they are spending on the streets. This is a really unique way to spread joy around the world during this holiday season. Please, spread the word about Children at Risk!
{Note: I will be receiving the funds from this campaign and giving them directly to Marlene during my stay in Argentina. If you are interested in donating, but would prefer to send money through a non-profit organization for tax purposes, please donate to the "Children at Risk" fund at WorldVenture: https://www.worldventure.com/give/select.php?id...}

story:
Short Summary

 Thank You for considering my campaign!  As an Uber Partner Driver and in celebration of Women's History Month Uber has collaborated with Indiegogo to  contribute seed money to support drivers and our communities!

                                                        

  1. What if you could help someone experience a life changing moment?
  2. What if you could help someone turn a hobby into a business in 30 days?
  3. What if these occurrence's could happen in 30 days?
                                                     Would you help?
Well you can!  I'm Lateefah Camacho the chef Owner of Divas Dessert Bar.com
I too made this same decision to make my life more functional by  turning something I loved into profit within 30 days, seven  years ago.
I attended Culinary School to learn all the skills and training to advance my goals.
I learned business production and management through New Venture Training sponsored by SBDC California.
Applying my skills and business knowledge to open my first business in just 30 days!
You see, it's very important for women in my community to have a sense of self worth while raising their families. I live in a hobby community where it can be difficult for one to get the information and the guidance needed to turn their hobby into financial independence!  I have this skill set and I'm excited to share it!


Here's How You Can Help

My goal for this campaign is to reach $5000. This amount will allow me to cover  4 city locations  and  help women of any age to jumpstart or revive an existing business.

Simply make a contribution based on one of the three levels and you will receive the perk!  

Contributions are gifted at  3 easy levels.

Contribution | Support | Investment

The funds will  be allocated in the following way.

  • Expense paid Workshop  $1,166.00 each city.
  • Workshop binder with custom follow along worksheets
  • Rented Conference facility
  • Refreshments
  • 4 hours of onsite hands on training.
If I  achieve half my goal I will conference in one city with the same stated breakdown.
If I achieve less than 1 city the money raised will be saved until I raise money for one city conference goal.
     

The Impact

This information as you may know, can be a huge investment for home based business. Trust me I've paid for it!  The benefit of knowing someone somewhere can now live a life a bit more functional is amazing  on its own.

My success in following my 30 day business plan has been phenomenal.

When I got my first phone call for a purchase I didn't know what to expect. I had the confidence  and ability to complete my order. It seemed as if all the questions and the guessing came into play. After successfully completing my order I knew I couldn't  go on being a ball of nerves with every order. I decided to put  systems into place. Every order will begin and end in the same way.

 Learning from my own do's and Screaming this is my Last order! will be very beneficial to others who are starting the same way. As business leaders it's imperative to have a mentor we can learn from and just as important for us to give back into the community.

 After hosting the conference the community can keep in touch throughout their business building by way of Twitter, Facebook and Snapchat and Periscope for Q&A sessions. Knowing that someone is there for you to see you through is a big reward and builds confidence for success.

Other Ways You Can Help

 If you can't contribute to one of the campaign levels. I want to thank you for taking the time to read my story! Can you please share my interest on your social media pages this is a great way to contribute to the campaign as well!

story:
The Educational Theatre Association

Last summer, my Thespian Troupe 7444 was honored with the chance to represent Rhode Island at the International Thespian Festival. So, I'm giving back to this amazing organization that has helped so many young people since 1929!
The Educational Theatre Association (EdTA) is a national nonprofit organization with approximately 90,000 student and professional members. EdTA’s mission is shaping lives through theatre education by: honoring student achievement in theatre and enriching their theatre education experience; supporting teachers by providing professional development, networking opportunities, resources, and recognition; and influencing public opinion that theatre education is essential and builds life skills.


EdTA operates the International Thespian Society (ITS), an honorary organization that has inducted more than two million theatre students since its founding in 1929. EdTA also publishes Dramatics, a monthly magazine for high school theatre students, and Teaching Theatre, a quarterly journal for theatre education professionals.
Visit them at schooltheatre.org

The 40 Project

For a year starting September 1, 2014, I'm launching a funding campaign every 40 days. Nine organizations that mean something to me personally will benefit

MissionThe 40 Project is a charitable organization that creates and promotes fundraising campaigns for the time span between September 1, 2014 and September 1, 2015. Nine organizations with intrinsic personal connection to Jason Robert LeClair will benefit from this venture.

Description

On September 1, 2014, I am launching the first of 9 fundraising campaigns. Why the 40 project? I am turning 40 on September 1. For that year I want to give back. Every 40 days of my 40th year, I will be trying to raise at least $1,000 funds for nine causes that mean something to me. 

The nine fundraisers will be run through Indiegogo. All funds will be paid directly to the organizations. The organizations are as follows:


9/1/14 - 10/10/14 - Rhode Island Stage Ensemble
10/11/14 - 11/19/14 - Walk for Life
11/20/14 - 12/29/14 - Beacon Charter High School for the Arts
12/30/14 - 2/7/15 - Educational Theatre Association
2/8/15 - 3/19/15 - National Art Educators Foundation
3/20/15 - 4/28/15 - Polycystic Kidney Disease Foundation
4/29/15 - 6/8/15 - ASPCA
6/9/15 - 7/19/15 - The Haitian Project
7/20/15 - 8/29/15 - St. Thomas Food Pantry

Thank you for your support of these amazing organizations trying to better our world in so many ways!

story:
The Campaign

As the only Jesuit university with a commercial real estate major, Marquette’s Center for Real Estate provides the commercial real estate industry with innovative, effective and ethical decision-makers through a world-class student experience rooted in applied learning, quality research and community outreach.

One of the hallmarks of the Marquette real estate program is our commitment to a “classroom without walls.” The Center for Real Estate takes nearly 100 students on conference trips, career day events, case competitions and site visits each year.  These experiences aren’t merely educational – they also give students a decided career advantage.

Today, we need your help with one of these foundational student experiences - student travel to the NAIOP, Urban Land Institute (ULI), and International Council of Shopping Centers (ICSC) conferences.  To send a student to one of these three conference costs $700. Our goal is to fully fund one of these trips - $7,000 for ten students.

The conference experience is truly unique. Our students are able to take the lessons they learn from the classroom and interact with industry professionals on a substantive level.

Class Competition

In addition to our goal of sending our students, we will also be tracking alumni participation rate for each graduating class. The class with the highest participation rate (# of donors / # of real estate alumni) will win bragging rights for the year! Last year, the Class of 2012 won with 9 alumni donors (41% participation!). Help your class win by making a gift today!

How You Can Help!

  1. Donate!- The campaign ends on Saturday, March 14, so please make your gift today.
  2. Share the campaign– use the Indiegogo share tools above to easily share with your friends and family.
  3. Track our progress– please check back here for updates on our progress as well as the class giving competition.

Questions?

Please contact Nina Schuerman at nina.schuerman@marquette.edu.

story:
A Computer For An Indigenous Police Force In Mexico

Dear Everyone,

I am writing to ask for help in procuring a laptop computer for the organizers of a very important social movement in Mexico.

Last Fall I worked with and wrote about a fascinating organization in Guerrero, Mexico, called La Policia Comunitaria. They are an indigenous, autonomous police force and justice system that arose out of an utter absence of any sort of state-sponsored security. They base themselves on indigenous ideas of law and justice, and they try to, instead of ostracizing people who are convicted of a crime, involve them in community service and "re-education."

Their system is not perfect, but it is an important movement and a beacon of inspiration in a region of Mexico that is riven with violence. Indeed, in the areas of La Policia Comunitaria's influence, there is almost no crime anymore, especially compared with the surrounding locales.

You can read more about them here, in an article I wrote:

http://upsidedownworld.org/main/mexico-archives...

And here is their (La Policia Comunitaria's) own website:

http://www.policiacomunitaria.org/

And here, from Left Turn magazine (in Spainish):

http://www.leftturn.org/la-polic%C3%AD-comunita...

While I was in La Costa Chica, as the region of the Policia is called, one of the founders and a current adviser to the group, Cirino Placido, asked if I could help them by procuring a laptop computer, one that they could use when they travel between the different towns in the region of the Policia Comunitaria. They don't care if it is a Macintosh or a PC, only that it can run a word-processing program and access the internet with a wireless connection. I am looking to raise funds here to buy a machine for them which I or another person will hand deliver to Cirino.

If anyone can help with this, I and they (La Policia) would be most grateful.

What They Need:


A laptop computer. As mentioned, it can be PC or Macintosh, with internet abilitiy. They will mainly be using it to update their website and write reports on their projects for the media. The people who make up La Policia Comunitaria are also involved in numerous other struggles, like the fight against a proposed gold mine in their region.

If you have any questions, of any kind, about this project or La Policia Comunitaria, or anything under the sun, please don't hesitate to write me.

moleverde@gmail.com

Best wishes,

David Martinez

story:
I recently went on a humanitarian trip to Thailand with an organization called Blue Star of Hope, that serves to bring Thai teens and people from all over the world to Thailand and to explore the amazing culture there. College seemed like a great idea for a while, but nothing felt more sure when I arrived in Thailand that I had to go back.
I am an 18 year old high school student, awaiting departure, and ready to do my part outside of my hometown to bring people together through music and education. I plan to stay in Thailand for 1 year to begin this journey, so I will need money for airfare, food, and various expenses, such as toilet paper, soap, etc. While there I will stay at Thapsakaewittaya High School in the Prachuap Khiri Khan Province to teach English, then at a monk's temple in the Prajuabkirikhan Province to teach English as well, and earn about meditation and Buddhism.
The duration of my stay is contingent upon how much money I raise, so all donations are greatly appreciated. Especially in Thailand, the American dollar goes a long way, and no donation could be too small. There is no price that can be put on the education of eager children.

story:
First and foremost, I want to introduce myself and give you a little background information. My name is Deva Watson and I am the founding and lead art teacher at at a charter school in the Philadelphia area. I went to the High School for Creative and Performing Arts, received my BA in film from Temple University, and my MAT in art education from University of The Arts. I recently just finished my AmeriCorps year of service where I served as a learning support co-teacher and art enrichment teacher. Throughout finishing my master's degree and AmeriCorps service, I have worked at Pub and Kitchen/The Diving Horse, with full support from GM Ed Hackett and Chef Johnathan Adams, as a server working 80 hour work weeks, in order to pay for art supplies for my students. I am from Northeast Philadelphia and currently living in Fishtown with my three roommates (all working artists) and my dog, Lenin. 
 
Education wasn't the field I envisioned myself being in. It became important over a period of time when I was freelancing as a film editor. I kept hearing how schools were cutting art programs in Philadelphia public schools, yet suburban schools were maintaining theirs for the most part. I wasn't happy editing reality tv, so I decided to got back to school and get my master's in education. I remember loving my teachers at CAPA because I got to do art 4 periods a day, learned editing foundational work, and even won a UPenn prize for a short film that I made there. At UArts, I honed my craft of creating lesson plans, classroom management, etc. I, unlike my peers, wanted to create lessons that were in depth, thought provoking, and not making art for art sake. While student teaching, I got 75 broken skate decks from Bustin longboards in NY for my 8th graders and did a graffiti art project based on working artists Banksy and Shepard Fairey. At my high school student teaching placement, I had my students create lino cuts/ prints based on areas of conflict. Students had to research Palestine, Holocaust, etc, create prints that represented those areas of struggle, and comment on those places/history in artist statements. I wanted students through the art classroom to become global citizens and begin to understand its complexities. You will see this work through all the videos and images I posted.
 
Currently, my school and principal are trying to make something really amazing for my future students. We deceided to seek a modern, sustainable design company that would build an art classroom pro-bono. Greensaw loved the project and came on board. We have taken measurements, had various design meetings, and finally finalized on our design plan to the school's leadership board.
 
Update:
 
Phase I:
The school itself was suppose to make an initial investment into building the art classroom. We just got word we lost money from state funding, meaning the school can not put up the initial $6,000 needed to get this project off the ground to secure shop time, pay the Greensaw team for doing the shop work (building cabinents, etc) because they would have to put larger paying projects on hold, and initial supplies. Therefore, all money will go into generated would contribute to initial funds not met because of losing state funding.
 
Phase II:
Getting donated building and art supplies for the art room.
 
I hope you can help. I really do.

Getting donated building and art supplies for the art room.
 
I hope you can help. I really do.

story:
Short Summary

Hello, my name is Alana Helin.  I am an engineering student at the University of Wisconsin-Plattville.  I have been selected by Engineers Without Borders to help the children of Ghana.  I am very excited about this opportunity but I need some help getting there.  Your contribution will help pay my expenses.  I dont want to ask for any resources in Ghana because they are so desperate for help.

Your contribution will make an incredible difference in the lives of underpriviledged children.  We will help build schools for the children.

Please help  with any small amount that you can.

story:
What we are doing...

 

Our organization brings together a large network of educators, financial professionals and curriculum providers to find the most efficient and cost effective way to reach students who are in need of financial literacy education. Our latest initiative is the youth basketball camp that we hope to implement. We have a head instructor who is on the coaching staff of a prominent Los Angeles college team. He brings with him connections to well-known college players and a few corporate sponsors. We hope that the opportunity to learn basketball skills with experienced coaches will draw students to join the camp while learning important life lessons that will protect them in the financial world. The camp will be held for 2 days in July for 6 hours each day. The students will have alot of fun and the coaches will keep them engaged with basketball training, guest speakers and literacy lessons. A rewards ceremony will also take place at the end of the camp.

Why You Should Support Us...

Our organization bring financial literacy curriculum to low-income communities where schools are not informed about the many different financial literacy materials that are available to them. We are always finding new ways to reach students so that they can be equipped with the basic lessons about the financial world. After the economic downtrend that started in 2008, financial literacy has come to the forefront of educational reform, but many states do not mandate this kind of curriculum, therefore it us up individuals and organizations that are passionate about the issue to continue advocating literacy. Our group of 6 is a passionate bunch, and when we set our minds to something we get the job done! We believe our work is imperative and our basketball camp proposal is the first of its kind that specifically serves this purpose. Hopefully this camp will be the first of many to come!

Our Impact Is...

We want to see a world where young students are given an equal opportunity to be financially sufficient and healthy. We believe that all youth, without regard to their economic background, should understand how to protect themselves in the business world that they will soon face. Financial literacy is a great way to provide these students with the basics to protecting themselves while creating a strong future population of capable and knowledgeable citizens.

story:
Friends , Family, Colleagues:

As a result of my audition for Harvard University's American Repertory Theater MFA program, I was invited back for the summer intensive they run in collaboration with the Moscow Art Theater School.Both of these are world renowned schools and the excitement I feel to have such an opportunity to study with amazing teachers and continue to develop my craft is immeasurable.


With your $20 ( tax deductible) donation you will help me achieve a huge step forward in my career as an actor and my goal to become a  teaching artist.


Your donation will go only towards paying the remaining balance of my tuition.


Please consider helping this dreamer out ! I will thank you for the rest of my days. Where ever my career takes me I will remember and thank those who helped me.



For more information about the programs click here :

http://www.americanrepertorytheater.org/inside/videos-podcasts/meet-institute-class-2012-why-artmxat

story:
Who We Are

 
Hack the Future is a recurring full-day event which helps inspire kids in the field of science and technology by providing a practical hands-on open-ended creative experience under the supervision of domain experts.  
 
Kids between the ages of 8 to 18 discover that it is possible for them to create things such as games, websites, and robots by creating these things live at the event. There is no set curriculum, only resources and challenges set before the kids. The kids are motivated by their own internal creativity and passions, and the results have absolutely blown us away.
 
 
 

Hack the Future creates a space for kids to bring their curiosity and dedication and be mentored by Silicon Valley engineers.  The patient and passionate environment of Hack the Future inspires these kids to take on challenges that even adults (sometimes even the ones there!) struggle with.
 

The program is funded entirely by donations and staffed entirely by volunteers. The event creates value without paid staff and without taxpayer involvement.  Your donation will go straight to the physical materials the children will be using to execute their projects, to Hack the Future shirts for children and adult volunteer Mentors, and to your contribution prize (should you select one).

 
To date we have run four successful events, three at the Tech Museum in San Jose and one on the Stanford Campus.  Hack the Future 5 is set to return to the Tech Museum on August 19. Unfortunately, we are struggling to find corporate sponsorship to help cover this specific event. In order to allow our volunteer Mentors to put their focus on designing more amazing startions for the kids to work on, we are now trying to raise the rest of event funds through IndieGoGo.
 

What We Need & What You Get

 
All of the funding collected by this campaign will go directly to materials to run the stations, food and drinks to fuel the kids throughout the event, and the T-shirts we use to keep kids excited and to designate volunteers.
 
We're really excited to offer a some awesome things to our wonderful backers: from your name projected on the wall to a shirt signed by the cofounders, we really want you to understand what an impact you are having on the lives and future opportunities of these children.
 
 
If we do not raise our entire goal, we will still apply all funds to this project. It just means that funds for the event will be coming out of our volunteers' personal pockets. The parents, the kids, and the volunteers have all been blown away by the incredible impact of Hack the Future, and we are absolutely dedicated to this program's success.
 

The Impact

 
The main goal is to empower the kids by helping them to realize that they can be creators of technology and not just consumers of it.
 
Many children, especially as they reach adolesence, struggle to find creative outlets for their energy and time. Hack the Future provides not only a positive outlet for these forces of nature, but gives the children real-world employable skills in a field that traditional education struggles to keep pace with.
 
"This is the first chance many kids will have to enter the exciting, advancing field of technology. Programming is literacy." 
 
--Joe Mathes, Hack the Future Co-Founder
 
Hack the Future has already offered four events, each teaching between 65-85 students, with many of the students happily returning for more classes and challenges.  

"Modern education lacks the resources to provide open-ended learning opportunities. Kids are losing the opportunity to engage with the world via their own self-discovered passions. At Hack the Future, we've been absolutely blown away by what these kids create when simply given the opportunity, and we're proud to give them a passion for technology that will serve them their whole life."

--Jocelyn Berl, Palo Alto District public school teacher for 12 years and Hack the Future Co-Founder.

 
 
With your help, we would like to grow and expand this program to offer these opportunities to more students.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not all of you can pitch in financially, so please consider lending us a hand in these other ways:
  • Share the campaign, especially on Facebook!
  • When you share, please include a little not about why the program is awesome, such as "I think this is an amazing program and I'd love to see them continue to exist." Little notes like these will make your link far more effective than a blank link.
  • Donate an unused and working laptop. Right now, we are only able to work with kids who alredy have one. We would love to be able to extend this opportunity to those without a computer. Contact information on our website.
  • Want to help mentor at the next HTF? Check out events at www.hackthefuture.org

From all of us at Hack the Future, thank you for your support!
